PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Delafield, Wisconsin. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the republication were the 1997 Code, as supplemented through November 20, 2017, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1997 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER 	CHT:1 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 	CHTCT:1 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CHARTER INDEX 	CHTi:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Beth Tattershall, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Jeanne O'Brien, Deputy Clerk/Treasurer, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

STATE OF WISCONSIN:  CITY OF DELAFIELD:  AUKESHA COUNTY: 
ordinance no. 770 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF DELAFIELD; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
WHEREAS, The Code entitled the "Municipal Code of the City of Delafield," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 52, each inclusive, is adopted. 
WHEREAS, all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before November 20, 2017, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
WHEREAS, the repeal provided shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
WHEREAS, unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  First offense. Any person who shall violate any provision of this Code shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $5.00 nor more than $500.00, but not more than the forfeiture permitted by statute together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs of prosecution shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
(2)  Second offense. Any person found guilty of violating any ordinance or part of an ordinance of this Code who has previously been convicted of a violation of the same ordinance within one year shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $500.00, but not more than the forfeiture permitted by statute for each such offense, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
WHEREAS, Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
WHEREAS, Ordinances adopted after November 20, 2017, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
NOW, THEREFORE, the Mayor and Common Council of the City of Delafield, Wisconsin, adopt the municipal code and enact a new code for the City of Delafield effective June 15, 2020. 
Passed and adopted this 15th day of June, 2020. 
CITY OF DELAFIELD 
By:___________ 
Kent Attwell, Mayor 
ATTESTED: 
___________ 
Michelle Luedtke City of Delafield, Clerk  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code of General Ordinances, the following rules shall be observed unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the ordinance: 
(1)  Wisconsin Statutes. All references to "Wisconsin Statutes" or "Wis. Stats." mean the current edition of the Wisconsin Statutes and includes the most recent biennial session. 
(2)  Gender, singular and plural. Every word in this Code and in any ordinance imparting the masculine gender may extend and be applied to females as well as males, and every word imparting the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things as well as to one person or thing; provided these rules of construction shall not be applied to any provision which contains any express language excluding such construction or when the subject matter or context of such provision may be repugnant thereto. 
(3)  Person. The word "person" extends and applies to natural persons, firms, corporations, associations, partnerships or other bodies politic and all entities capable of being sued, unless plainly inapplicable. 
(4)  Acts of agents. When a provision requires an act to be done which may, by law, as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent. 
(Code 1997, § 25.01)  
Sec. 1-2. - Conflict and separability. 
(a)  Conflict of provisions. If the provisions of the different chapters of this Code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all matters and questions arising out of the subject matter of such chapter. 
(b)  Separability of Code provisions. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of the Code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by reason of any decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of any other section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase or portion thereof. The council hereby declares that they would have passed this Code and each section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses, phrases or portions may be declared invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Code 1997, § 25.02)  
Sec. 1-3. - Clerk to file documents incorporated by reference. 
Whenever in this Code any standard, code, rule, regulation or other written or printed matter is adopted by reference, it shall be deemed incorporated in this Code as if fully set forth herein and the clerk shall file, deposit and keep in his office a copy of the code, standard, rule, regulation or other written or printed matter as adopted. Materials so filed, deposited and kept shall be public records open for examination with proper care by any person during the clerk's office hours, subject to such orders or regulations which the clerk may prescribe for their preservation. 
(Code 1997, § 25.03)  
Sec. 1-4. - Penalty provisions. 
(a)  General penalty. Except as otherwise provided, any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Code shall, upon conviction of such violation, be subject to a penalty, which shall be as follows: 
(1)  First offense. Any person who shall violate any provision of this Code shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $5.00 nor more than $500.00, but not more than the forfeiture permitted by statute together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs of prosecution shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
(2)  Second offense. Any person found guilty of violating any ordinance or part of an ordinance of this Code who has previously been convicted of a violation of the same ordinance within one year shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $500.00, but not more than the forfeiture permitted by statute for each such offense, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
(b)  Continued violations. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Nothing in this Code shall preclude the city from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provision of this Code. 
(c)  Execution against defendant's property. Whenever any person fails to pay any forfeiture and costs of prosecution upon the order of any court for violation of any ordinance of the city, the court may, in lieu of ordering imprisonment of the defendant, or after the defendant has been released from custody, issue an execution against the property of the defendant for such forfeiture and costs. 
(Code 1997, § 25.04)  
Sec. 1-5. - Repeal of general ordinances. 
All ordinances heretofore adopted by the city council are hereby repealed, except all ordinances or parts of ordinances relating to the following subjects and not conflicting with any of the provisions of this Code: 
(1)  The issuance of corporate bonds and notes of the city of whatever name or description. 
(2)  The establishment of grades, curb lines and widths of sidewalks in the public streets and alleys. 
(3)  The fixing of salaries of public officials and employees. 
(4)  Rights, licenses or franchises or the creation of any contract with the city. 
(5)  The lighting of streets and alleys. 
(6)  The annexation of territory to the city. 
(7)  The naming and changing of names of streets, alleys, public grounds and parks. 
(8)  The letting of contracts without bids. 
(9)  The establishment of aldermanic districts, aldermanic district boundaries and election precincts. 
(10)  Tax and special assessment levies. 
(11)  Releases of persons, firms or corporations from liability. 
(12)  Construction of public works. 
(13)  Water, sewer and electric rates, rules and regulations and sewer and water main construction. 
(14)  Budget ordinances, resolutions and actions. 
(Code 1997, § 25.05)  
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeals. 
The repeal or amendment of any section or provision of this Code or of any other ordinance or resolution of the council shall not: 
(1)  By implication be deemed to revive any ordinance not in force or existing at the time such repeal or amendment takes effect. 
(2)  Affect any vested right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed or amended, unless the privilege of repealing such obligation or privilege has been reserved by the city. 
(3)  Affect any offense committed, or penalty or forfeiture incurred, previous to the time when any ordinance is repealed or amended; except when any forfeiture or penalty has been mitigated by the provisions of any ordinance, such provisions shall apply to and control any judgment to be pronounced after such ordinance takes effect for any offense committed before that time. 
(4)  Affect any prosecution for any offense, or the levy of any penalty or forfeiture pending at the time when any ordinance aforesaid is repealed or amended; but the right of action shall continue and the offender shall be subject to the penalty as provided in such ordinance, and such prosecution shall proceed, in all respects, as if such ordinance had not been repealed; except all such proceedings had after the time this Code takes effect shall be conducted according to the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1997, § 25.06)  
Sec. 1-7. - Title; effective date citation. 
These ordinances shall be known as the "Municipal Code of the City of Delafield" and shall take effect from and after passage and publication as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.035. All references thereto shall be cited by section number (example: section 50-6, Municipal Code of the City of Delafield). 
(Code 1997, § 25.07)  
Sec. 1-8. - Keeping code current; revisor's amendments. 
As each ordinance or resolution affecting the Municipal Code becomes effective, the city clerk shall forward such ordinance or resolution to the revisor, who shall incorporate them into the Municipal Code. The revisor shall make no substantive changes to such ordinances and resolutions but may renumber, rearrange and edit them without first submitting them to the city clerk; and such rearranging, renumbering and editing shall not affect the validity of such ordinances and resolutions or the provisions of this Municipal Code affected thereby. 
(Code 1997, § 25.08)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 2-12-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL GOVERNMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-19. - Form of government. 
The City of Delafield shall be organized and governed under the provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 62. 
(Code 1997, § 1.01; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-20. - Elected officials. 
(a)  Officials. The elective officers of the city shall be a mayor, municipal judge and one alderman from each aldermanic district. 
(b)  Eligibility. No person shall be elected to a city office who is not, at the time of his election, 18 years of age, a citizen of the United States and of the state and an elector of the city, and, if an aldermanic district office, of the aldermanic district and actually residing therein. 
(Code 1997, § 1.02)  
Sec. 2-21. - Appointed officials. 
The following shall be appointed officials: 
Official 	How 
Appointed 	Term 
Administrator 	Mayor, subj. to conf. by the council 	Indefinite 
Chief of 
police 	Police comm. 	Indefinite

City attorney 	Mayor, subj. to conf. by the council 	2 yrs. 
City engineer 	Mayor, subj. to conf. by the council 	2 yrs., commencing May 1, even years.

(Code 1997, § 1.03; Rep. & Recr. 694 )  
Sec. 2-22. - Oaths and bonds. 
Elected and appointed officials shall take and file the official oath within ten days after notice of their election or appointment as provided in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4)(a) and shall execute and file the official bond as required by state statutes and this Municipal Code. 
(Code 1997, § 1.04)  
Sec. 2-23. - Removals. 
(a)  Elected officials. Elected officials may be removed by the city council as provided in Wis. Stats. § 17.12(1)(a) or 17.16. 
(b)  Appointed officials. Appointed officials may be removed as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 17.12(1)(c) and 17.16. 
(Code 1997, § 1.05)  
Sec. 2-24. - Vacancies. 
(a)  How occurring. Vacancies in elective and appointive positions are caused as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 17.03 and 17.035. 
(b)  How filled. Vacancies in elective and appointive offices shall be filled as provided in Wis. Stats. § 17.23. 
(Code 1997, § 1.06)  
Sec. 2-25. - Salaries. 
The salaries of all elected and appointed officials, including members of boards and commissions, shall be as determined by the city council from time to time, provided the salary of the mayor and members of the council shall not be increased during their terms of office. (See Wis. Stats. § 66.0505(2).) 
(Code 1997, § 1.07; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-26. - Receipt of gifts and gratuities. 
(a)  Restricted. No city employee or official shall receive or offer to receive, either directly or indirectly, any gift, gratuity or other thing of value which he is not authorized by ordinance or state statute to receive from any person who: 
(1)  Has or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the city or city council; or 
(2)  Conducts operations or activities which are regulated by the city or city council; or 
(3)  Has interests which may be substantially affected by the city or city council. 
(b)  Penalty. The receipt of any gift, gratuity or other thing of value as denoted above is contrary to the public policy of the city and is punishable as provided in Wis. Stats. § 946.12. Such conduct shall also be punishable under section 1-4. 
(Code 1997, § 1.08)  
Sec. 2-27. - Defense of officers. 
(a)  By city attorney. The city council may authorize the city attorney to defend actions brought against any officer or employee of the city or of any board or commission of the city growing out of any acts done in the course of his employment or out of any alleged breach of his duty as such officer or employee. This section is discretionary. The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 62.115 are incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  By private counsel. The city council may authorize special counsel privately retained by the officer or employee of the city or of any board or commission of the city to defend actions brought against the officer or employee growing out of any acts done in the course of his employment or out of any alleged breach of his duty as such officer or employee. The officer or employee is required to submit the name of the special counsel that the officer or employee wishes to retain and a written fee agreement. No fees or other costs of defense of any officer or employee of the city or of any board or commission of the city shall be paid by the city, unless the name of the special counsel and the fee arrangement have been submitted to and approved by council resolution. 
(Code 1997, § 1.09; Cr. #315)  
Secs. 2-282-57. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OFFICIALS 
 
Sec. 2-58. - Mayor and alderpersons. 
(a)  Election and term. 
(1)  The mayor and alderpersons from aldermanic districts 2, 4 and 6 shall be elected during even-numbered years. The alderpersons from aldermanic districts 1, 3, 5 and 7 shall be elected during odd-numbered years. (See Charter Ordinance No. 93.) 
(2)  Except as otherwise specifically provided, the regular term of the mayor and alderperson shall be two years. 
(b)  Duties and powers. 
(1)  Mayor. See Wis. Stats. § 62.09(8). 
(2)  City council. The alderpersons shall constitute the city council and shall have such duties and powers as are enumerated in Wis. Stats. ch. 62 and elsewhere in the statutes. 
(3)  Police powers. See section 26-22. 
(c)  Authority. The city council shall have all powers of the city not specifically given to some other body or officer. Except as otherwise provided by law, the city council shall have the management and control of the city property, finances, highways, streets, utilities and the public service and may act for the government and good order of the city, for its commercial benefit and for the health, safety, welfare and convenience of the public and may carry its powers into effect by license, regulations, suppression, borrowing, taxation, special assessment, appropriation, imposition of forfeiture and other necessary or convenient means. The city council may appoint such officers from time to time as may be deemed necessary for the benefit of the community. The powers hereby conferred shall be in addition to all other grants and shall be limited only by express language. 
(Code 1997, § 1.10; Am. #296; Am. #373; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-59. - Assessor. 
(a)  Appointment and term. See section 2-21. 
(b)  Applicable statute. See Wis. Stats. § 62.09. 
(c)  Duties and powers. 
(1)  Statutes. See Wis. Stats. §§ 70.12, 70.13, 70.17, 70.18, 70.23, 70.29, 70.30, 70.32, 70.34, 70.345, 70.35, 70.365, 70.43, 70.44, 70.45, 70.48, 70.49, 70.50, 70.501 and 70.503, in particular. 
(2)  Other duties prescribed law. The assessor shall perform such other duties as shall be prescribed by state law, supervisory personnel of the state department of revenue and the city council, including attendance at all meetings of the board of review. 
(Code 1997, § 1.11; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-60. - Municipal judge and municipal court. 
(a)  Municipal judge. 
(1)  Office created. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 755.01, there is created the office of municipal judge for the city. 
(2)  Election; term. The municipal judge shall be elected at large at the spring election in even-numbered years for a term of four years, or until a successor is elected and qualifies, commencing on May 1 next succeeding his election. 
(3)  Salary. The municipal judge shall receive a salary as determined from time to time by the city council, which shall be in lieu of fees and costs. No salary shall be paid to the judge for any time during his term for which he has not executed and filed his official bond and oath as required by subsection (a)(4) of this section. 
(4)  Bond; oath. 
a.  The municipal judge shall execute and file with the clerk of the courts for Waukesha County the oath prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 757.02 and a bond in the penal sum of $500.00. 
b.  The municipal judge shall not be qualified to act until a certified copy of the bond is filed with the city clerk and a certified copy of the oath is filed with the office of the state administrator of courts as required by Wis. Stats. § 755.03. 
(5)  Jurisdiction. The municipal judge shall have jurisdiction as provided by law and Wis. Stats. § 755.045 and exclusive jurisdiction of violations of city ordinances, resolutions and bylaws. 
(6)  Appointment of clerks, deputy clerks. The municipal judge shall, in writing, appoint such clerks and deputy clerks as are authorized by the council or board. Their salaries shall be fixed by the council or board as provided in Wis. Stats. § 755.10. 
(b)  Municipal court. 
(1)  Court established. The municipal court for the City of Delafield is established pursuant to Wis. Stats § 755.01(1) and ch. 755. 
(2)  Hours. The municipal court for the city shall be open as determined by order of the municipal judge. 
(3)  Location. The municipal judge shall keep his office and hold court in the city hall. 
(4)  Collection and return of forfeitures. The municipal judge shall collect all forfeitures, penalty assessments, fees and taxable costs in any action or proceeding before him and shall pay over such moneys to the city treasurer within seven days of collection. At such time the municipal judge shall also report to the city treasurer the title, nature of offenses and total amount of judgments imposed in actions and proceedings in which such moneys were collected. 
(5)  Contempt of court. 
a.  The municipal judge, after affording an opportunity to the person accused to be heard in defense, may punish for contempt of municipal court persons guilty of either of the following acts: 
1.  Disorderly, contemptuous and insolent behavior toward the judge while engaged in any judicial proceeding or other conduct which tends to interrupt the proceedings or to impair the respect due the judge's authority. 
2.  Resistance of or disobedience to any lawful order or process made or issued by the judge. 
b.  For the purpose of hearing the person's defense, the municipal judge may, if the alleged offender is not present, issue a warrant for the person to be brought before the municipal judge. 
c.  The municipal judge may, upon finding any person guilty of contempt, order such person to forfeit not more than $50.00 plus a penalty assessment under Wis. Stats. § 757.05. Upon nonpayment of the forfeiture and penalty the person found guilty of contempt may be sentenced to the county jail not to exceed seven days. 
(c)  Stipulations and deposits in municipal court. 
(1)  Deposit schedule to be established. The municipal judge shall establish and submit to the city council for approval in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 800.037, a schedule of deposits for violations of city ordinances, resolutions and bylaws except traffic regulations which are governed by Wis. Stats. § 345.27 and boating violations governed by Wis. Stats. § 23.67. When approved by the council, such deposit schedule shall be posted in the office of the municipal court clerk and the city police department. 
(2)  Stipulation and deposit in lieu of court appearance. Persons cited for violations of city ordinances, resolutions or bylaws for which a deposit has been established under this subsection shall be permitted to make a stipulation of no contest and a deposit in lieu of court appearance as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 800.037, 800.035 and 800.09. 
(3)  Traffic and boating deposits. The deposit schedule established by the Wisconsin Judicial Conference and the procedures set forth in Wis. Stats. chs. 23 and 345 shall apply to stipulations and deposits for violations of traffic regulations enacted in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 345.27 and boating regulations enacted in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 30.77. 
(4)  When not permitted. Stipulations and deposits shall not be permitted after initial appearance or in cases of contempt under subsection (b)(5) of this section. 
(Code 1997, § 1.12; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-61. - City attorney. 
(a)  Appointment and term. See section 2-21. 
(b)  Applicable statute. See Wis. Stats. § 62.09(12). 
(Code 1997, § 1.13)

See section 8-83. 
(Code 1997, § 1.14)  
Sec. 2-63. - Plumbing inspector.

Sec. 2-64. - City engineer.

(b)  Duties and powers. The city engineer shall perform such duties and have such powers as are provided by state statute and this Municipal Code or as shall be prescribed from time to time by the mayor or the city council. 
(c)  Compensation. The office of city engineer shall be compensated on a fee-for-service basis only at a rate to be agreed upon from time to time. 
(Code 1997, § 1.15)  
Sec. 2-65. - Clerk. 
(a)  Appointment and term. See section 2-21. 
(b)  Duties. The clerk shall perform those duties prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(11) and such other duties as the council may prescribe. 
(c)  Deputy. The clerk may, in writing filed with the mayor and in the office of the clerk, appoint a deputy who shall act under the clerk's direction and, in the clerk's absence or disability or in case of a vacancy, shall perform the clerk's duties and shall have power to administer oaths and affirmations. The deputy shall receive such compensation as the council shall provide. The clerk and the clerk's sureties shall be liable on the clerk's official bond for the acts of such deputy. 
(Code 1997, § 1.16; Am. Ch. Ord. #331) 
Editor's note Charter Ordinance 579, adopted Oct. 1, 2007, provided for the combining of the offices of clerk and treasurer. Appointment to be made by the mayor, subject to confirmation of the common council.

(c)  Deputy. The treasurer may, in writing filed with the mayor and in the office of the clerk, appoint a deputy who shall act under the treasurer's direction and, in the treasurer's absence or disability or in case of a vacancy, shall perform the treasurer's duties. The deputy shall receive such compensation as the council shall provide. The acts of such deputy shall be covered by official bond as the council shall direct. 
(Code 1997, § 1.192; Am. Ch. Ord. #331) 
Editor's note Charter Ordinance 579, adopted Oct. 1, 2007, provided for the combining of the offices of clerk and treasurer. Appointment to be made by the mayor, subject to confirmation of the common council.  
Sec. 2-70. - City administrator. 
(a)  Creation. There is hereby created the office of city administrator. The offices of city administrator and director of public works may be held by the same person, that person to be called city administrator/director of public works. 
(b)  Appointment and term. See section 2-21. 
(c)  Duties. The administrative duties and responsibilities of the city administrator shall be prescribed from time to time by the mayor and the council, provided these duties do not usurp the duties or functions that are required by state law to be performed by the city boards, commissions and other city officers or department officials. The administrator shall have the following specific duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Effectuate all actions of the council which require administrative implementation. 
(2)  Direct, coordinate and expedite the activities of all city departments, except where such authority is vested by State law in officers, boards and commissions. Such responsibilities shall include making or directing such studies as are necessary to determine or bring about the most economical, efficient operation of such departments and their programs as deemed necessary. However, the administrator shall not control the activities within the various departments, such functional departmental activities to remain under the direct control of the department heads. 
(3)  Direct and control, through appropriate organizational channels, the efficient performance of all city employees' duties. After the appropriate screening and selection process has been followed, the administrator shall submit recommendations to the mayor and council for appointees to vacancies in any city positions for offices of the city not required by law or ordinance to be otherwise selected. 
(4)  Develop budgeting procedures and prepare or supervise the preparation of the annual operating budget. The administrator shall also be responsible for coordinating financial and economic data for the city's long-range financial plans. In addition, the administrator shall make such reports as the mayor and the council require as to the current status of budgeted items and shall review and report to the mayor and council any variations in the operation of the city budget. 
(5)  Serve as personnel officer for the city and be responsible for the development and administration of standardized personnel policies and procedures, subject to council approval and in accordance with all prior ordinances relating to tenure of certain city positions; conduct labor negotiations with union representatives. 
(6)  Develop and implement standardized purchasing policy and procedure for the city. The administrator is responsible for supervising the purchasing of all supplies, materials and equipment. 
(7)  Review proposed and pending county, state and federal legislation and report to the mayor and council on its effect upon the city. In addition, the administrator shall appear on the city's behalf at all legislative and administrative hearings as directed by the mayor or the council. 
(8)  Submit, when necessary, recommendations and suggestions for improving the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city and coordinate a system of communications among and with the mayor and the council as well as with the general public. This shall include the establishment of procedures for the facilitation of the communications between citizens and the city to assure that complaints, grievances, recommendations and other matters receive the prompt attention of a responsible official and are expeditiously resolved. 
(9)  Keep informed concerning current developments in the field of municipal administration and the availability of state and federal funds for local purposes. 
(10)  Work closely with all department heads to ensure that they and other city employees receive adequate opportunities for training within budget allowances prescribed by the council to improve their knowledge and skills. The administrator shall act as the approving authority for all requests by city employees to attend conferences, meetings, training schools, etc., pertaining to their employment. 
(11)  In coordination with the mayor and the city clerk, prepare the agenda for all meetings of the council, together with such supporting data as may be required, provided nothing herein shall be construed to give the administrator authority to limit or prevent matters from being considered by the council. The administrator shall assist the mayor and the city clerk as required in the performance of their duties. 
(12)  Shall attend all meetings of the council, assisting the mayor and the city clerk as required in the performance of their duties; attends meetings of boards and commissions as necessary and desired. 
(13)  Negotiate, manage, and monitor a wide variety of city contracts with other governmental bodies and private vendors that provide service to city residents and customers. 
(14)  Serve as city liaison to a number of regional boards, commissions, agencies, and districts that provide services directly or indirectly to the city; creates and negotiates intergovernmental agreements for consideration by, and approval of, the city council. 
(15)  Manage a variety of special projects; serve as liaison with property owners, residents, contractors, engineers, and regulatory agencies. 
(16)  Apply for state and federal grants for the city alone or in conjunction with other governmental jurisdictions. 
(17)  Provide effective and efficient customer services and promote and maintain responsive community relations. 
(18)  Act as press officer for the city and be the spokesperson on all matters within his/her authority to assure that news media are kept fully informed and that all open meeting rules and regulations are followed. 
(19)  Assist in the preparation of ordinances and resolutions as requested by the mayor or the council as needed. 
(d)  Under Delafield Code section 52-293, the administrator "is hereby designated the administrative officer under the direction of the plan commission. The administrator may delegate certain administrative, inspection, and enforcement responsibilities to the building inspector or other city employees or independent contractors subject to approval by the plan commission." 
(e)  The City of Delafield organizational chart, designated as appendix A and on file in the office of the city clerk, shall hereby be adopted and established as the official organizational chart for the City of Delafield. Absent statutory conflicts to the contrary, this chart shall establish the chain of command throughout the organization. 
(Code 1997, § 1.193; Cr. Ch. Ord. #331; Cr. #410; Cr. #585; Am. #585; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-71. - Director of tourism, promotion, and economic development. 
(a)  Office created. The office of tourism, promotion, and economic development is hereby created. The city promotion and tourism commission ("commission") shall appoint a director of tourism, promotion, and economic development. 
(b)  Duties. The office of tourism, promotion and economic development shall serve as a tourism entity, and shall be responsible for performing those duties and obligations imposed upon a tourism entity as described in Wis. Stats. § 66.0615. The director shall, coordinate and expedite tourism, promotion and economic development activities within the city, and shall perform such other duties as the city promotion and tourism commission may authorize and direct. 
(c)  Budget. The director shall, after giving due consideration to the anticipated tax revenues to be collected by the city under section 46-3 ("Room Tax"), formulate and submit an annual budget pursuant to the financial policies and procedures of the city. Funding for the office shall be exclusively from room tax proceeds. The city shall not budget or make payments in excess of the room tax collected under section 46-3. No expenditure exceeding the budget approved by the council shall be made without an appropriate fund transfer approved by the city council. 
(Code 1997, § 1.194; Cr. # 734 ) 
( Ord. No. 747 , §§ 1, 2, 8-20-2018)  
Secs. 2-722-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND DEPARTMENTS 
 
Sec. 2-101. - City plan commission. 
(a)  How constituted. The city plan commission shall consist of the mayor, who shall be its presiding officer, one alderperson, and six citizen members. The chairperson or designee of the lake welfare committee and park and recreation commission, shall be appointed as citizen members together with four additional citizen members. The plan commission shall, at all times consist of eight members. Members shall for cause be removable by the city council. 
(b)  Appointment and term. 
(1)  Citizen members. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. 
(2)  Appointment. Citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor annually in April for staggered three-year terms, subject to confirmation by city council. 
(3)  Alderperson member. Annually, during the month of April, the alderperson member of the plan commission shall be appointed by the mayor and subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The authority of the city plan commission and its functions and duties shall be as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 62.23. 
(Code 1997, § 1.20; Am. #558; Am. #599; Rep. & Recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-102. - Park and recreation commission. 
(a)  Composition. The park and recreation commission shall consist of seven members. One member shall be a city alderman, selected annually by majority vote of the city council to serve for a one-year term to begin on May 1. The six citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the members of the city council. Members of the park and recreation commission shall be qualified residents of the city. 
(b)  Terms. Each citizen member shall serve a three-year term, the terms to be staggered by the appointment of two citizen members each year so as to provide continuity of membership. 
(c)  Organization. 
(1)  Officers. The commission members shall annually elect for one-year terms, to begin in May, a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. 
(2)  Vacancies. Any vacancies occurring on the park and recreation commission shall be filled by appointment by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. Such appointees shall serve the balance of the term of the member replaced. 
(d)  Duties and powers. 
(1)  Buying, selling and letting. The park and recreation commission shall have the power to purchase, lease, sell or exchange park or recreation lands, facilities and equipment, subject to approval of the city council. 
(2)  Acquisition by other means. The commission shall have the power to acquire any park or recreation lands, facilities and equipment by gift, devise, bequest or condemnation, either absolutely or in trust; money, real or personal property, or any incorporeal right or privilege, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(3)  Control and management. The commission shall have the power to govern, manage, control, improve, develop, maintain and operate all city parks or recreational lands, facilities, equipment and activities and to adopt necessary rules and regulations for such purposes. 
(4)  Tree board. The commission shall also serve as the city's tree board as required to meet the Arbor Day Foundation's Tree City USA standards. The commission shall be charged with developing and administering a comprehensive tree management program. The commission shall be responsible for writing and implementing an annual community forestry work plan. The commission shall also have all powers and duties enumerated in Wis. Stats. § 27.09. 
(5)  Other duties. The commission shall have such additional powers and duties as shall be assigned by the city council in addition to all powers enumerated in Wis. Stats. § 27.08. 
(e)  Finances. The commission shall submit to the city administrator by August 1 of each year a proposed program and budget for the ensuing year. The commission shall not contract any liability in excess of the budget appropriated unless specifically authorized by the city council. All monies received for the purposes of the commission, whether from the general fund or from approved donations or from such reasonable fees as may be charged for activities, facilities or services, shall be deposited in the general fund of the city and segregated on the books of the city. The city treasurer shall act as treasurer of the commission without additional compensation. 
(Code 1997, § 1.21; Am. #282; Am. #559; Cr. # 687 )  
Sec. 2-103. - Zoning board of appeals. 
(a)  How constituted. The city zoning board of appeals shall consist of five members to be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. Members shall be appointed to staggered three-year terms, with one or two members to be appointed each year. In addition, the mayor shall appoint two alternate members of the board of appeals, who shall act with full power only when a member of the board refuses to vote because of interest or when a regular member is absent. Any vacancy occurring on the board shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member involved, by appointment and confirmation as stipulated for full-term appointments. Members shall be removable for cause as provided by law. 
(b)  Powers and duties. The zoning board of appeals shall have the power to adopt rules; meet and hear and determine appeals as prescribed by law; and shall have all of the powers conferred or conferrable thereon by the provisions of any statute, law, rule or provision of this Code now existing or hereafter created, including, but not limited to, the power, in appropriate cases and subject to appropriate conditions and safeguards, to make special exceptions to the terms of the Zoning Code or of any other zoning provisions hereafter adopted, in harmony with the general purposes and intent of such regulations and in accordance with general or specific rules therein contained. Such exceptions or variances may be granted upon determination by the board that the variance shall not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the terms of the Zoning Code shall result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of the regulations shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. See Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(e). 
(Code 1997, § 1.22)  
Sec. 2-104. - Water pollution control commission. 
See section 50-3. 
(Code 1997, § 1.24)  
Sec. 2-105. - Police commission. 
(a)  Creation. The police commission shall consist of five citizens, three of whom shall constitute a quorum. The mayor shall annually, between the last Monday of April and the first Monday of May, appoint in writing, to be filed with the secretary of the commission, one member for a five-year term. The initial appointments shall be of the required five commissioners each for varying terms from one to five years. All appointments shall be subject to confirmation by the council. No appointment shall be made which will result in more than three members of the commission belonging to the same political party. 
(b)  Ex officio alderman member. In addition to the members provided in subsection (a) of this section, the mayor shall appoint for a term of one year, subject to confirmation by the council, one alderman to serve with the commission as an ex officio nonvoting member. 
(c)  Duties. The police commission shall perform such duties as are prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 62.13. 
(d)  Rules. The police commission shall keep a record of its proceedings, and shall adopt rules and regulations necessary to carry out its duties. 
(Code 1997, § 1.25; Rep. & Recr. #625)  
Sec. 2-106. - Public works committee. 
(a)  Public works committee. The department of public works shall operate within the authority of the public works committee as granted by the city council. The public works committee shall be comprised of seven members to include one member of the city council serving a one-year term, renewable annually; and six citizen members serving three-year terms. Appointments shall be made by the mayor with approval of the city council. 
(b)  Duties. The department of public works shall be responsible for the maintenance, repair and construction of all city bridges, buildings, grounds, public rights-of-way, as well as repair and maintenance of city sanitary sewers and equipment pertinent to its functions. 
(c)  Administration. The city administrator shall administer the department of public works. 
(Code 1997, § 1.26; Rep. & recr. #694 )  
Sec. 2-107. - Board of review. 
(a)  Composition. The board of review shall consist of the mayor, the president of the common council, and five citizen members who shall be appointed by the mayor to serve a term of two years, subject to confirmation by the common council. In addition, the mayor shall appoint two alternate members to the board of review who shall serve a term of two years, and whose appointment shall be subject to confirmation by the common council. One alternate member shall be designated as the first alternate and the other as being the second alternate. Alternate members, when required, shall act with full power when a member of the board of review refuses to vote because of conflict of interest, is absent, or if a person who is objecting to a valuation requests the removal of a board of review member pursuant to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 70.47(6m) or is otherwise unavailable to hear an objection. The mayor and common council president shall receive no additional compensation for service on the board of review, but citizen members and alternate members shall be compensated at a rate of $40.00 per meeting, or such other compensation as may be determined annually by the common council. The mayor, or in the absence of the mayor, the president of the common council shall chair the board of review. 
(b)  Duties; Wisconsin Statutes adopted by reference. The duties and functions of the board of review shall be as prescribed in Wis. Stats. §§ 70.46, 70.47 and 70.48, which sections of the Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference. 
(c)  Confidentiality of information about income and expenses. Whenever the assessor, in the performance of the assessor's duties, requests or obtains income and expense information pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), or any successor statute thereto, then such income and expense information that is provided to the assessor shall be held by the assessor on a confidential basis except, however, that the information may be released to and used by persons; in the discharging of duties imposed by law; in the discharge of duties imposed by office (including, not limited to, use by the assessor in performance of official duties of the assessor's office and used by the board of review in performance of its official duties) or pursuant to order of a court. Income and expense information provided to the assessor under Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), unless a court determines that it is inaccurate, is not, per Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), subject to the right of inspection or copying under Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1). 
(d)  Hearing procedure. In accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 70.47(8), the board of review is authorized to consider requests and objections from property owners or the property owner's representatives to offer testimony, under oath, by telephone or submit written statements under oath to the board of review. The following procedure shall apply to such requests: 
(1)  A property owner or property owner's representative may request that the board of review consider testimony offered under oath by telephone, or consider written statements submitted under oath, provided that: 
a.  The requirements of Wis. Stats. § 70.47, which requires that the property owner or property owner's representative provide notice of intent to appear at the board of review hearing are satisfied; and 
b.  The objection form for real estate property assessment (PA-115A) has been completed and submitted to the board of review in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 70.47; and 
c.  A request to testify by telephone or submit a written statement under oath to the board of review (Form PA-814) shall be filed with the city clerk. Such requests must be submitted timely to be considered by the board of review at the first meeting of the board of review. 
(2)  Criteria to be considered. The board of review may consider any and all of the following factors when deciding whether to grant or deny a request established under this subsection: 
a.  The requester's stated reason(s) for the request as indicated on the PA-814. 
b.  Fairness to the parties. 
c.  Ability of the requester to procure in person oral testimony and any due diligence exhibited by the requester in procuring such testimony. 
d.  Ability to cross-examine the person providing the testimony. 
e.  The board of review's technical capacity to honor the request. 
f.  Any other factors that the board deems pertinent to deciding the request. 
(Code 1997, § 1.27; Cr. #433; Cr. #464; Cr. #715 ; Rep. & Recr. # 736 )  
Sec. 2-108. - Lake welfare committee. 
(a)  Committee created. A committee to represent the City of Delafield. Such committee shall be known as the "lake welfare committee" (hereafter called the "committee"), pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.11(5). The purpose of this committee is to study problems and issues relating to Nagawicka Lake, Upper Nashotah Lake, and the Bark River within the city limits, and make recommendations to the common council concerning solutions thereto. 
(b)  Membership. 
(1)  Number of members. The committee shall consist of 11 members as follows: one member of the common council, one representative from the Village of Nashotah, and nine City of Delafield citizen members. 
(2)  Selection. All members shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of the common council. 
(3)  Term of office. The representative of the common council and the representative from the Village of Nashotah shall serve one year terms. Those citizen members from the odd-numbered aldermanic districts shall serve two-year terms to expire in the odd-numbered years, and those citizen members from even-numbered aldermanic districts shall serve two-year terms that expire in the even-numbered years. 
(4)  Citizen member. Citizen members shall represent as closely as possible the seven aldermanic districts. 
(5)  Removal. Any member of the committee may only be removed by a majority vote of the common council. 
(6)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the mayor with approval of the common council. Each successor so selected shall serve the remaining term of the member whose office has been vacated. 
(c)  Officers. 
(1)  Officers designated. The officers of the committee shall be a chair and a vice-chair. In addition, the committee may choose to appoint a clerk. 
(2)  Selection and term of office. Each committee officer shall be elected annually by the committee members at the June meeting and shall serve a one-year term. 
(3)  Removal. Any officer may be removed by a majority vote of the committee. 
(4)  Vacancies. Any vacancy of office shall be filled by the committee at its next meeting following the vacancy. 
(d)  Meetings. 
(1)  Regular meetings. The committee shall meet once a month, or additionally as needed. 
(2)  Annual lake awareness meeting. The committee shall have an annual lake awareness meeting each year. 
(e)  Powers and duties. The committee shall be responsible for investigating any and all issues and concerns that arise regarding Nagawicka Lake, Upper Nashotah Lake, and the Bark River within the city limits and make recommendations to the common council concerning solutions thereto. 
(Code 1997, § 1.29; Cr. #573; Rep. & Recr. #694 ) 
( Ord. No. 758 , § 1, 11-18-2019; Ord. No. 766 , § 1, 1-20-20)  
Sec. 2-109. - Library board. 
The library board shall be appointed pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 43.54(1) and 43.60. 
(Code 1997, § 1.295; Rep. & Recr. #647)  
Sec. 2-110. - Deer management committee. 
(a)  Committee created. The common council has determined that a deer management committee shall be created to implement the deer management plan and policy approved by the common council. The deer management committee shall be advisory to the common council. 
(b)  Membership. 
(1)  Number of members. The deer management committee shall consist of seven members as follows: one member of the common council, one member from the public works committee, one member from the park and recreation commission, one member from the promotional and tourism council, and three city citizen members. 
(2)  Selection. All members shall be appointed by the mayor with confirmation by a majority of the members of the common council. 
(3)  Term of appointments. The representative from the common council shall serve a one-year term. All other members shall serve staggered two-year terms (half of these initial appointments shall be one-year terms to accomplish the staggering) to provide continuity of membership, with half of the terms expiring in even numbered years and half of the terms expiring in odd numbered years. The terms of the public works committee member and two of the citizen members shall expire in even numbered years. The terms of the park and recreation commission member, the promotional and tourism council member, and one of the citizen members shall expire in odd numbered years. Terms shall expire in April as part of the common council organizational meeting appointments following the spring election. 
(4)  Removal. Members shall, for cause, be removable by a majority vote of the common council. 
(5)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the mayor with confirmation by a majority of the members of the common council. Each successor so elected shall serve the remaining term of the member they replaced. 
(6)  Officers. The officers of the deer management committee shall include a chair and a vice-chair. Officers shall be elected annually, following the April appointment, by the committee members. The chair shall work with city staff to coordinate meetings, set the meeting agendas and packet documentation, and shall preside over all meetings of the deer management committee when in attendance. The vice-chair shall fulfill the responsibilities of the chair when the chair is unavailable or absent. Any officer may be removed as an officer (not as a committee member) by a majority vote of the committee members. Officer vacancies shall be filled by the committee at its next meeting following the vacancy. 
(c)  Termination of committee. Unless otherwise terminated by action of the common council, adopted by a majority of the common council, the deer management committee shall terminate on March 31, 2023. 
( Ord. No. 746 , § 1, 5-21-2018)  
Secs. 2-1112-131. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - POLITICAL BOUNDARIES 
 
Sec. 2-132. - Aldermanic districts. 
(a)  District 1. Wards 1 and 2, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 3, 4, 5, 8, 9 and 16 lying east and north of Nagawicka Lake and north of Oakwood Road and Evergreen Lane, extended to the east shore of Nagawicka Lake. 
(b)  District 2. Wards 3 and 4, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 16, 21 and 20 lying east and south of Nagawicka Lake; south of Oakwood Road and Evergreen Lane, extended to the east shore of Nagawicka Lake; north of I-94; east of Genesee Street; and south and east of Poplar Path, Woodberry Drive, W. Devonshire Road, N. Lapham Peak Road, E. Devonshire Road, 1st Street, extended to E. Devonshire Road, and 3rd Street extended to Nagawicka Lake. 
(c)  District 3. Wards 7 and 8, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 17, 20, and 19 lying south of Nagawicka Lake and the Bark River; east of Genesee Street; north and west of 3rd Street extended to Nagawicka Lake, 1st Street, extended to E. Devonshire Road, E. Devonshire Road, N. Lapham Peak Road, W. Devonshire Road, Woodberry Drive, Poplar Path, and Genesee Street; and an area lying west of Genesee Street, south of Main Street and north of Wells Street, east of Butler Drive, north of Pamelia Street extended to Butler Drive and including Parcels 0793-051, 0793-052, and 0793-053. 
(d)  District 4. Wards 5 and 6, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 27, 21, 20, 19 and 30 lying south of I-94 west of Genesee Street, south of Main Street, except that part of Section 19 as described follows; the area lying south of Main Street, west of Genesee Street and north of Wells Street, east of Butler Drive, north of Pamelia Street extended to Butler Drive and including Parcels 0793-051, 0793-052, and 0793-053. 
(e)  District 5. Wards 9 and 10, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 18 and 19 lying north of Main Street, west of Genesee Street and South of Oakwood Drive. 
(f)  District 6. Wards 11 and 12, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 17, 18, and 8 lying west of Nagawicka Lake, north of the Bark River and east of Genesee Street; and the area lying north of Oakwood Drive, east of Hillcrest Drive and south of Copperfield Drive. 
(g)  District 7. Wards 13 and 14, includes all of the area in the city, which are a part of Sections 18, 7, and 6 lying north of Oakwood Drive, west of Hillcrest Drive, north of Copperfield Drive and west of Genesee Street. 
(Code 1997, § 1.30; Rep. & Recr. #660)  
Sec. 2-133. - Annexations. 
(a)  Ordinances. #51, Gigas property; #79, Nickel property; #121 (repealed); #123, Butler's Woods; #124, Binkowski and Cistercian property; #136, Nickel property; #138, Nashotah House property; #163, Nickel property; #203, Exhibit B Hirsch; #220, Nickel property; #220, Tax Key Nos. 807.989 and 807.990; #234, Nickel property; #234, Tax Key No. 807.988; #407, Hartland Sportsmen's Club; #414, County property; #550, County property; #704, County property. 
(b)  Security for payment of litigation costs. 
(1)  Prior to city council action on a pending annexation, the applicant shall file with the city clerk-treasurer sufficient security, approved by the city attorney, to pay the costs of litigation to test the validity of such annexation. 
(2)  Such security may be in the form of a cash or surety bond in an amount determined by the city attorney or in the form of an irrevocable letter of credit from a recognized lending institution. If such security is not filed, the city council may reject the petition for annexation. 
(Code 1997, § 1.31; #704 )  
Secs. 2-1342-164. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ELECTIONS 
 
Sec. 2-165. - Polling places. 
The polling place for all aldermanic districts shall be located at Christ the King Lutheran Church, 1600 N. Genesee Street. 
(Code 1997, § 1.40; Am. #236; Am. #594)  
Sec. 2-166. - Registration of electors. 
A registry of electors shall be made for each aldermanic district applicable to regular, special and primary elections. 
(Code 1997, § 1.41)  
Sec. 2-167. - Spring primary. 
Whenever three or more candidates file nomination papers for a city office, the primary election to nominate candidates shall be held. 
(Code 1997, § 1.42; Cr. Ch. Ord. #63)  
Sec. 2-168. - Polling hours. 
Polls shall be open in the city from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1997, § 1.43; Cr. #180)  
Secs. 2-1692-189. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - THE GOVERNING BODY 
 
Sec. 2-190. - The city council. 
The city council shall consist of the mayor and one alderperson from each aldermanic district, who shall be elected for two-year terms. 
(Code 1997, § 2.01)  
Sec. 2-191. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. Regular meetings of the city council shall be held at least once per month, typically on the third Monday of each calendar month. By October 31 of each year the city council shall approve a schedule of city council meetings for the next year. The city clerk shall publish this approved schedule on the city's website by November 15 of each year. For months when a second city council meeting is scheduled, it shall typically be scheduled for the first Monday of the month. City council meetings shall be held in the council chambers at City Hall, unless otherwise noted. City council meetings shall begin at 7:00 p.m., unless otherwise noted, and shall be open and public pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 19. 
(b)  Special meetings. Special meetings of the city council may be called by the mayor or any two alderpersons with written notice filed with the clerk at least 24 hours prior to the time specified for such meeting. The clerk shall notify each alderperson of the time and purpose of such meeting by telephone, electronic mail and/or causing a written notice thereof to be delivered to each alderperson. Special meetings may be held without such notice when all members of the city council are present in person or consent in writing to the holding of such meeting, such written consent to be filed with the clerk prior to the beginning of the meeting. Any special meeting attended by all the alderpersons shall be a regular meeting for the transaction of any business that may come before such meeting. 
(c)  Adjournments. The council may, by a majority vote of those present, but not less than three affirmative votes, adjourn from time to time to a specific date and hour. 
(Code 1997, § 2.02; Am. #373; Rep. & Recr. #695 ) 
( Ord. No. 753 , § 1, 10-7-2019)  
Sec. 2-192. - Presiding officer. 
(a)  Designated. The mayor shall preside. In the absence of the mayor, the president of the council shall preside. In the absence of both the mayor and the president, the city clerk shall call the meeting to order and preside until the alderpersons present elect one of their number acting mayor for that meeting. 
(b)  Duties. The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum, decide all questions of order and conduct the proceedings of the meeting in accordance with the parliamentary rules contained in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, unless otherwise provided by statute or by these rules. 
(c)  Decisions, appeals from. Any member may appeal from a decision of the presiding officer. An appeal shall be sustained by a two-thirds vote of the council. 
(Code 1997, § 2.03; Am. #373)  
Sec. 2-193. - Roll call; quorum. 
(a)  Roll call; procedure when quorum not in attendance. As soon as the council is called to order, the city clerk shall proceed to call the names of the members, noting who are present and who are absent, and record the same in the proceedings of the council. If there is not a quorum present, the fact shall be entered in the minutes and the council may adjourn; or the mayor or, in his absence, the clerk may issue a process to any policeman commanding him forthwith to summon the absentees. 
(b)  Quorum. Two-thirds of the members shall be a quorum, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.11(3)(b). The mayor shall not be counted in computing a quorum. In determining a quorum of the council, the term "member" shall mean those council members who have been duly elected or appointed for a current regular or unexpired term and whose service has not been terminated by death, resignation or removal from office. 
(Code 1997, § 2.04; Rep. & Recr. #695 )  
Sec. 2-194. - Order of business. 
The business of the council shall be conducted in the following order: 
(1)  Call common council meeting to order. 
(2)  Pledge of Allegiance. 
(3)  Roll call. 
(4)  Approve minutes. 
(5)  City of Delafield citizen's comments for items not on the agenda. City of Delafield citizen's comments for items on the agenda. 
(6)  Consent agenda. 
(7)  Committee reports. Report on discussion and action taken at previous meetings, future agenda items and upcoming scheduled meetings. 
a.  Licenses. 
b.  Plan commission. 
c.  Lake welfare committee. 
d.  Park and recreation commission. 
e.  Public works committee. 
f.  Del-Hart commission. 
g.  Police commission. 
h.  Library board. 
i.  Board of zoning. 
j.  Promotional and tourism committee. 
k.  Lake Country fire commission. 
l.  Lake Country fire board. 
(8)  Unfinished business. 
(9)  Mayor's report. 
(10)  New business. 
(11)  Reports of city officials. 
a.  Administrator. 
b.  Clerk-treasurer. 
c.  Council requests for future agenda items. NO DISCUSSION OF REQUESTED ITEMS. 
(12)  Correspondence. 
(13)  Adjourn. 
(Code 1997, § 2.05; Rep. & Recr. #695 )  
Sec. 2-195. - Clerk pro tem. 
In the absence of the clerk, the mayor shall appoint a clerk pro tem. 
(Code 1997, § 2.06; Am. #373)  
Sec. 2-196. - Mayor to conduct. 
The mayor at the stated hour shall call the meeting to order. He shall preserve order and decorum, decide all questions of order and conduct the proceedings of the meeting in accordance with the parliamentary rules contained in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, unless otherwise provided by statute or by these rules. Any member shall have the right of appeal from a decision of the presiding officer. The appeal may be sustained by a majority of the members present, exclusive of the presiding officer. 
(Code 1997, § 2.07)  
Sec. 2-197. - President to conduct in absence of mayor. 
If the mayor is absent at the designated time of any meeting, the president of the council shall preside, and during the absence or inability of the mayor, shall have the powers and duties of the mayor, excepting that he shall not have the power to approve an act of the council which the mayor has disapproved by filing an objection with the clerk. He shall, when so officiating, be styled "acting mayor." The president shall be selected by a two-thirds vote of all members of the council at the annual organizational meeting on the third Tuesday of April. In the absence of both the mayor and the president of the council, the clerk shall call the meeting to order and preside until the council shall, by motion, select an acting mayor for that meeting. 
(Code 1997, § 2.08; Am. #373)  
Sec. 2-198. - Conduct of deliberations. 
(a)  Presiding officer speaking. Whenever the presiding officer shall desire to speak upon any question, or to make any motion, he shall vacate the chair and designate the president of the council, if present, or any alderperson to preside temporarily. 
(b)  Council may act as committee of the whole. The mayor may declare the entire council a committee of the whole for informal discussion at any meeting or for any other purpose, and shall ex officio be chairman of the same, provided there is no objection by any one of the alderpersons present at the meeting. 
(c)  Appointment of committees. The mayor may, from time to time, appoint such special committee or committees as he may deem advisable or as provided for by motion or resolution stating the number of members and object thereof to perform such duties as may be assigned to them. 
(Code 1997, § 2.09)  
Sec. 2-199. - Consideration of matters before the council. 
(a)  Reference to committee. All ordinances, resolutions, communications and other matters submitted to the council shall be read by title and author and acted on by the council unless the council chooses to refer such matters to the appropriate committee for study and recommendation back to the council. The clerk shall read and record each such reference by title. Any alderperson may require the reading in full of any matter at any time it is before the council. 
(b)  Financial claims upon the city. All bills and other financial claims against the city shall be itemized and upon receipt thereof shall be examined by the clerk and referred by the clerk to the next meeting of the council, provided that payment of regular wages and salaries of officials and employees according to schedules adopted by the council shall be made by the clerk without submission to the council after verification and approval by the mayor. 
(c)  Committee minutes required. Each committee shall, at the next regular council meeting, submit written minutes of all matters considered by it. 
(d)  Committee may require conference. When authorized by the council, any committee may require any city official to confer with it and supply information needed in connection with any matter pending before the committee. 
(e)  Action on matters discussed. When a question is under discussion, no action shall be in order except the following motions which shall have precedence in the order listed: 
(1)  To adjourn; 
(2)  To recess; 
(3)  To lay on the table; 
(4)  To move the previous question; 
(5)  To postpone to a certain day; 
(6)  To refer to a committee; 
(7)  To amend; or 
(8)  To postpone indefinitely. 
(f)  Termination of debate. Any member desiring to terminate debate may move the previous question, in which event the presiding officer shall announce the question as, "Shall the main question now be put?" If a majority of the members present vote in the affirmative, the main question shall be taken without further debate, its effect being to put an end to all debate and bring the council to a direct vote, first upon any pending amendments and then upon the main question. 
(g)  Vote may be demanded. Any alderperson may demand an aye and nay vote on any matter, and such vote shall be entered in the proceedings. On confirmation of appointments and on the adoption of any measure assessing or levying taxes, appropriating or disbursing money, or creating any liability or charge against the city, or any fund thereof, the vote shall be aye and nay. Every member shall vote when a question is put unless the council by a majority vote of those present excuses him for special cause. A majority vote of all members of the council in favor of any proposed ordinance, resolution or appointment shall be necessary for passage or approval unless a larger number is required by statute. Except as otherwise provided by these rules, a majority vote of those present shall prevail in other cases. 
(h)  Mayor to abstain. The mayor shall not vote except in the case of a tie. When the mayor does vote in the case of a tie, his vote shall be counted in determining whether a sufficient number of council members has voted favorably or unfavorably on any measure. A majority vote of all members of the council in favor of any proposed ordinance, resolution or appointment shall be necessary for passage or approval, unless a larger number is required by statute. Except as otherwise provided, a majority vote of those present shall prevail in other cases. 
(i)  Motion to adjourn. A motion to adjourn shall always be in order; and a motion to adjourn, to recess or to lay on the table and a call for the previous question shall be decided without debate. 
(j)  Resolutions appropriating money or creating charges to the city. All ordinances or resolutions appropriating money or creating any charge against the city other than the payment of claims for purchases or work previously authorized by the council shall not be finally acted upon by the council sooner than at the next regular meeting following their introduction, provided that this provision may be suspended by affirmative action by three-fourths of all members of the council. 
(Code 1997, § 2.10; Am. #173; Am. #373)  
Sec. 2-200. - Reconsideration of question. 
Any member voting with the majority may move for a reconsideration of the vote on any question at that meeting. A motion to reconsider being put and lost shall not be renewed. An alderperson may not change his vote on any question after the result has been announced. 
(Code 1997, § 2.11)  
Sec. 2-201. - Disturbances and disorderly conduct. 
Whenever any disturbance or disorderly conduct occurs in any meeting of the council, the presiding officer may cause the room to be cleared of all persons guilty of such disorderly conduct except the alderpersons. If any alderperson is guilty of disorderly conduct, the presiding officer may order the police to take him/her into custody for the time being or until the meeting adjourns. Such member may appeal from such order to the council as in other cases. 
(Code 1997, § 2.13; Am. #373)  
Sec. 2-202. - Appropriations and accounts. 
All demands or accounts shall be acted upon at the time of presentation unless one or more members demands a reference. 
(Code 1997, § 2.14)  
Sec. 2-203. - Publication and effect of ordinances. 
(a)  Publication. All general ordinances of the city, and all regulations imposing a penalty, or a summary of the general ordinance or regulation as permitted by Wis. Stats. § 62.11(4)(c)1., shall be published in the official newspaper of the city as a Class 1 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985, and shall be immediately recorded by the city clerk in a book kept for that purpose. Affidavits of publication shall be filed separately. A printed copy of such ordinance or resolution in any book, pamphlet or newspaper and published or purporting to be published therein by direction of the city council shall be prima facie proof of due passage, publication and recording thereof. 
(b)  Effective date. Unless otherwise provided, all ordinances shall take effect and be in force from and after passage and publication; and published copies thereof shall have appended the date of first publication. 
(Code 1997, § 2.16; Am. #373; Am. #592)  
Sec. 2-204. - Amendment of rules. 
These rules shall not be rescinded or amended unless the proposed amendment or motion to rescind has laid over from a regular meeting, and then it shall require a vote of two-thirds of all the members of the council. 
(Code 1997, § 2.17)  
Sec. 2-205. - Suspension of rules. 
These rules or any part thereof may be temporarily suspended in connection with any matter under consideration by a recorded vote of the members present. 
(Code 1997, § 2.18)  
Secs. 2-2062-233. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE 
 
Sec. 2-234. - Fiscal year. 
The calendar year shall be the fiscal year. 
(Code 1997, § 3.02)  
Sec. 2-235. - Budget. 
(a)  Departmental estimates. Annually, on or before October 1, each officer or department shall file with the finance officer/budget analyst an itemized statement of disbursements made to carry out the powers and duties of the officer or department during the preceding fiscal year, a detailed statement of the receipts and disbursements on account of any special fund under the supervision of the officer or department during the year and of the condition and management of the fund and detailed estimates of the same matters for the current fiscal year and for the ensuing fiscal year. Such statements, which shall be designated as "departmental estimates," shall be presented in the form prescribed by the finance officer/budget analyst, such form to be as nearly uniform as possible for the main division of all departments. 
(b)  Budget preparation. 
(1)  Finance officer/budget analyst to submit estimates. The finance officer/budget analyst shall submit all departmental estimates to the city administrator who shall be responsible for the preparation of the annual budget, per section 2-70(c)(4). 
(2)  Information required. The budget shall include the following information:
