The developer or landowner shall provide a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse or storm sewer, and such further width for construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose and as may be necessary to comply with this section; or 
b.  The watercourse, drainageway, storm sewer, channel, or stream may be relocated in such a manner that the maintenance of adequate drainage will be assured. When channels are relocated, the developer or owner shall provide a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming to the lines of the relocated watercourse, and such further width for construction, or both. 
c.  Whenever possible, drainage shall be maintained in an easement by an open channel with vegetated banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume flow. In all cases, such easements shall be wide enough to convey the ten-year critical duration storm for the minor drainage system. The drainage easement shall not be less than 20 feet in width and should be 30 feet in width when site conditions allow. 
(16)  Structure protection and safety. Flows generated by the 100-year critical duration storm under planned land use conditions may exceed the design capacity of conveyance systems, but shall not come in contact with any buildings. For buildings designed for human occupation on a regular basis, the following additional requirements shall apply: 
a.  The lowest elevation of the structure that is exposed to the ground surface shall be a minimum of two feet above the maximum water elevation produced by the 100-year critical duration storm, including flows through any storm water BMP that is designed to store water at a depth of three feet or greater. 
b.  All structures shall be setback a distance, as follows, from the closest edge of the water elevation produced by the 100-year critical duration storm: 
1.  Residential structures 25 feet. 
2.  Commercial and industrial structures ten feet. 
(k)  Exceptions. The requirements for on-site stormwater management measures established in subsections (a) through (c) of this section are not applicable in areas which are determined by the plan commission to be covered by an approved stormwater management system plan which was developed and approved as an alternative stormwater management planning approach to carrying out on-site measures consistent with the purpose and intent of this article. In such cases, the recommendations of the approved stormwater management system plan shall be applied either through the installation of stormwater management provisions recommended to be included on the development site being considered and/or through the payment of a fee as set forth in section 16-324. These minimum requirements may also be waived in whole or in part by the plan commission, in cooperation with the director of public works, or designee, upon written request of the applicant, provided that at least one of the following conditions applies: 
(1)  Provisions are made to manage stormwater by an off-site facility. This requires meeting all the following conditions: the off-site facility is in place; is designed and adequately sized to provide a level of stormwater control equal to or greater than that which would be afforded by on-site practices meeting the requirements of this division; and the facility has a legally obligated entity responsible for its long-term operation and maintenance. 
(2)  Director of public works, or designee, finds that meeting the minimum on-site management requirements is infeasible due to space or site restrictions. 
(l)  Fee in lieu of on-site stormwater management practices. Where the plan commission, in cooperation with the director of public works, or designee, waives all or part of the minimum on-site stormwater management requirements, or where the waiver is based on the provision of adequate stormwater facilities provided by a responsible entity downstream, the applicant may be required to pay a fee set by the common council. In setting the fee for land development projects, the city shall consider an equitable distribution of the cost of land, engineering design, construction, and maintenance, as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.55. 
(m)  General considerations for on-site and off-site stormwater management measures. The following considerations shall be observed in managing stormwater runoff: 
(1)  Natural topography and land cover features such as natural swales, natural depressions, native soil infiltrating capacity, and natural groundwater recharge areas shall be preserved and used for stormwater infiltration and conveyance, to the extent practical and reasonably feasible, to meet the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Emergency overland flow for all stormwater facilities shall be provided to prevent exceeding the safe capacity of downstream property or public safety. 
(n)  Exemptions. 
(1)  Internally drained sites. The site is internally drained and will not discharge runoff from the site after development occurs. The site must be evaluated using post developed conditions assuming frozen conditions (CN = 98), no infiltration and the 100-year critical duration storm when determining safe structure elevations. 
(2)  Site conditions. It may be impracticable to meet the requirements due to site conditions such as slopes, soils, proximity to structures or desirable trees, limited site dimensions, surrounding land uses, the potential for groundwater contamination, public health or safety problems, or other factors beyond the control of the developer. No site shall be entitled to an exemption under this section due solely to the size of the proposed land development activity in relation to the parcel size. However, the city shall provide special consideration in granting exemptions under this section for the following type of sites: 
a.  Redevelopment sites; 
b.  In-fill development areas less than five acres; 
c.  Highway projects where limited public right-of-way land is available for the installation of storm water BMPs. 
(Code 1997, § 23.11)  
Sec. 16-320. - Permit requirements and procedures. 
(a)  Permit required. No landowner or land operator may undertake a land development activity subject to this article without receiving a permit from the city prior to commencing the proposed activity. The permit will be a combined permit for erosion control and stormwater management. 
(b)  Permit application and fee. Unless otherwise excepted by this article, any landowner or operator desiring a permit shall submit to the city a permit application made on a form provided by the city for that purpose. At least one landowner or land user controlling or using the site and desiring to undertake a land developing activity subject to this section shall submit an application for a permit, a stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement, erosion control plan and pay required fees to the city clerk. The applicant may file supplemental information with the city clerk to comply with directives resulting from the city's initial review. By submitting an application, the applicant is authorizing the city to enter the site to obtain information required for the review of the erosion control plan, stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement. 
(1)  Unless otherwise excepted by this article, a permit application must be accompanied by the following in order that the permit application be considered by the director of public works, or designee: a stormwater management plan with a maintenance agreement, erosion control plan, any payment of "fees in lieu" prior to permit issuance, a non-refundable permit administration fee and signed professional services reimbursement form. 
(2)  The erosion control plan shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16-299; the stormwater management plan shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16-321; the maintenance agreement shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16-322; and fees shall be those established by the plan commission as set forth in section 16-324. 
(c)  Review and approval of permit application. The stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement will be reviewed along the same timeline as that for review of the erosion control plan, as specified in section 16-299(3). 
(d)  Permit conditions. All permits issued under this article shall be subject to the following conditions, and holders of permits issued under this article shall be deemed to have accepted these conditions. The director of public works, or designee, may suspend or revoke a permit for violation of a permit condition, following written notification of the permittee. An action by the city to suspend or revoke this permit may be appealed in accordance with section 16-327. 
(1)  Compliance with this permit does not relieve the permit holder of the responsibility to comply with other applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations. The city may require applicant to obtain other permits or plan approvals prior to issuing a permit. 
(2)  The permit holder shall design, install, and maintain all structural and non-structural stormwater management measures in accordance with the approved erosion control plan, stormwater management plan, maintenance agreement, and the permit. A copy of all approved plans shall be maintained at the construction site all times during normal business hours until all temporary BMPs have been removed. 
(3)  The permit holder shall notify the director of public works, or designee, within 48 hours of commencing any work in conjunction with the stormwater management plan, and within three working days upon completion of the stormwater management practices. If required as a special condition, the permit holder shall make additional notification according to a schedule set forth by the plan commission in cooperation with the director of public works, or designee, so that practice installations can be inspected during construction. 
(4)  Completed structural stormwater management practices must pass a final inspection to determine if they are built in accordance with the approved stormwater management plan and ordinance. The director of public works, or designee, shall notify the permit holder in writing of any changes required in such practices to bring them into compliance with conditions of this permit. The practice installation required as part of this division shall be certified as built by a licensed professional engineer representing the permit holder. 
(5)  The permit holder shall notify the director of public works, or designee, of any significant modifications it intends to make to an approved stormwater management or erosion control plan. The director of public works, or designee, may require that the proposed modifications be submitted for approval prior to incorporation into the stormwater management or erosion control plan and execution. 
(6)  The permit holder shall maintain all stormwater management practices specified in the approved stormwater management plan until the practices either become the responsibility of the city, or are transferred to subsequent private owners as specified in the approved maintenance agreement. 
(7)  The permit holder shall allow access to the director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator for the purpose of inspecting the property for compliance with the approved stormwater management and erosion control plan and permit. 
(8)  If so directed by the city, the permit holder shall repair at the permit holder's own expense all damage to adjoining properties, municipal facilities and drainage ways caused by erosion, siltation, stormwater runoff, or equipment tracking from the holder's permit site, where such damage is caused by activities that are not in compliance with the approved stormwater management or erosion control plan. 
(9)  The permit holder authorizes the city, following written notification, to perform any work or operations necessary to bring stormwater management or erosion control measures into conformance with the approved stormwater management or erosion control plan, and consents to placing associated costs upon the tax roll as a special lien against the property or to charging such costs against the financial guarantee posted for the project. 
(10)  Where a stormwater management plan involves changes in direction, increases in peak rate, and/or total volume of runoff off a site, the planning commission in cooperation with the director of public works, or designee, may require the permittee to make appropriate legal arrangements with adjacent property owners concerning the prevention of endangerment to downstream property or public safety. 
(11)  The permit holder is subject to the enforceable actions detailed in section 16-327 if the permit holder fails to comply with the terms of this permit. 
(12)  Letter of credit or cash. As a condition of approval and issuance of the permit, the plan commission shall require the applicant to provide an appropriate irrevocable letter of credit or cash to guarantee good faith execution of the approved erosion control and stormwater management plan, maintenance agreement, and permit conditions. 
(e)  Permit duration. Permits shall be valid for a period based on the construction schedule outlined in the approved plans with an initial maximum duration of two years. An expiration date will be issued based on the provided information. Extension requests should be made two weeks prior to the expiration date. The director of public works, or designee, may require additional control measures as a condition of the extension, if they are necessary to meet the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1997, § 23.12)  
Sec. 16-321. - Stormwater management plans. 
(a)  Plan requirements. The stormwater management plan required under section 16-320(b) shall contain any information the director of public works, or designee, may need to evaluate the environmental characteristics of the area affected by the land development activity, the potential impacts of the proposed development upon the quality and quantity of stormwater discharges, the potential impacts upon water resources and drainage utilities, and the effectiveness and acceptability of proposed stormwater management measures in meeting the performance standards set forth in this article. Stormwater management plans shall contain at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, e-mail address and telephone number for the following or their designees: landowner; developer; project engineer for practice design and certification; person(s) responsible for installation of erosion control and stormwater management measures; person(s) responsible for maintenance of stormwater measures prior to the transfer, if any, of maintenance responsibility to another party. 
(2)  A proper legal description of the property proposed to be developed referenced to the U.S. Public Land Survey system or to block and lot numbers within a recorded land subdivision plat. 
(3)  Existing (pre-development) site conditions, including: 
a.  A site map, at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet. The site map shall show the following: site location; predominant soil types and hydrologic soil groups; existing cover type and condition with accompanying runoff curve numbers; topographic contours of the site not to exceed two-foot contour interval; topography and drainage network including enough of the contiguous properties to show runoff patterns onto, through, and from the site; watercourses that may affect or be affected by runoff from the site; flow path and direction for all stormwater conveyance sections, including time of travel and time of concentration applicable to each; watershed boundaries used in determinations of peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes from the site; lakes, streams, wetlands, channels, ditches, and other watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site; limits of the 100-year floodplain; location of municipal or community wells located within 400 feet and private wells located within 100 feet of stormwater detention ponds, infiltration basins, or infiltration trenches; delineation of wellhead protection areas delineated pursuant to Wis. Admin. Code § NR 811.16. 
b.  Computations of the peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes, from each discharge point in the development, including analysis of the capacity of downstream drainage conveyance systems. At a minimum, computations must be made for the following 24-hour storm events: one-year, two-year; ten-year; and 100-year. All major assumptions used in developing input shall be clearly stated. The areas used in making the calculations shall be clearly cross-referenced to the required map(s). 
c.  A storm sewer system map, showing the location, size, material type, and invert elevations of all existing and proposed storm sewers. 
(4)  Site development plan, including: 
a.  A narrative summary of the overall storm water management plan including an explanation of the BMPs proposed and why they were chosen, how the plan meets the requirements of this article, an explanation of the provisions to preserve and use natural topography and land cover features to minimize changes in peak flow runoff rates and volumes to surface waters and wetlands, and explanation of any restrictions on stormwater management measures in the development area imposed by wellhead protection plans and ordinances. 
b.  A site map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet showing: proposed land uses including vegetative cover type and accompanying runoff curve numbers; proposed topographic contours of the site not to exceed two feet; proposed drainage network including enough of the contiguous properties to show runoff patterns onto, through, and from the site; locations and dimensions of drainage and access easements; flow path and direction for all stormwater conveyance sections, including time of travel and time of concentration applicable to each; location and type of all stormwater management conveyance and treatment practices, including the on-site and off-site tributary drainage area; location and type of conveyance system that will carry runoff from the drainage and treatment practices to the nearest adequate outlet such as a curbed street, storm drain, or natural drainage way; watershed boundaries used in determinations of peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes; and amendments to lakes, streams, wetlands, channels, ditches, and other watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site. 
c.  Computations of the peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes, from each discharge point in the development, including analysis of the capacity of downstream drainage conveyance systems. At a minimum, computations must be made for the following 24-hour storms: one-year, two-year; ten-year; and 100-year. All major assumptions used in developing input parameters shall be clearly stated. The areas used in making the calculations shall be clearly cross-referenced to the required map(s). 
d.  Investigations of soils and groundwater required for the placement and design of stormwater management measures. Adequate soil boring information must be provided based on WDNR Technical Standards 1002. 
e.  Design computations including type, size and location for all pipes, open channels and other proposed storm water conveyance systems and all applicable assumptions. Cross-sections of proposed conveyances may be required if determined critical. 
f.  Detailed cross-sections and profiles of each BMP showing all critical design features, side slopes, structures, soil profiles and applicable elevations, including seasonal highwater table. 
g.  Detailed drawings with specifications for inlets and/or outlets. 
h.  Detailed construction notes explaining all necessary procedures to be followed to properly implement the plan, including seeding and restoration specifications, timing and sequencing of construction and any temporary measures needed to protect BMPs during the construction phase. 
(b)  Exceptions. Director of public works, or designee, may prescribe alternative submittal requirements for applicants seeking an exemption to on-site stormwater management performance standards under section 16-319(c). 
(c)  Waivers. Director of public works, or designee, may waive some of the requirements of subsection (a) of this section to accommodate smaller scale projects. 
(Code 1997, § 23.13)  
Sec. 16-322. - Maintenance agreement. 
(a)  Maintenance agreement required. The maintenance agreement required for stormwater management measures under section 16-320 shall be an agreement between the city and the permittee to provide for maintenance of stormwater management practices beyond the duration period of this permit. The agreement or recordable document shall be filed with the city clerk and recorded with the Waukesha County register of deeds so that it is binding upon all subsequent owners of land served by the stormwater management measure(s). 
(b)  Agreement provisions. The maintenance agreement shall contain the following provisions: 
(1)  Identification of the stormwater management measure(s), their design components, and description of all long term maintenance activities that will likely be required for each for each measure included in the agreement, and an estimated time interval between each activity. 
(2)  Identification of the landowner(s), organization or municipality responsible for maintenance of the stormwater management measure(s). For subdivisions, all storm water management measures that collect runoff from more than one lot shall be located on outlots, unless otherwise requested by the permittee and approved by the city. For all privately owned outlots, ownership shall be by proportional undividable interest of all properties that are within the control of the permittee and drain to the BMP. However, the permittee may combine ownership of more than one storm water management measure within the site. 
(3)  The landowner(s), organization, or city shall maintain stormwater management practices in accordance with the stormwater practice maintenance provisions contained in the approved stormwater management plan submitted under section 16-321. 
(4)  The director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator is authorized to access the property to conduct inspections of stormwater practices as necessary to ascertain that the practices are being maintained and operated in accordance with the approved stormwater management plan. 
(5)  The city representative conducting the inspection shall maintain public records of the results of the site inspections, shall inform the designated entity responsible for maintenance of the inspection results, and shall specifically indicate any corrective actions required to bring the stormwater management practice into proper working condition. 
(6)  Upon notifying the designated entity of maintenance problems which require correction, the specified corrective actions shall be taken within 24 hours, or as specified by the city. 
(7)  The city is authorized to perform the corrected actions identified in the inspection report if the landowner does not make the required corrections in the specified time period. The costs and expenses shall be entered on the tax roll as a special assessment against the property and collected with any other taxes levied thereon for the year in which the work is completed. 
(Code 1997, § 23.14)  
Sec. 16-323. - Financial guarantee. 
(a)  Establishment of the guarantee. 
(1)  The director of public works, or designee, may require the applicant to furnish the city with a financial guarantee, the form and type of which shall be acceptable to the city prior to release of a permit. The financial guarantee shall be in an amount determined by the director of public works, or designee, to be the estimated cost of constructing and installing the erosion control and stormwater management practices and the estimated cost of maintenance during the period which the designated party in the maintenance agreement has maintenance responsibility. A financial guarantee shall not be required of departments, boards, commissions, public offices, and corporations having the authority of eminent domain under Wis. Stats ch. 32. 
(2)  The financial guarantee shall be sufficient to cover all phases of the plan from clearing and stockpiling operations to final grading, landscaping, and maintenance, and shall give the city the authority to use the funds to complete the project if the applicant defaults or does not properly implement the approved plan. 
(b)  Conditions for release. Conditions for release of the financial guarantee are as follows: 
(1)  The director of public works, or designee, shall release the portion of the financial guarantee pertaining to installation of erosion and sediment control and stormwater management practices, minus any costs incurred by the city to complete installation, once the site has been stabilized with vegetative cover (including vegetative cover required as a result of utility distribution system installation) and the best management practice installation, required as a part of this article, has been certified as built by a licensed professional engineer. 
(2)  The director of public works, or designee, shall release the portion of the financial security established to assure maintenance of stormwater practices, minus any costs incurred by the city, at such time that the responsibility for practice maintenance is passed on to another entity via an approved maintenance agreement. 
(Code 1997, § 23.15)  
Sec. 16-324. - Fee schedule. 
The fees referred to in other sections of this article shall be established by the city council and may be modified from time to time by resolution. A schedule of fees established by the city shall be available for review at the office of the city clerk. The landowner, land user, permit holder, or other responsible party is also responsible for payment of costs related to review of proposed erosion control and stormwater management plans and for project inspection and related administrative costs related to city inspections conducted to ensure compliance with approved erosion control and stormwater management plans, per the inspection schedule specified in section 16-325. 
(Code 1997, § 23.16)  
Sec. 16-325. - Inspection. 
(a)  The director of public works, or designee, shall inspect construction sites at least once a month to ensure compliance with the erosion control plan and the stormwater management plan. The frequency of inspections may increase based on the proximity of the project to outstanding resources or if site conditions warrant it. After the project has been completed and accepted by the city, the director of public works, or designee, may inspect the site as needed to ensure stormwater management practices are being maintained in accordance with the approved stormwater management maintenance agreement. The director of public works, or designee, will notify the permittee in writing of any deficiencies which require correction. The permittee shall correct said deficiencies within ten days or notify the director of public works, or designee, of a reasonable time frame in which the repairs will be accomplished. 
(b)  The city authorizes the director of public works, or designee, or other city staff access to property to inspect all existing basins within the city, within a drainage easement, a minimum of once per year, regardless of when the basins were constructed, to determine whether repairs are necessary. The director of public works, or designee, will create a record of the inspection and, if necessary, notify the responsible party that repairs are required to be made within a ten-day period, depending on weather conditions. If the repairs are not made within this period or an acceptable schedule for repairs is not submitted, the city shall have the authority to make said repairs and bill the property owner immediately following the repairs, or make an assessment against the property on the tax rolls. 
(c)  If land disturbing or land development activities are being carried on without a permit, the director of public works, or designee, shall enter the land pursuant to the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.122 and 66.123. 
(Code 1997, § 23.17)  
Sec. 16-326. - Illicit discharges. 
(a)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  Discharges. Except for stormwater and other discharges specifically exempted under subsection (b) of this section, no discharge, spilling or dumping of substances or materials shall be allowed into receiving water bodies or onto driveways, sidewalks, parking lots or other areas that drain into the storm drainage system. 
(2)  Connections. The construction, use, maintenance or continued existence of illicit connections to the storm drainage system is prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit connections made prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, regardless of whether the connection was permissible under law or practice applicable or prevailing at the time of connection. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following activities are exempt from the provisions of this section unless found to have an adverse impact on the stormwater: 
(1)  Discharges authorized by a permit issued by the Wisconsin department of natural resources. 
(2)  Discharges resulting from firefighting activities. 
(3)  Discharges from uncontaminated ground water, potable water source, roof drains, foundation drain and sump pump, air conditioning condensation, springs, lawn watering, individual residential car washing, water main and hydrant flushing and swimming pools if the water has been dechlorinated. 
(c)  Notice of violation. Whenever the City of Delafield finds a violation of this section, the City of Delafield may order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible party. Such notice may require without limitation: 
(1)  The elimination of illicit connections or discharges; 
(2)  That violating discharges, practices, or operations shall cease and desist; 
(3)  The abatement or remediation of stormwater pollution or contaminated hazards and the restoration of any affected property; 
(4)  Any responsible party that fails to comply with a notice of violation under this section shall be subject to further enforcement under the provisions of section 16-327 below. 
(Code 1997, § 23.18)  
Sec. 16-327. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Issuance of a stop work order. The director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may post a stop work order if: 
(1)  Any land disturbing or land development activity regulated under this article is being undertaken without a permit; or 
(2)  The approved erosion control plan, stormwater management plan, or maintenance agreement are not being implemented in a good faith manner; or 
(3)  The conditions of the permit are not being met. 
(b)  Noncompliance. If the permittee does not cease the activity or comply with the erosion control plan, stormwater management plan, maintenance agreement, or permit conditions within ten days, the director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may revoke the permit. 
(c)  Cease and desist order. If the landowner or land user where no permit has been issued does not cease the activity within ten days, the director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may request the city to issue a cease and desist order. 
(d)  Retraction of stop work order or revocation. The director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may retract the stop work order or the revocation. 
(e)  Nonemergency and emergency violations. 
(1)  Nonemergency violations. Ten days after posting a stop work order, the director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may issue a notice of intent to the permittee, landowner, or land user of the city's intent to perform work necessary to comply with this section. The director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator may enter the land and commence work after 14 days from issuing the notice of intent. The costs of the work performed or caused to be performed by the city and, in addition, all administrative costs of the city, including office staff and legal, plus interest at the rate authorized by the city council, shall be billed to the permittee, landowner, or land user. In the event a permittee, landowner, or land user fails to pay the amount due, the clerk shall enter the amount due on the tax rolls and collect as a special charge against the property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.60(16) or deduct the amount from the financial guarantee. 
(2)  Emergency violations. Improper or inadequate installation of erosion control or stormwater management facilities or lack of maintenance of these facilities may cause irreparable environmental damage. Accordingly, a summary procedure is necessary to install, repair, or replace erosion control or stormwater facilities should it be necessary to prevent irreparable harm to the environment. In situations where in the opinion of the director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator irreparable harm may result if corrective measures are not immediately taken, the city may order immediate installation, repair, or replacement of erosion control or stormwater management facilities. An emergency is defined as a situation existing which, if not rectified immediately, would cause damage to neighboring properties, public properties, or the environment. The director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator shall allow no more than 24 hours for compliance with the order for installation, repair, or replacement or erosion control or stormwater management facilities. In the absence of compliance, the city may go on the land and commence the work or cause the work to be completed by third parties. The costs of the work performed, plus interest at the rate authorized by the city council, and in addition all indirect expenses set forth in subsection (e)(1) of this section, shall be billed to the permittee, landowner, or land user. In the event a permittee, landowner, or land user fails to pay the amount due, the clerk shall enter the amount due on the tax rolls and collect the costs as a special charge against the property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.60(16). 
(f)  Penalty. The city is authorized to refer any violation of this article, or of a stop work order or cease and desist order issued pursuant to this article, to the city attorney for the commencement of further legal proceedings in any court with jurisdiction. Every violation of this article is a public nuisance and is subject to the penalties described in section 1-4. 
(g)  Injunction, etc. Compliance with the provisions of this section may also be enforced by injunction, abatement of nuisances, or other appropriate and available remedy. 
(Code 1997, § 23.19)  
Sec. 16-328. - Appeals. 
(a)  Board of appeals. The board of appeals created pursuant to section 52-291 pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(e): 
(1)  Shall hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is error in any order, decision, or determination made by the plan commission, director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator in administering this section. 
(2)  Upon appeal, may authorize variances from the provisions of this section which are not contrary to the public interest and where owing to special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of this section will result in unnecessary hardship. 
(3)  Shall use the rules, procedures, duties, and powers authorized by statute in hearing and deciding appeals and authorizing variances. 
(b)  Who may appeal. Appeals to the board of appeals may be taken by any aggrieved person or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city affected by any decision of the plan commission, director of public works, or designee, building inspector, or administrator. 
(Code 1997, § 23.20)  
Sec. 16-329. - Validity. 
The several sections, subsections, and paragraphs of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any section, subsection, or paragraph of this article shall be declared by a decision of a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the other provisions of the article, or of the section of which the invalid portion or paragraph may be a part. 
(Code 1997, § 23.21)  
Sec. 16-330. - Effective date. 
This article shall be effective upon passage, approval, and publication, and shall apply to all projects of land disturbing and land development activities commenced after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, except that this article shall not apply to construction activities for which a building permit or other construction authorization has been issued as of the said effective date. 
(Code 1997, § 23.22)  
Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Recognition, bylaws, funds and compensation. 
(a)  Adoption of inter-municipal agreement. Pursuant to article XIII of the inter-municipal agreement between the Villages of Nashotah and Chenequa and the City of Delafield dated June 17, 2009, that created the lake country fire and rescue, the terms of said inter-municipal agreement are incorporated herein and made part of this chapter along with any amendments duly made to such inter-municipal agreement adopted subsequent to its adoption, for purposes of creating the lake country fire and rescue, lake country fire board, and lake country fire commission referred to therein. A copy of the inter-municipal agreement as amended from time-to-time shall be attached hereto as an addendum. 
(b)  Recognition. The lake country fire and rescue is hereby officially recognized as the fire and rescue department of the city, and the duty of providing fire, ambulance and rescue services in the city is delegated to that department. 
(Code 1997, § 5.01; Rep. & Recr. #655)  
Sec. 18-2. - State codes adopted; automatic sprinkler protection. 
(a)  State codes adopted. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, the statutory provisions of Wis. Stats. § 101.14, Fire Inspections, Prevention, Detection and Suppression, and the following chapters of the Wisconsin Administrative Codes and National Fire Protection Association Codes are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute or code provision incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this Code. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes and codes incorporated herein are considered to be made a part of this Code in order to secure uniform statewide regulation: 
SPS 	307 	Explosives 
SPS 	310 	Flammable and Combustive Liquids 
SPS 	311 	Liquefied Petroleum Gases 
SPS 	312 	Liquefied Natural Gas 
SPS 	313 	Compressed Natural Gas 
SPS 	314 	Fire Prevention 
SPS 	316 	Electrical Code 
SPS 	328 	Smoke Detectors 
SPS 	350 	Administration and Enforcement 
SPS 	351 	Definitions and Standards 
SPS 	352 	General Requirements 
SPS 	353 	Structural Requirements 
SPS 	354 	Factories, Office and Mercantile Buildings 
SPS 	355 	Theaters and Assembly Halls 
SPS 	356 	Schools and Other Places of Instruction 
SPS 	357 	Residential Occupancies 
SPS 	358 	Health Care, Detention and Correctional Facilities 
SPS 	359 	Hazardous Occupancies 
SPS 	360 	Child Care Facilities 
SPS 	361 	Community-Based Residential Facilities and Sheltered Facilities for Battered Women 
SPS 	362 	Specialty Occupancies 
SPS 	364 	Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning 
SPS 	366 	Uniform Multi-Family Dwellings 
SPS 	370 	Historic Building Code 
SPS 	375-379 	Existing Buildings 
NFPA 	13 	Installation of Sprinkler Systems 
NFPA 	13R 	Installation of Sprinkler Systems in Residential Occupancies (multi-family) 
NFPA 	14 	Installation of Standpipe and Hose Systems 
NFPA 	24 	Installation of Private Fire Service Mains 
NFPA 	25 	Inspection, Testing and Maintenance of Water-Based Fire Protection Systems 
NFPA 	72 	National Fire Alarm Code 
NFPA 	291 	Fire Flow Testing and Marking of Hydrants 
NFPA 	704 	Identification of the Fire Hazards of Materials for Emergency Response 
NFPA 	231D 	Storage of Rubber Tires 
NFPA 	1231 	Water Supplies for Suburban and Rural Fire Fighting 
 
(b)  Automatic sprinkler protection. 
(1)  Purpose. To provide the means for the automatic extinguishment of fire in buildings or parts of buildings which because of their size, construction or occupancy or lack of suitable protective equipment, constitute a special fire hazard to life or property or an excessive burden upon the fire extinguishing capabilities of the fire department. 
(2)  Design and installation. The design and installation of said automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed per National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 13, 13D, and 13R, and maintained per NFPA 25 codes. All single-family and two-family dwellings under the Uniform Dwelling Code (UDC) are exempt. 
(3)  Where required. Automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed and maintained in operable condition in the following new occupancies and locations: 
a.  Buildings used as chapter 54Factories, offices, and mercantile occupancies. This classification includes all factories, workshops, office buildings, mercantile establishments, warehouses, exhibition buildings, and places where not more than 100 persons assemble for recreation, entertainment, worship, or dining purposes. 
1.  Building is of Class 1 or Class 2 fire-resistive construction, where the area exceeds 15,000 square feet per floor or 25,000 square feet total area of all floors. 
2.  Building is of Class 36 non-fire-resistive construction, where the area exceeds 12,000 square feet per floor or 21,000 square feet total area of all floors. 
3.  Building is of Class 7 or Class 8 non-fire-resistive construction, where the area exceeds 10,000 square feet per floor or 10,000 square feet total area of all floors. 
4.  Building has three floor levels or more in height above grade regardless of area. 
b.  Buildings used as chapter 55Theaters and assembly halls occupancies. This classification includes theaters and assembly halls. 
1.  Building is one level and 6,000 square feet or more, regardless of building construction class. 
2.  Building has two floor levels or more in height above grade regardless of area. 
c.  Buildings used as chapter 56Schools and places of instruction occupancies. This classification includes all public and private schools, universities, colleges, academies, seminaries, libraries, and museums and art galleries. 
1.  Building is of Class 1 or Class 2 fire-resistive construction, where the area exceeds 10,000 square feet per floor or 20,000 square feet total area of all floors. 
2.  Buildings of Class 38 non-fire-resistive construction, automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed throughout the building, regardless of size. 
3.  Building has three floor levels or more in height above grade regardless of area. 
d.  Buildings used as chapter 57Residential occupancies. This classification includes motels, hotels, dormitories, homes for the aged, sheltered facilities for battered women serving more than 20 occupants, rooming houses, convents and monasteries, and community-based facilities located in existing buildings serving more than 20 unrelated adults. 
1.  Automatic sprinklers shall be installed throughout such buildings regardless of size or type of construction. 
2.  Building that has residential units mixed with other types of occupancies, such as mercantile space on the first floor and residential space on the second floor, shall be sprinkled throughout the entire building. 
e.  Buildings used as chapter 58Health care, detention and correctional facilities occupancies. This classification includes health care facilities, nursing homes, and detention and correctional facilities. 
Automatic sprinklers shall be installed throughout such buildings regardless of size or type of construction. 
f.  Buildings used as chapter 59Hazardous occupancies. This classification includes storage garages, body shops, and repair garages. 
1.  Buildings of Class 1 or Class 2 fire-resistive construction, and is 10,000 square feet or more in total area. 
2.  Buildings of Class 38 non-fire-resistive construction, and is 6,000 square feet or more in total area. 
3.  Building has two floor levels or more in height above grade regardless of area. 
4.  In any basement or sub-basement if a vehicle can be parked therein. 
g.  Buildings used as chapter 61Community-based residential facilities and sheltered facilities for battered women occupancies. This classification includes all buildings used as CBRF, providing care, treatment and services to nine through 20 unrelated adults, to be located in existing buildings. 
Automatic sprinklers shall be installed throughout such buildings regardless of size or type of construction. 
h.  Buildings used as chapter 66Uniform multi-family dwellings occupancies. This classification includes all multi-family dwellings and any addition to an existing multi-family dwelling constructed after April 1, 1995, and to any building or portion of a building which is converted to a multi-family dwelling after April 1, 1995. 
Buildings shall be sprinklered in accordance with Table 66.33-B. 
(4)  New additions, remodeling, change of use. 
a.  If more than 50 percent of the gross interior area of a building is remodeled and/or added to, sprinkler protection shall be provided throughout the entire building. However, if the addition or remodeled area is separated from the existing building by a fire division wall as specified by the Wisconsin Administrative Code, the existing may be exempt from the requirements of this article. 
b.  Any building, with or without an existing sprinkler system, that has a change of use, and the hazard and/or life safety becomes more severe, the entire building shall conform to section 18-2. 
c.  Substitute fire suppression systems may be used in lieu of a sprinkler system when the jurisdictional authority determines the use of water could damage equipment or materials, or such system is impossible or impracticable to install. Said equivalent shall depend on the type of occupancies, and the type of structure. Smoke detectors and/or other fire protection devices may be required. 
(5)  Approval of plans and systems. 
a.  Prior to the installation of a sprinkler system, plans must be submitted to the fire department for review. All sprinkler systems and plans must meet the standards of the National Fire Protection Association, Wisconsin Commercial Building Code, and codes of the City of Delafield. 
b.  Two or more copies of sprinkler plans have been submitted to, and approved by the fire department. 
c.  All submitted plans must be drawn to a scale no less than one-eighth inch equal to one foot. Site plans shall show the location of water laterals, hydrants, and fire department connection. All plans must be stamped and signed in accordance with Wisconsin department of commerce division of industry, labor and human relations. 
d.  Approved plans must be stamped approved by the fire department along with the date of approval. One copy shall be kept on file with the fire department. 
e.  The fire department's approval of sprinkler plans does not affirm the accuracy of any calculations or system design performed by the contractor. Full responsibility for the accuracy of any calculations or the system's design is the contractor's. 
f.  The fire department must witness the final acceptance test of the sprinkler system. The building or area of the building may not be occupied before the test is completed. The fire department must be notified two working days in advance of an acceptance test. 
(6)  Maintenance. 
a.  Sprinkler systems and standpipe systems shall be maintained in operative condition at all times, regardless if required. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant to reduce the effectiveness of the protection so required; except this shall not prohibit the owner or occupant from temporarily reducing or discontinuing the protection where necessary to make tests, repairs, alterations, or additions. 
c.  The fire department shall be notified when the system has been shut down for any reason, and again when the system has been restored to service. 
d.  Records of inspections, tests, and maintenance as specified in NFPA 25 shall be kept and shall be made available, upon request, to the department. 
(7)  Inspections. Every sprinkler system required by the Municipal Code, or by the Administrative Rules of the State of Wisconsin, shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 25. The results of the testing shall be forwarded to the fire department on an annual basis. 
(8)  Fees. The fee schedule for automatic sprinkler protection fees are established, from time and time, by resolution adopted by the lake country fire and rescue department fire board. 
(c)  Alarm systems. All sprinkler, suppression, and detection systems shall be connected to an approved alarm system and installed and maintained to NFPA 72 standard. 
(1)  Approval of plans and systems. 
a.  Prior to the installation of a fire alarm system, plans must be submitted to the fire department for review. All fire alarm systems and plans must meet the standards of the National Fire Protection Association, Wisconsin Commercial Building Code, and codes of the City of Delafield. 
b.  Two or more copies of fire alarm plans have been submitted to, and approved by the fire department. 
(2)  Installation. 
a.  The alarm system shall be monitored by an Underwriters Laboratory (U.L.), or equal, listed monitoring station. 
Exception: A monitoring station is not required if the building has occupants in the premises on a 24-hour basis. 
b.  The alarm/indicator panel shall be located in the main entry foyer or airlock of the building or in a location approved by the department. All functions for reset and area identification shall be performed at this panel. 
c.  The alarm system shall be audible to the interior of the building in all areas of the building. 
(3)  Maintenance and inspections. 
a.  The alarm system shall be maintained in operative condition at all times. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant to reduce the effectiveness of the protection so required; except this shall not prohibit the owner or occupant from temporarily reducing or discontinuing the protection where necessary to make tests, repairs, alterations, or additions. 
c.  The fire department shall be notified when the system has been shut down for any reason, and again when the system has been restored to service. 
d.  Records of inspections, tests, and maintenance as specified in NFPA 72 shall be kept and shall be available, upon request, to the department. 
(4)  Fee. Plan review: $75.00. 
(d)  Fire department standpipes/risers. 
(1)  The design, installation, and maintenance of standpipe systems shall be in accordance with this section and NFPA 14, Standard for the Installation of Standpipe and Hose Systems. 
(2)  The installation of a fire suppression system will not supersede the requirements for installation of fire department standpipes. 
(3)  Standpipes shall be installed in all buildings with three floor levels or more above grade or as required by the fire department. 
(4)  Standpipe connections shall have a 2½-inch to 1½-inch reducer cap. 
(e)  Security key and vault system. 
(1)  Purpose. When access to or within a structure or an area is unduly difficult because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for lifesaving or firefighting purposes. 
(2)  Key box required. The Knox Box vault system has been adopted for use by this fire department. A Knox Box shall be installed in all existing buildings which have an automatic alarm system which is monitored or an automated sprinkler system. The key box shall be a type approved by the fire department and shall contain those keys found to be necessary to provide emergency access. 
Exception: This section does not apply to one- and two-family dwellings. 
(3)  Location. The Knox Box shall be installed at such location as designated by the fire chief or deputy fire inspector. 
(4)  Property owner responsible. The property owner is responsible to assure that keys maintained within a key box are those of the current type. When a change of locks within the building is necessary, the fire department shall be notified with new keys placed in the key box. 
(5)  Installation. The Knox Box shall be installed at owner's or occupant's expense. 
(f)  Fire hydrants/water systemsPrivate. 
(1)  General. The requirements of this section apply to private water systems that supply fire suppression systems. All fire hydrants in the City of Delafield and water mains serving said hydrants are considered public unless specifically exempted by the fire department and city council. Section 44-225 of the City of Delafield Subdivision Control Code shall apply, where applicable. (Am. #515) 
(2)  Installation and maintenance standards. Private fire hydrants and water mains shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 24 and the City of Delafield water utility regulation. All fire hydrants and water mains shall be maintained in accordance with NFPA 25. 
(3)  Approval required. Plans shall be submitted to the fire chief for review to determine compliance with the applicable standards prior to the installation of fire hydrants. 
(4)  Hydrant locations. All portions of exterior walls of newly constructed commercial, industrial and multifamily residential buildings and open storage of combustible materials shall be within 500 feet of at least two fire hydrants. Hydrant spacing shall not exceed 500 feet between any two hydrants. One- and two-family dwellings shall be within 500 feet of at least one fire hydrant. On new streets, hydrants shall be located at the intersections and the end of dead-end streets. Distances shall be measured along the path of the hose lay. Private fire hydrants shall not be located in the public right-of-way. Hydrant requirements in accordance with this standard may be met with existing public or private hydrants. The fire chief may approve alternative locations and spacing of hydrants provided hydrants meet fire suppression tactical needs. 
(5)  Setback distances. Fire hydrants shall not be located within 40 feet of any building. Fire hydrants shall be no more than ten feet and no less than five feet from the curb or edge of the street or fire apparatus access. Fire hydrants located in parking lot islands shall be a minimum of 3.5 feet from the center of the hydrants to the curb. Alternative setback distances may be considered when site conditions conflict with the provisions of this section. 
(6)  Minimum flow and system design. 
a.  Size of mains. Private water mains serving fire hydrants shall be the same size as the public main supplying the private water system, unless hydraulically calculated to provide the minimum required flow and pressure in accordance with nationally recognized standards. In all cases, mains do not need to exceed 12 inches but shall be at least eight inches in diameter. Alternative designs, based on nationally recognized standards for calculating fire flow demands, may be approved. If the minimum flow and pressure requirements cannot be supplied by a private water supply system, the owner may be required to install a public water supply system and/or multiple points of connection to public water main(s). 
b.  Valves. Control valves shall be provided to limit the number of private hydrants affected by maintenance, repair or construction. Valves shall be located at street intersections and at no more than 1,000-foot intervals. Valves shall be provided in each hydrant lead. 
c.  Outlet position. All hydrants shall be positioned so that the largest outlet faces the street or fire apparatus access route. 
d.  Hydrant height above grade. The center of the lowest outlet cap of fire hydrants shall be at least 18 inches above grade and not more than 24 inches above grade. 
e.  Hydrant colors. All fire hydrants shall have a red barrel and bonnet with white caps or as specified by city fire department. The paint shall be a reflective-type paint. (Am. #515) 
f.  Hydrant markers. Whenever the location of a fire hydrant may be obscured by its placement, or due to the placement of a building, structure, fencing, grade or land, vegetation, snow accumulation or other obstruction of vision, the fire chief may require such fire hydrants to be marked with "above grade markers." Above grade markers are any device approved for use by the fire chief, designed to promote and enhance the ready identification of fire hydrant locations. 
g.  Obstructions. No obstructions, including but not limited to power poles, trees, bushes, fences or posts may be located within five feet of a fire hydrant. Grade changes exceeding 1.5 feet are not permitted within five feet of a fire hydrant or hydrant lead. Owners shall remove snow, vegetation or other material that has covered or obscured the view of the hydrant(s) on their property. 
h.  Installation prior to construction. Fire hydrants shall be installed and in service prior to combustible construction. 
i.  Maintenance. Inspection, tests and maintenance shall be recorded and a copy shall be forwarded to the fire chief. Fire hydrants located on private property shall be routinely inspected, repaired and maintained by the owner thereof and all fire hydrants shall satisfy the minimum performance requirements established by the city water department for city fire hydrants. Water department personnel shall have free access to any property within the city at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting, repairing and maintaining fire hydrants. Any and all costs for repair and maintenance shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
j.  Out of service hydrants. Any fire hydrant that is out of service for any reason whether for repair, maintenance, or during construction shall be covered with a durable and weather-resistant bag to indicate the fire hydrant is not useable. The fire department shall be immediately notified when fire hydrants and/or systems are out of service. Fire hydrants and/or water systems shall be repaired and returned to service within 48 hours. 
(g)  Pump access sites. 
(1)  General. "Pump access sites" are areas throughout the city as determined by the fire chief that provide access to public waterways. These areas have been designated as no parking zones. 
(2)  Parking prohibited. No person shall park any motor vehicle, trailer, wagon, or conveyance upon, or in the roadside, curb, or shoulder area immediately in front of the tract of land designated as a pump access site. 
(3)  Penalty. Any person who violates, disobeys, neglects, omits or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-4. 
(h)  Underground water tanks. 
(1)  General requirements. 
a.  To ensure adequate water is available for the purposes of fire suppression, any developer or owner who subdivides lands into five or more residential or commercial lots shall provide an underground water tank within the platted area for fire protection purposes. The full and total cost of all engineering and legal fees, tank, installation, plumbing, fire fittings, painting, access lanes/roads, initial filling of water, land restoration, and other cost of compliance with this chapter shall be the responsibility of the developer or owner. 
b.  The underground water tank shall be in place, approved and functional before occupancy is approved for any new building within the platted areas. 
c.  A fire protection underground water tank surety in a form and in an amount determined by the city council, shall be required to ensure the system is installed and fully functional prior to any building construction. The required surety amount shall not be less than $5,000.00 in any case. Application for release of the surety shall not be considered until final approval of the system is obtained from the fire and department of public works (DPW) and all materials defined are provided. 
d.  The requirements for fire protection underground water tanks shall apply equally to new and existing developments if, after the date of enactment, in excess of four lots are created. 
e.  All specifications and installations shall follow established engineering practices, the fire department's tank installation guidelines and NFPA 1231, Standard on Water Supplies for Suburban and Rural Fire Fighting as they may be amended from time to time. All proposed installation plans and specifications shall be approved by the department before work is begun. 
f.  Within 30 days of final approval of the system, a complete set of record drawings, specifications, warranties and other requested information shall be provided to the department and DPW. 
g.  The complete installation and all associated items shall have a 24-month warranty, beginning at the final acceptance date, to be free from defects in materials and/or workmanship. If corrective actions are necessary, the developer shall make the corrections at his expense in a period determined by the city but not to exceed 60 days from notification of defect. 
(2)  When required. 
a.  The developer of new or expanded plats shall provide underground water tanks as hereby defined: 
1.  5 to 25 lots/units: minimum of one 25,000-gallon storage tank. 
2.  26 or more lots/units: 1,000-gallon storage capacity minimum for each lot. 
b.  The city, upon recommendation of the fire chief, may require greater or less capacity if it is determined, after reviewing the proximity of other water sources, that such capacity is appropriate. 
c.  All fire fittings used for installation shall be as specified by the department and the cost of these fittings shall be included as part of the overall installation. 
(3)  Location. Tank location shall be determined by the city after reviewing a recommendation from the fire chief, DPW superintendent and city engineer. 
(4)  Inspection and acceptance. 
a.  When all work has been completed and the tanks are functional, the developer may request an inspection. This inspection will be made by the fire chief using the fire department water tank inspection report form. In addition, a test pumping may be performed to insure that adequate water flow can be obtained. 
b.  When all requirements contained herein have been satisfied, the city shall provide final acceptance of the water source. 
(5)  In lieu of underground water tank. In lieu of an underground water tank(s), the owner or developer may contribute funds to the city that would be used to help offset the purchase of future firefighting apparatus. 
(i)  Prohibited discharges. 
(1)  Prohibited discharges. No person, firm or corporation shall discharge or cause to discharge, leak, leach or spill upon any public street, alley, or public property, or onto the ground, surface waters, subsurface waters, or aquifers, or on any private property, within the city, any explosive, flammable or combustible solid, liquid or gas, any radioactive material at or above nuclear regulator restriction levels, etiologic agents or any solid, liquid or gas creating a hazard, potential hazard, or public nuisance or any solid, liquid or gas having a deleterious effect on the environment. 
(2)  Containment, cleanup and restoration. Any person, firm or corporation in violation of subsection (i)(1) of this section must, upon direction of the fire chief of the fire department or his designee, begin immediate actions to contain, cleanup and remove to any approved repository the offending material(s) and restore the site to its original condition, with the offending person, firm or corporation being responsible for all expenses incurred. Should any person, firm or corporation fail to engage or complete the requirements of this section, the fire chief of the fire department or his designee may order the required actions to be taken by public or private resources and allow the recovery of any and all costs incurred by the city under subsection (i)(5) of this section. 
(3)  Emergency services response. Includes, but is not limited to, fire service, emergency medical service, law enforcement. A person, firm, or corporation who possesses or controls a hazardous substance which is discharged or who causes the discharge of a hazardous substance shall be responsible for reimbursement to the responding agencies for actual and necessary expenses incurred in carrying out their duties under this chapter. Actual and necessary expenses may include but not be limited to: replacement of equipment damaged by the hazardous material, cleaning, decontamination and maintenance of the equipment specific to the incident, costs incurred in the procurement and use of specialized equipment specific to the incident, specific laboratory expenses incurred in the recognition and identification of hazardous substances in the evaluation of response, decontamination, clean up and medical surveillance, and incurred costs of future medical surveillance of response personnel as required by the responding agencies medical advisor. 
(4)  Site access. Access to any site, public or private, where a prohibited discharge is indicated or suspected will be provided to the chiefs of the fire department or his designee for the purpose of evaluating the threat to the public and monitor containment, cleanup and restoration activities. 
(5)  Public protection. Should any prohibited discharge occur that threatens the life, safety or health of the public at, near, or around the site of a prohibited discharge, and that the situation is so critical that immediate steps must be taken to protect life and limb, the fire chief, or incident commander, on the scene of the emergency may order an evacuation of the area or take other appropriate steps for a period of time until the city council can take appropriate action. Incident commander shall be determined under the provisions of the incident command system set forth in Title 49, Federal Registry. 
(6)  Civil liability. Any person, firm or corporation in violation of this section shall be liable to the city for any expenses incurred by the city or loss or damage sustained by the city by reason of such violation. 
(j)  Building address numbers. 
(1)  New buildings. Whenever any new house or building is erected in the city, the owner or his agent shall procure the correct number of numbers as designated for the property and the owner or agent shall immediately install the number or numbers so assigned upon the house or building. 
(2)  Location of number. 
a.  All numbers shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the front of each house, building or occupancy so as to be easily seen and read from the public way. 
b.  If the house, building or occupancy is serviced by an alley or rear drive thorough fare, an additional set of numbers shall be posted to the rear of each house or building so as to be easily seen from the public way. 
(3)  Number style. All numbers shall be in numerical form. 
(Code 1997, § 5.06; Rep. #494; Am. #515; Am. #562; Rep. & Recr. # 684 ; Rep. & Recr. #697 )  
Sec. 18-3. - Fire inspection and occupancy fees. 
Fees. The fee schedule for fire inspection and occupancy fees are established, from time and time, by resolution adopted by the lake country fire and rescue department fire board. 
(Code 1997, § 5.07; Cr. # 684 )  
Sec. 18-4. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, any provision of the articles of association or the district bylaws adopted herein, or any provision of the state fire prevention manual herein adopted by reference, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1997, § 5.30; Rn. MCC '95)  
Chapter 20 - HEALTH AND PUBLIC WELFARE 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Health administration. 
The city and/or county health department shall enforce any provisions of this Municipal Code affecting the public health and may initiate any action on behalf of the city to prosecute a violation of this chapter or to abate a public health nuisance. As used in this chapter, "health officer" means the county health department. 
(Code 1997, § 11.01; Am. #263)  
Sec. 20-2. - Rules and regulations. 
The city and/or county health department may enact rules and regulations pertaining to health and sanitation which, when approved by the city council, may be enforced within the city as city ordinances, and violations thereof may be prosecuted by the county health department or by the city. 
(Code 1997, § 11.02; Am. #263)  
Sec. 20-3. - Health nuisances, abatement of. 
Wis. Stats. § 254.59 is adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter. The city and/or county health department may enforce the provisions of this section within the city. 
(Code 1997, § 11.03; Rep. & Recr. # 703 )  
Sec. 20-4. - Communicable diseases. 
Wis. Stats. § 252.01 and Wis. Admin. Code ch. DHS 145 are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter and the city and/or county health department shall enforce the provisions thereof. 
(Code 1997, § 11.04; Rep. & Recr. # 703 )  
Sec. 20-5. - Regulation of the application and use of fertilizers. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The common council finds that Delafield's lakes and streams are a natural asset, which enhance the environmental, recreational, cultural and economic resources of the area and contribute to the general health and welfare of the public. The purpose of this chapter is to set forth regulations which will enable the city to protect its water resources for the health, safety, and welfare of the public without detracting from the natural beauty of homeowners' lawns and gardens. The common council further finds that regulating the amount of nutrients and contaminants contained in fertilizer, including phosphorus, that enter the bodies of water as a result of runoff from lawns and turf will improve and maintain lake water quality. 
(b)  Applicability. This chapter applies in all areas of the City of Delafield. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fertilizer has the meaning set forth in Wis. Stats. § 94.64(1)(e). 
Impervious surface means a highway, street, sidewalk, parking lot, driveway, or other material that prevents infiltration of water into the soil. 
Lawn fertilizer means any fertilizer, whether distributed by property owner, renter or commercial entity, distributed for nonagricultural use, such as for lawns, golf courses, parks and cemeteries. "Lawn fertilizer" does not include fertilizer products intended primarily for garden and indoor plant application. 
(d)  Concerning the use and application of lawn fertilizer. 
(1)  No person shall apply any lawn fertilizer within the City of Delafield that is labeled as containing more than zero percent phosphorus or other compound containing phosphorus, such as phosphate, except as provided in subsection (e) of this section. 
(2)  No lawn fertilizer shall be applied when the ground is frozen. 
(3)  No lawn fertilizer shall be applied when conditions exist which promote or create runoff. 
(4)  No person shall apply fertilizer to any impervious surface. If such application occurs, the fertilizer must be immediately contained and either legally applied to turf or placed in an appropriate container. 
(5)  A sign containing the regulations set forth in this chapter and the effects of phosphorus on Delafield's waters must be prominently displayed where lawn fertilizers are sold within the city. 
(e)  Exemptions. The prohibition against the use of fertilizer under subsection (d) of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Turf or lawn areas newly established via seed or sod procedures during their first growing season. 
(2)  Turf or lawn areas that soil tests, performed within the past three years by a state-certified soil testing laboratory, confirm are below phosphorus levels established by the University of Wisconsin Extension Service. The lawn fertilizer application shall not contain an amount of phosphorus exceeding the amount and rate of application recommended in the soil test evaluation. 
(3)  Agricultural uses, vegetable and flower gardens, or application to trees or shrubs. 
(4)  Yard waste compost, biosolids or other similar materials that are primarily organic in nature and are applied to improve the physical condition of the soil. 
(f)  Enforcement. Violations of this chapter will be enforced by the city administrator or the city administrator's designee upon a complaint basis. 
(g)  Penalty. Unless otherwise exempted under subsection (e) of this section, any person who violates subsection (d) of this section in the application of fertilizer at his or her residence shall be subject to a forfeiture of $50.00 per violation. Any commercial fertilizer applicator, residential or commercial developer, industrial or commercial owner, or other person who violates subsection (d) of this section shall be subject to a forfeiture of $50.00 for the first violation within a 12-month period, $150.00 for the second violation within a 12-month period, and $300.00 for the third and each subsequent violation within a 12-month period. 
(Code 1997, § 11.10; Cr. #556)  
Chapter 22 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION 
(RESERVED)  
Chapter 24 - HUMAN RELATIONS AND SOCIAL SERVICES 
(RESERVED)  
Chapter 26 - LAW ENFORCEMENT  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-126-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 26-19. - Police department personnel. 
(a)  Enumerated. The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such police officers as the city council may prescribe by ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  Salary; collection of fees. The chief and the police officers shall receive a salary fixed by the city council and shall not be entitled to any other compensation. All fees, bail deposits and other special remuneration or funds collected or received by the department or any officers thereof shall be deposited with the treasurer not less than monthly, provided, in actions in municipal court deposited and forfeited penalties other than parking violation forfeitures shall be paid into the court. 
(Code 1997, § 4.01)  
Sec. 26-20. - Chief of policeDuties and powers. 
(a)  The chief of police shall possess the powers, enjoy the privileges and be subject to the liabilities conferred and imposed by law upon marshals and constables. 
(b)  He shall obey all lawful written orders of the mayor and council. 
(c)  He shall cause the public peace to be preserved and see that all laws and ordinances of the city and state are enforced; and whenever any violation thereof comes to his knowledge, he shall cause the requisite complaint to be made and see that the evidence is procured for the successful prosecution of the offender. 
(d)  He shall exercise supervisory control over all department personnel and may adopt rules and regulations for the government, discipline, equipment and uniforms of police officers. 
(e)  He shall be solely responsible for the care and condition of the equipment used by his department. 
(f)  He shall keep an accurate and complete record of all complaints, arrests, traffic violations, convictions and dispositions of the department. 
(Code 1997, § 4.02; Am. #691 )  
Sec. 26-21. - Police officersDuties and powers. 
Each officer of the department shall possess the powers conferred on marshals and constables by law and shall preserve the public peace and enforce the laws and ordinances of the state and city subject to the lawful orders, rules and regulations of the chief, the mayor and the council. 
(Code 1997, § 4.03)  
Sec. 26-22. - Power of arrest. 
The chief of police and police officers shall arrest any person in the city found in the act of violating any law or ordinance of the city or state or aiding or abetting in such violation and arrest without warrant any person whom they have reasonable grounds to believe has violated any law or ordinance and who will not be apprehended unless immediately arrested, shall take any arrested person in charge and confine him and shall within a reasonable time bring such person before the court having jurisdiction thereof to be dealt with according to law. 
(Code 1997, § 4.04)  
Sec. 26-23. - Destruction of police records. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish records retention schedules for police records and authorize destruction of police records pursuant to the schedule on an annual basis. Records custodians do not have authority to destroy records prior to the established retention period, unless such records have been photographically reproduced as original records under Wis. Stats. § 16.61(7), and under this section. 
(b)  Historical records. The State Historical Society of Wisconsin (SHSW) has waived the required 60 days' statutory notice under Wis. Stats. § 19.21(5)(d), for the records marked "W," which designates waived notice. SHSW must be notified prior to destruction of records marked "N," designating nonwaiver. "N/A" indicates not applicable and applies to all records designated for permanent retention. 
(c)  Destruction after request for inspection. No requested record may be destroyed until after the request is granted or 60 days after the request is denied. If an action is to commence under Wis. Stats. § 19.37, the requested record may not be destroyed until a court order is issued and all appeals have been completed. 
(d)  Destruction pending litigation. No record subject to pending litigation shall be destroyed until the litigation has been resolved. 
(e)  Electronic records. Any police department records may be kept on an electronic content management (ECM) software, provided the applicable standards established in Wis. Stats. § 16.61(7) are met. Factors, such as retention periods and estimated costs and benefits of converting records between different media, should be considered in deciding whether or not to digitize. The retention periods identified in this section apply to records in any media. 
(f)  Listing of records. All of the records listed below have been given a "W" designation by the State Historical Society of Wisconsin: 
Record 	Retention 
Radio tape recordings 	CR + 120 days 
Videotapes of patrol activities 	CR + 120 days 
Overnight parking permissions 	CR + 120 days 
Jail register 	CR + 8 years 
Personnel files 	EVT + 8 years 
Incidents and complaints 	CR + 10 years 
Arrest records, including support documents 	EVT + 8 years 
Traffic and parking ordinance violations 	EVT + 1 year 
Municipal ordinance violations 	EVT + 2 years 
Traffic accident reports 	EVT + 8 years
