(j)  Ongoing management fees. The cost of trimming trees around facilities is an ongoing cost to the city. The specific cost will be determined and a fee to offset those costs may be assessed in the future. 
(k)  Compliance with other laws. Obtaining a permit to excavate and/or occupy the right-of-way does not relieve permittee of its duty to obtain all other necessary permits, licenses, and authority and to pay all fees required by any other city, county, state, or federal rules, laws or regulations. A permittee shall comply with all requirements of local, state and federal laws. A permittee shall perform all work in conformance with all applicable codes and established rules and regulations, and is responsible for all work done in the right-of-way pursuant to its permit, regardless of who does the work. 
(l)  Revocations, suspensions, refusals to issue or extend permits. 
(1)  The department may refuse to issue a permit or may revoke, suspend or refuse to extend an existing permit if it finds any of the following grounds: 
a.  The applicant or permittee is required to be registered and has not done so; 
b.  Issuance of a permit for the requested date would interfere with an exhibition, celebration, festival or other event; 
c.  Misrepresentation of any fact by the applicant or permittee; 
d.  Failure of the applicant or permittee to maintain required bonds and/or insurance; 
e.  Failure of the applicant or permittee to complete work in a timely manner; 
f.  The proposed activity is contrary to the public health, safety or welfare; 
g.  The extent to which right-of-way space where the permit is sought is available; 
h.  The competing demands for the particular space in the right-of-way; 
i.  The availability of other locations in the right-of-way or in other rights-of-way for the facilities of the permittee or applicant; 
j.  The applicability of ordinances or other regulations of the right-of-way that affect location of facilities in the right-of-way. 
(2)  Discretionary issuance. The department may issue a permit where issuance is necessary: 
a.  To prevent substantial economic hardship to a customer of the permittee or applicant; or 
b.  To allow such customer to materially improve its utility service; or 
c.  To allow the permittee or applicant to comply with state or federal law or city ordinance or an order of a court or administrative agency. 
(3)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the department revoking, suspending, refusing to issue or refusing to extend a permit may file a request for review with the city council. A request for review shall be filed within ten days of the decision being appealed. Following a hearing, the city council may affirm, reverse or modify the decision of the department. 
(m)  Work done without a permit. 
(1)  Emergency situations. 
a.  Each registrant shall immediately notify the city by verbal notice on an emergency phone number provided by the city of any event regarding its facilities that it considers to be an emergency. The registrant may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary to respond to the emergency. Within two business days after the occurrence of the emergency the registrant shall apply for the necessary permits, pay the fees associated therewith and otherwise fully comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
b.  If the city becomes aware of any emergency regarding a registrant's facilities, the department may attempt to contact the local representative of each registrant affected, or potentially affected, by the emergency. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary to protect the public safety as a result of the emergency, the cost of which shall be borne by the registrant whose facilities occasioned the emergency. 
(2)  Non-emergency situations. Except in an emergency, any person who, without first having obtained the necessary permit, excavates a right-of-way must subsequently obtain a permit, and shall in addition to any penalties prescribed by ordinance, pay double the normal fee for said permit, pay double all the other fees required by this chapter or other chapters of the General Ordinances of the City of Delafield, deposit with the department the fees necessary to correct any damage to the right-of-way and comply with all of the requirements of this chapter. 
(n)  Location of facilities. 
(1)  Undergrounding. Unless in conflict with state or federal law, except when existing aboveground facilities are used, the installation of new facilities and replacement of old facilities shall be done underground or contained within buildings or other structures in conformity with applicable codes. 
(2)  Limitation of space. The department may prohibit or limit the placement of new or additional facilities within the right-of-way if there is insufficient space to accommodate all of the requests of persons to occupy and use the right-of-way. In making such decisions, the department shall strive to the extent possible to accommodate all existing and potential users of the right-of-way, but may prohibit or limit the placement of new or additional facilities when required to protect the public, health, safety or welfare. 
(o)  Relocation of facilities. A registrant must, promptly and at its own expense, permanently remove and relocate its facilities in the right-of-way whenever the city, acting in its governmental capacity, requests such removal and relocation. If requested, the registrant shall restore the right-of-way. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a person shall not be required to remove or relocate its facilities from any right-of-way which has been vacated in favor of a non-governmental entity unless and until the reasonable costs thereof are first paid to the person therefor. 
(p)  Interference with other facilities during municipal construction. When the city performs work in the right-of-way and finds it necessary to maintain, support, shore, or move a registrant's facilities, the city shall notify the local representative. The registrant shall meet with the city's representative within 24 hours and coordinate the protection, maintenance, supporting and/or shoring of the registrant's facilities. The registrant shall accomplish the needed work within 72 hours, unless the city agrees to a longer period. In the event that the registrant does not proceed to maintain, support, shore or move its facilities, the city may arrange to do the work and bill the registrant, said bill to be paid within 30 days. 
(q)  Abandoned facilities. 
(1)  Discontinued operations. A registrant who has determined to discontinue its operations in the city must either: 
a.  Provide information satisfactory to the department that the registrant's obligations for its facilities under this chapter have been lawfully assumed by another registrant; or 
b.  Submit to the department a proposal and instruments for dedication of its facilities to the city. If a registrant proceeds under this clause, the city may, at its option: 
1.  Accept the dedication for all or a portion of the facilities; or 
2.  Require the registrant, at its own expense, to remove the facilities in the right-of-way at ground or above ground level; or 
3.  Require the registrant to post a bond or provide payment sufficient to reimburse the city for reasonably anticipated costs to be incurred in removing the facilities. 
However, any registrant who has unusable and abandoned facilities in any right-of-way shall remove it from that right-of-way within two years, unless the department waives this requirement. 
(2)  Abandoned facilities. Facilities of a registrant who fails to comply with subsection (q)(1) of this section, and which, for two years, remains unused shall be deemed to be abandoned. Abandoned facilities are deemed to be a nuisance. In addition to any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, the city may, at its option: 
a.  Abate the nuisance; 
b.  Take possession of the facilities; or 
c.  Require removal of the facilities by the registrant, or the registrant's successor in interest. 
(3)  Public utilities. This section shall not apply to a public utility, as defined by Wis. Stats. § 196.01(5), that is required to follow the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 196.81. 
(r)  Reservation of regulatory and police powers. The city, by the granting of a permit to excavate, obstruct and/or occupy the right-of-way, or by registering a person under this chapter does not surrender or in any extent lose, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or maybe hereafter granted to the city under the constitution and statutes of the State of Wisconsin to regulate the use of the right-of-way by the permittee; and the permittee by its acceptance of a permit to excavate, obstruct and/or occupy the right-of-way or of registration under this chapter agrees that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory powers, or police power, or otherwise as are or the same may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and effect and subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general law, and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to such powers. 
(s)  Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. 
(t)  Penalty. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $120.00 nor more than $600.00. Each day such violation or failure to comply continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1997, § 8.09; Cr. #733 )  
Chapter 44 - SUBDIVISIONS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 44-1. - Authority. 
These regulations are adopted under the authority granted by Wis. Stats. §§ 66.23, 236.45 and 703.27(1). 
(Code 1997, § 18.01; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the development of land, creation of condominium developments, the division of land within the corporate limits of the city, and the extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of the city in order to promote the public health, safety, morals, aesthetics, and general welfare of the community; and it is deemed in the best interests of the city to adopt a floodplain management program in pursuance with the State Water Resources Act of 1965. 
(Code 1997, § 18.02; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-3. - Intent. 
(a)  It is the general intent of this chapter to regulate the development and division of land so as to: 
(1)  Lessen congestion in and promote the safety and efficiency of the streets and highways. 
(2)  Further the orderly and appropriate layout and use of land. 
(3)  Secure safety from fire, flooding, water pollution, disease, panic and other dangers or hazards. 
(4)  Provide adequate light, air, sanitation and drainage. 
(5)  Avoid the overcrowding of land and undue population concentration. 
(6)  Facilitate the adequate provision of public facilities, utilities, schools, parks and playgrounds. 
(7)  Facilitate the further division of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. 
(8)  Ensure adequate legal description and proper survey monumentation of subdivided land. 
(9)  Implement enforcement of community development standards as are presently, and as may in the future be, set forth in the comprehensive plan, zoning ordinances, building code and official map of the city. 
(10)  Prevent flood damage to persons and properties and minimize expenditures for flood relief and flood control projects. 
(11)  Obtain dedication of floodlands. 
(12)  Restrict building sites on floodlands or in other areas poorly suited for development. 
(13)  Prevent and control erosion, sedimentation, and other pollution of surface and subsurface water. 
(14)  Promote the natural beauty of the city, including preservation of shore growth and cover. 
(b)  It is further intended to provide for the administration and enforcement of this chapter and to provide penalties for its violation. 
(Code 1997, § 18.03; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-4. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate, impair or interfere with any existing easements, covenants, deed restrictions, agreements, ordinances, rules, regulations or permits previously adopted or issued pursuant to laws. However, where this chapter imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this chapter shall govern. 
(Code 1997, § 18.04; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-5. - Interpretation. 
In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements, shall be liberally construed in favor of the city and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other power granted by the Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Code 1997, § 18.05; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-6. - Severability. 
If any section, clause, provision or portion of this chapter is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall not be affected thereby. 
(Code 1997, § 18.06; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-7. - Nonliability of city. 
The city does not guarantee, warrant or represent that only those areas designated as floodlands will be subject to periodic inundation and hereby asserts that there is no liability on the part of the common council, its agencies or employees for any flood damages that may occur as a result of reliance upon and conformance with this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.07; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-8. - Repeal. 
All other ordinances or parts of ordinances of the city inconsistent or conflicting with this chapter to the extent of such inconsistency or conflict only are hereby repealed. 
(Code 1997, § 18.08; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-9. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known as, referred to or cited as the "Subdivision and Land Development Ordinance, City of Delafield, Wisconsin." 
(Code 1997, § 18.09; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-10. - Effective date. 
This chapter shall be effective August 21, 1998. 
(Code 1997, § 18.10; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-11. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall be used. The words used in the present tense include the future; the singular number includes the plural; and the plural number includes the singular. The word "shall" is mandatory and not directory. 
Alley means a special public way affording only secondary access to abutting properties. 
Arterial street means a street used, or intended to be used, primarily for fast or heavy through traffic. Arterial streets shall include freeways and expressways, as well as standard arterial streets, highways and parkways. 
Bicycle trail means a trail used or intended to be used primarily for nonmotorized bicycles. 
Building line means a line parallel to a lot line and at a distance from the lot line to comply with the city zoning code as to yard requirements. 
Collector street means a street used, or intended to be used, to carry traffic from minor streets to the major system of arterial streets, including the principal entrance streets to residential developments. 
Community means a town, municipality, or a group of adjacent towns or municipalities having common social, economic or physical interests. 
Comprehensive plan means the comprehensive plan is the development plan heretofore or hereafter adopted by the plan commission and certified to the common council pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.23(2), including proposals for future land use, transportation, urban redevelopment and public facilities. Devices and means for the implementation of the comprehensive plan, such as zoning, official map, building line ordinances and the like, shall be considered a part of the comprehensive plan. 
County planning agency means Waukesha County Parks and Land Use. 
Cul-de-sac means a minor street closed at one end with a turnaround provided for motor vehicles. 
Developer means any person, firm or corporation, or any agent thereof, developing land or constructing a structure in the City of Delafield. 
Equestrian trail means a trail used or intended to be used primarily for equestrian traffic. 
Extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction means the unincorporated area within 1½ miles of the city. 
Floodlands means those lands including the floodplains, floodways and channels subject to inundation by the 100-year recurrence interval flood or where such data is not available, the maximum flood of record. 
Frontage street means a minor street auxiliary to and located on the side of an arterial street, for control of access and for service to the abutting development. 
High water elevation means the average annual high water level of a pond, stream, lake, flowage or wetland, or if where such data is not available, the point up to which the presence of the water is so frequent as to leave a distinct mark by erosion, change in or destruction of vegetation or other easily recognized topographic, geologic or vegetative characteristic. 
Land development means any new construction of structures, required improvements on land, or subdivision of land or consolidation of parcels in the City of Delafield. 
Minor street means a street used or intended to be used, primarily for access to abutting property. 
Minor subdivision means the division of land by the owner or subdivider resulting in the creation of four or less parcels or building sites, any one of which is 1½ acres in size or less, or the division of a block, lot or outlot within a recorded subdivision, with not more than four parcels or building sites without changing the exterior boundaries of said block, lot or outlot. 
Municipality means an incorporated city. 
Public way means any public road, street, highway, walkway, drainageway, equestrian trail, bicycle trail or part thereof. 
Registered land surveyor means a surveyor duly registered by the State of Wisconsin. 
Street plat means the changing of the boundaries of a recorded subdivision plat or part thereof. 
Subdivider means any person, firm or corporation, or any agent thereof, dividing or proposing to divide land resulting in a subdivision, minor subdivision, or replat. 
Subdivision means the division of a lot, parcel or tract of land by the owners thereof, or their agents, for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development, where the act of division creates five or more parcels or building sites of 1½ acres each, or less in area; or where the act of division creates five or more parcels or building sites of 1½ acres each, or less in area, by successive division within a period of five years. 
Wetlands means those lands that are partially or wholly covered by marshland flora and generally covered with shallow standing water or lands that are wet and spongy due to a high water table. 
(Code 1997, § 18.11; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-12. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  Jurisdiction of this chapter and the regulations therein contained shall include all lands within the corporate limits of the city as well as the unincorporated area within 1½ miles of the corporate limits. 
(b)  The provisions of this chapter as it applies to divisions of tracts of land into less than five parcels shall not apply to: 
(1)  Transfers of interest in land by will or pursuant to court order. 
(2)  Leases for a term not to exceed ten years, mortgages or easements. 
(3)  Sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining property if additional lots are not thereby created and the lots resulting are not reduced below the minimum sizes required by these regulations, zoning ordinance, or other applicable laws or ordinances. 
(4)  Division of land for agricultural purposes in parcels of more than ten acres, not involving any new street, easement or access. 
(c)  The provisions of this chapter apply to all land developments within the City of Delafield. 
(Code 1997, § 18.12; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-13. - Compliance. 
No person, firm or corporation shall develop land or divide any land located within the jurisdictional limits of these regulations which results in a subdivision, minor subdivision, or a replat as defined herein, no such division shall be entitled to be recorded, no street shall be laid out or improvements made to land without compliance with: 
(1)  All requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Provisions of Wis. Stats. chs. 62 and 236. 
(3)  Rules of the Wisconsin division of environmental protection, as applicable to the city, setting water quality standards, preventing and abating pollution, and regulating septic systems. 
(4)  Applicable rules of the Wisconsin department of transportation if the land divided abuts a state trunk highway or a street connecting therewith. 
(5)  City comprehensive plan. 
(6)  Zoning ordinances, official map and all other applicable local and county ordinances. 
(Code 1997, § 18.13; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-14. - Applicability to condominiums. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 703.27(1), this chapter applies to condominiums. 
(b)  In the event land is developed and improved under condominium ownership, which includes the construction of public or private roads and streets to serve buildings, such roads and streets shall conform to the provisions of this code, whether or not the land is laid out in lots or blocks. 
(c)  All the required improvements set forth in article VII of this chapter shall be applicable, whether or not the land is laid out in lots or blocks. 
(d)  All other provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to the condominium development to the extent applicable. 
(e)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply whether the condominium development is a new development or a conversion to or from condominiums. 
(Code 1997, § 18.14; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-15. - Dedication and reservation of lands. 
(a)  Whenever a tract of land to be developed or subdivided embraces all or any part of an arterial street, drainageway or other public way that has been designated in the comprehensive plan, comprehensive plan component, or on the official map of the city, such public way shall be made a part of the plat and dedicated or reserved by the subdivider or developer at the locations and in the dimensions indicated on said plan or such map and as set forth in article VI of this chapter. 
(b)  Whenever a proposed playground, park or other public land (other than streets or drainageways), designated in the comprehensive plan, comprehensive plan component, or on the official map of the city, is embraced all or in part in a tract of land to be subdivided or developed, such proposed public lands shall be made a part of the plat or site plan and shall be dedicated at no charge to the public by the subdivider or developer at the rate of 1/20 acre for each proposed dwelling unit, but such dedicated lands shall not include floodlands. 
(c)  Any such proposed public lands, other than streets or drainageways, in excess of the rate established herein, shall be reserved for a period not to exceed two years unless extended by mutual agreement for purchase by the city or public agency having jurisdiction. Such lands so reserved for future purchase as herein provided shall be expressly defined and described by the plan commission prior to preliminary plat or site plan approval as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  In the event of the purchase of such land so reserved within the time herein limited, the subdivider or developer shall be paid for such excess lands as so reserved as follows: 
(1)  If he purchased such land within one year prior to filing of his application for plat approval, a sum equal to the cost to him of such land, with the cost to be computed as follows: 
a.  A certified public accountant selected by the subdivider or developer shall compute the cost of the land and the fair allocation of the cost of all improvements which have been installed by the subdivider or developer and which benefit such land. 
b.  The computations shall show in detail the principles upon which the costs were allocated; provided, that if the purchasing authority shall disagree with the cost figures as so submitted, the matter may at the option of the purchasing authority be referred to a board of three arbitrators, one of whom shall be selected by the subdivider or developer, one by the city clerk, and the third, who shall be a certified public accountant, to be selected by the first two arbitrators. 
c.  The decision of the arbitrators shall be final as to the cost of the land to be acquired, and the expense of such arbitration shall be shared equally by the subdivider or developer and the purchasing authority. 
(2)  If the subdivider or developer shall not have purchased the land within one year prior to filing the application for plat approval, he shall be paid for such excess land so reserved a sum equal to the market value thereof, and such market value shall be determined by the city or purchasing authority after appraisal of such land by a qualified real estate appraiser. 
(3)  Whether the value of the land is determined on the basis of cost or market value, the subdivider or developer shall in addition to the amount so determined, be paid a sum equal to five percent of such amount to accrue from the time of recording of the plat or issuance of a building permit to the time of payment to the subdivider or developer. 
(e)  In the event the subdivider or developer shall not be required to dedicate or reserve lands under the terms of this subsection, a public site fee shall be levied against the subdivider or developer at the rate and according to the procedures established in section 44-271. 
(f)  Proposed public lands lying outside the corporate limits of the city, but within the jurisdictional area of this chapter, shall be reserved for acquisition by the town or county at undeveloped land cost, and such reservation shall be for a period not to exceed two years unless extended by mutual agreement between the subdivider or developer and the town or county. 
(g)  Land dedicated to the city under the provisions of this section shall be graded and seeded to the specifications of the city engineer. Unless otherwise specified by the city engineer all land dedicated for park purposes shall be seeded to a mixture containing a minimum of 50 percent bluegrasses and 50 percent fescues and ryegrasses. 
(Code 1997, § 18.15; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-16. - Improvements, improvement bond, approval of contractors. 
(a)  Before final approval of any plat or land development located within the corporate limits of the city, the subdivider or developer shall install street and utility improvements, other required improvements, and survey monuments as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  If such improvements and monuments are not installed as required at the time that the final plat is submitted for approval, the subdivider or developer shall before the recording of the plat enter into a contract with the city agreeing to install the required improvements and monuments and shall file with such contract a bond meeting the approval of the city attorney or a certified check. 
(c)  Such bond or certified check shall equal 110 percent of the city engineer's estimate of the cost of such improvements and monuments. 
(d)  Such bond or certified check shall guarantee that such improvements and monuments will be installed by the subdivider or developer not later than one year from the date of recording of the plat and further to guarantee that all obligations to subcontractors for work on the development are satisfied. 
(e)  No occupancy permits shall be issued for any structure in the proposed subdivision until the improvements required by this chapter have been installed and accepted by the city. 
(f)  The owner may not sell any lot prior to the acceptance of the public improvement by the city, unless he gives a promise in writing to each purchaser, that he will complete the improvements in accordance with city specifications. 
(g)  Contractors and subcontractors who are to be engaged in the construction of street and utility improvements on dedicated street rights-of-way shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(h)  Governmental units to which such bond and contract provisions apply may file, in lieu of such contract bond and check, a letter from officers authorized to act on their behalf agreeing to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(i)  As to plats outside the corporate limits of the city, but within the plat approval jurisdiction of the city, the subdivider shall give evidence that he has complied with all street and utility improvement requirements of the town in which the land being platted is located. 
(Code 1997, § 18.16; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-17. - Bond and waiver requirements. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall tender a cash bond in a sum sufficient to guarantee that any and all engineering, legal, administrative or fiscal work incurred by the city in processing any plat, plan, specification, application, petition or in processing any other work incurred pursuant to the terms of this chapter will be paid in full, but in no event shall said cash bond be less than $500.00. 
(b)  This provision may be waived or reduced, upon written application, by the common council where the anticipated expense to the city is so minimal as to render the bond requirements set forth herein an unnecessary hardship upon the subdivider or developer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.17; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-18. - Modifications. 
(a)  Where in the judgment of the plan commission it would be inappropriate literally to apply the provisions of articles VI and VII of this chapter because of the proposed subdivision being located outside of the corporate limits, or because exceptional or undue hardship would result, the plan commission may waive or modify any requirement to the extent deemed justified and proper. 
(b)  Such waiver or modification shall require a three-fourths vote of the entire membership of the plan commission, and the reasons for such waiver or modification shall be entered on the minutes of the plan commission. 
(c)  In determining whether such waiver or modification is to be granted, consideration shall be given to whether such action will result in any detriment to the public good or the desirable general development of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan, and whether such relief would impair the intent and general purpose of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.18; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-19. - Land suitability. 
No land shall be subdivided or developed which is held unsuitable by the plan commission by reason of flooding, inadequate drainage, adverse soil or rock formation, unfavorable topography, characteristics inadequate for sewage disposal system or by reason of any other feature likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future users of the proposed subdivision. 
(1)  Lands made, altered or filled with within the last ten years shall not be divided into building sites which are to be served by a soil absorption waste disposal system. 
(2)  Existing residential land abutting Lake Nagawicka, Upper Nashotah Lake, Bark River, or wetland shall not hereafter be divided so as to give water access to more than one residential lot. 
(3)  Lands shall not be divided into building sites to be served by soil absorption sewage disposal systems without first obtaining required permits from the Waukesha Environmental Health Division. 
(Code 1997, § 18.19; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-20. - Lake access by off-lots. 
No subdivision or development shall be approved which creates or uses any site, tract, strip or piece of land lying on any lake or stream, any portion of which is within the city corporate limits, for use of, or access to, such lake or stream, for the benefit of any lots or outlots in a subdivision which are off-shore, whether such use or access is by fee title, reservation or easement. 
(Code 1997, § 18.20; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-21. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to build upon, divide, convey, record, or monument any land in violation of this chapter or of the Wisconsin Statutes. No person, firm or corporation shall be issued a building permit by the city authorizing the building on, or improvements of, any subdivision, minor subdivision, replat or land split within the jurisdiction of this chapter until the provisions and requirements of this chapter have been fully met. The city may institute appropriate action or proceedings to enjoin violations of this chapter or the applicable Wisconsin Statutes. 
(b)  Every structure, fill or development placed or maintained on floodlands in violation of this chapter is a public nuisance and the creation thereof may be enjoined and maintenance thereof may be abated by action at suit of the city. 
(Code 1997, § 18.21; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-22. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 and the costs of prosecution for each violation, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until payment thereof, but not exceeding 30 days. 
(b)  Each day a violation exists or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties herein provided, the penalties provided in Wis. Stats. § 236.30, relating to improper recordation, the penalty provided for in Wis. Stats. § 236.31, relating to conveyance of lots and unrecorded plats, and the penalties provided for in Wis. Stats. § 236.32, relating to disturbance of monuments shall apply. 
(d)  Floodland structures, fills, and development shall have penalties as specified in Wis. Stats. § 87.30(2). 
(Code 1997, § 18.22; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-23. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by an objection to a plat or a failure to approve a plat may appeal therefrom as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 236.13(5) and 62.23(7)(e)1015, within 30 days after notification of the rejection of the plat. 
(b)  Where failure to approve the plat is based on an unsatisfied objection, the agency making the objection shall be made a party to the action. The court shall direct that the plat be approved if it finds that the action of the approving or objection agency is arbitrary, unreasonable or discriminatory. 
(Code 1997, § 18.23; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Secs. 44-2444-49. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 44-50. - Initial consultation. 
It is recommended that prior to the filing of any application for plat approval, the subdivider consult the plan commission or its staff in order to obtain advice and assistance. This consultation is neither formal nor mandatory. 
(Code 1997, § 18.24; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-51. - Preliminary plat review within the city. 
(a)  Before submitting the final plat for approval, the subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat and a letter of application. The preliminary plat shall be prepared in accordance with this chapter, and the subdivider shall file an adequate number of copies of the preliminary plat and the application with the city clerk at least 25 days prior to the meeting of the plan commission at which action is desired. 
(b)  The city clerk shall within two days after filing thereof, transmit: 
(1)  Four copies to the county planning agency. 
(2)  One copy to Southeastern Wisconsin Regional Planning Commission in the case of areas to be sewered. 
(3)  Two copies to the department of agriculture, trade and consumer protection, with two additional copies for the state department of transportation if the subdivision abuts or adjoins a state trunk highway or a connecting street and two copies for the department of health and social services if the subdivision is not served by public sewer and provision for such service has not been made. 
(4)  An adequate number of copies to the plan commission. 
(c)  The plan commission is hereby designated as the approving authority for all preliminary plats, and it shall transmit a copy of the preliminary plat to all affected city boards, commissions or departments, and all affected local utility companies and school districts for their review and recommendations. Such recommendations shall be transmitted to the plan commission within 15 days from the date the plat is filed. The preliminary plat shall then be reviewed by the plan commission for conformance with this chapter and all other applicable ordinances, rules, regulations, comprehensive plans and comprehensive plan components in effect when the subdivider submits a preliminary plat or a final plat if no preliminary plat is submitted. 
(Code 1997, § 18.25; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. #646)  
Sec. 44-52. - Preliminary plat approval within the city. 
(a)  The following are objecting agencies: The county planning agency, Southeastern Wisconsin Regional Planning Commission in the case of areas to be sewered, department of agriculture, trade and consumer protection, Wisconsin department of transportation, the department of health and social services, and the Wisconsin department of administration. 
(1)  The objecting agencies shall, within 20 days of the date of receiving their copies of the preliminary plat, notify the subdivider and all other approving and objecting agencies of any objections. If there are no objections, they shall so certify on the face of the copy of the plat and return that copy to the plan commission. 
(2)  If an objecting agency fails to act within 20 days it shall be deemed to have no objection to the plat. 
(b)  The plan commission shall within 90 days of the date of filing the preliminary plat approve, approve conditionally, or reject such plat. 
(1)  One copy of the plat shall thereupon be returned to the subdivider with the date and action endorsed thereon; and if approved conditionally or rejected, a letter setting forth the conditions of approval or the reasons for rejection shall accompany the plat. 
(2)  One copy each of the plat and such letter shall be placed in the plan commission's permanent file. 
(c)  Failure of the plan commission to act within 90 days shall constitute an approval. 
(d)  Approval or conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute automatic approval of the final plat, except that if the final plat is submitted within 36 months of preliminary plat approval and conforms substantially to the preliminary plat layout as indicated in Wis. Stats. § 236.11(1)(b), the final plat shall be entitled to approval with respect to such layout. 
(Code 1997, § 18.26; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #486; Rep. & Recr. #646; Am. # 720 ; )  
Sec. 44-53. - Final plat review within the city. 
(a)  The subdivider shall prepare a final plat and a letter of application in accordance with this chapter and shall file an adequate number of copies of the plat and the application with the city clerk at least 25 days prior to the meeting of the plan commission at which action is desired. Additionally, all plans shall be provided to both the city clerk and city engineer in digital (i.e., PDF) format. 
(b)  Within two days after filing, the city clerk shall transmit the same number of copies to the same agencies as required of the preliminary plat and as referred to in section 44-52. 
(c)  The plan commission shall examine the final plat as to its conformance with the approved preliminary plat, all conditions of approval of the preliminary plat, if any, and this chapter as well as all ordinances, rules, regulations, comprehensive plan and comprehensive plan components which may affect the final plat. It shall then, based on a recommendation from the city planner, recommend approval, conditional approval or rejection of the plat to the common council. 
(d)  The final plat, may, if so permitted by the plan commission, constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record at that time. 
(Code 1997, § 18.27; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #588; Rep. & Recr. #646)  
Sec. 44-54. - Final plat approval within the city. 
(a)  The objecting agencies shall, within 20 days of the date of receiving their copies of the final plat, notify the subdivider and all other approving and objecting agencies of any objections. 
(1)  If there are no objections, they shall so certify on the face of the copy of the plat and shall return that copy to the plan commission. 
(2)  If an objecting agency fails to act within 20 days, it shall be deemed to have no objection to the plat. 
(b)  If the final plat is not submitted within 36 months of the last required approval of the preliminary plat, the common council may refuse to approve the final plat. The common council may extend the time for submission of the final plat beyond 36 months, if requested by the subdivider. 
(c)  The plan commission shall, within 30 days of the date of filing of the final plat with the city clerk, recommend approval, conditional approval or rejection of the plat and shall transmit the final plat and application along with its recommendations to the common council. 
(d)  The plan commission, when it determines to recommend approval of a plat, shall give at least ten days prior written notice of its intention to the clerk of any municipality within 1,000 feet of the plat. 
(e)  The common council shall, within 60 days after the date of filing the original final plat with the city clerk, approve or reject such plat unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. 
(1)  If the plat is rejected, the reasons shall be stated in the minutes of the meeting and a written statement of the reasons forwarded to the subdivider. 
(2)  The common council shall not inscribe its approval on the final plat until the city clerk certifies on the face of the plat: 
a.  That the copies were forwarded to objecting agencies as herein required. 
b.  The date of such forwarding. 
c.  That no objections have been filed within 20 days, or if filed, have been met. 
(f)  Upon failure of the common council to act within 60 days, the time having not been extended and no unsatisfied objections having been filed, the plat shall be deemed approved. 
(g)  After the final plat has been approved by the common council and required improvements have been installed or a contract and sureties insuring their installation have been filed, the city clerk shall cause the certificate inscribed upon the plat attesting to such approval to be duly executed and record the final plat with the Waukesha County register of deeds, but the plat shall not be recorded unless it is offered for recording within 12 months from the date of the last approval and not more than 36 months after the first approval. 
(h)  The subdivider shall file ten copies of the final plat with the city clerk for distribution to the city engineer, building inspector, assessor, and other affected departments for their files. Additionally, all plans shall be provided to both the city clerk and city engineer in digital (i.e., PDF) format. 
(i)  AutoCAD drawing files of all final plats shall be submitted to the city engineer as required. 
(j)  The subdivider may develop a subdivision in conformance with a phasing plan approved by the plan commission and common council. 
(1)  Financial surety for a phased final plat shall be commensurate with the extent of infrastructure improvements unique to the active phase of development. 
(2)  Each subsequent phase of a phased final plat shall be permitted as an independent development with financial surety applicable to infrastructure improvements unique to the approved phase. 
(3)  Upon completion of a phase of development the financial surety applicable to that phase shall refunded to the subdivider as recommended by the city engineer and approved by the common council. 
(Code 1997, § 18.28; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. #588; Cr. #588; Cr. #646; Am. #646; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-55. - Plats within extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction. 
When the land to be subdivided lies within 1½ miles of the corporate limits of the city, the city may not deny approval of a plat based on land use. The city shall review the plat for compliance with applicable zoning and subdivision regulations as prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7a). The subdivider shall proceed as specified in sections 44-50 through 44-54, except: 
(1)  Transmittal responsibility lies with the city clerk, town clerk or county planning agency, to whomever the plat is first submitted, and the subdivider shall indicate which one is charged with such responsibility in his application. 
(2)  Approval agencies include the city plan commission, the common council, the town board and county planning agency, and the subdivider must comply with the subdivision control or land division ordinances of those agencies. 
(3)  The subdivider may proceed with the installation of such improvements and under such regulations as the town board of the town within whose limits the plat lies may require. Wherever connection to any city utility is desired, approval by the common council for such connection shall be required. 
(4)  All improvement requirements specified by the town board or any special improvement district in matters over which they have jurisdiction, shall be met before filing of the final plat. 
(Code 1997, § 18.29; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. #646)  
Sec. 44-56. - Replat. 
(a)  When it is proposed to replat a recorded subdivision, or a part thereof, so as to change the boundaries of such recorded subdivision, or part thereof, the subdivider or person wishing to replat shall vacate or alter the recorded plat as provided by the Wisconsin Statutes, and the subdivider or person wishing to replat shall then proceed as specified in sections 44-50 through 44-54. 
(b)  The city clerk shall schedule a public hearing before the plan commission when a preliminary plat of a replat of lands within the city is filed and shall cause notices of the proposed replat and public hearing to be mailed to the owners of all properties within the limits of the exterior boundaries of the proposed replat and to the owners of all properties within 200 feet of the exterior boundaries of the proposed replat. 
(Code 1997, § 18.30; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-57. - Minor subdivision. 
(a)  When it is proposed to divide land into four or less parcels or building sites, any one of which is less than 1½ acres in size, or when it is proposed to divide a block, lot or outlot into not more than four parcels or building sites within a recorded subdivision without changing the boundaries of such block, lot or outlot, the subdivider may subdivide by use of a certified survey map. 
(b)  The subdivider shall prepare the certified survey map in accordance with this chapter and shall file an adequate number of copies of the map and a completed application form with the city clerk at least 25 days prior to the meeting of the plan commission at which action is desired. 
(c)  The city clerk shall within two days after filing thereof, transmit the copies of the certified survey map and application form to the plan commission, which shall transmit a copy of such map to all affected city boards, commissions or departments for their review and recommendations concerning matters within their jurisdiction. 
(d)  Their recommendations shall be transmitted to the plan commission within ten days from the date the map is filed. Thereupon the map shall be reviewed by the plan commission for conformity with this chapter and all ordinances, rules, regulations, comprehensive plans and comprehensive plan components which affect it. 
(e)  The plan commission shall, within 60 days from the date of filing of the map recommend approval, conditional approval or rejection and shall transmit the map along with its recommendations to the common council. 
(f)  The common council shall approve, approve conditionally, or reject such map within 60 days from the date of filing of the map unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. If the map is rejected, the reason shall be stated in the minutes of the meeting and a written statement forwarded to the subdivider. If the map is approved, the common council shall cause the city clerk so to certify on the face of the original map and return a copy of the map to the subdivider. 
(g)  The city clerk shall record the original map with the county register of deeds within 30 days of its approval by the common council, and shall distribute copies of the certified survey map to the city engineer, building inspector, assessor and other affected departments for their files, retaining a copy for the clerk's files. (See section 44-277 regarding recording fees.) Additionally, all plans shall be provided to both the city clerk and city engineer in digital (i.e., PDF) format. 
(h)  AutoCAD drawing files of minor subdivisions shall be submitted to the city engineer as required. 
(Code 1997, § 18.31; Rep. & Recr. #441; Cr. #588; Rep. & Recr. #588; Am. #620; Rep. # 689 ) 
( Ord. No. 745 , § 1, 5-7-2018)  
Sec. 44-58. - Other land splits. 
(a)  When it is proposed to divide any parcel of land resulting in a division of land other than a subdivision or minor subdivision, an application therefor shall be made by petition, accompanied by a certified survey map, to the plan commission, and no such division shall be permitted unless the same be approved by the city council. It shall be recorded as in section 44-57. 
(b)  Dedication fees will be required of all land splits under this section where additional parcels of land are created except that dedication fees are not to be required where the land split creates parcels no one of which are less than ten acres in size. 
(Code 1997, § 18.32; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Secs. 44-5944-89. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 
 
Sec. 44-90. - General. 
A preliminary plat shall be required for all subdivisions, and shall comply with all aspects of article II of this chapter. The plat shall be shall be based upon a survey by a registered land surveyor, and the plat prepared on tracing cloth or paper of a good quality at a scale of not more than 100 feet to the inch and shall show correctly on its face: 
(1)  Date, scale, and north point. 
(2)  The proposed subdivision name, which shall not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in Waukesha County. 
(3)  Names and addresses of the owner, subdivider and land surveyor preparing the plat. 
(4)  Location of proposed subdivision by government lot, quarter section, section, township, range, and county. 
(5)  A small scale drawing of the section or government subdivision of the section in which the subdivision lies, with location of the subdivision indicated thereon. 
(6)  The entire area owned or controlled by the subdivider contiguous to the proposed plat shall be included on the preliminary plat even though only a portion of such area is proposed for immediately development. The plan commission may waive this requirement where it is unnecessary to fulfill the purposes and intent of this chapter, and undue hardship would result from strict application of this section. 
(Code 1997, § 18.33; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. #646)  
Sec. 44-91. - Plat data. 
All preliminary plats shall show the following: 
(1)  Title of development. 
(2)  Location map. 
(3)  Name and address of the owner, subdivider and surveyor. 
(4)  Sheet number and total numbered sheets. 
(5)  North arrow and graphic scale. 
(6)  Soil types. 
(7)  Wetlands and source of delineation. 
(8)  Existing structures on the property and within 50 feet of the property. 
(9)  Wells on the property and within 100 feet of the property. 
(10)  Storm water management facilities. 
(11)  All drain tiles on the property. 
(12)  The quarter-quarter section where the property is located, exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries of the proposed subdivision referenced to a corner established in U.S. Public Land Survey, and the total acreage encompassed thereby. 
(13)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet, with reference to U.S.G.S. datum, or at more frequent intervals if required by the plan commission for land of unusual topography. 
(14)  Water elevations of adjoining lakes and streams at the date of the survey and the ordinary high water mark of such lakes or streams, all referred to U.S.G.S. datum. In the case of floodlands, floodland boundaries and the contour line lying a vertical distance of two feet above the elevation of the 100-year recurrence interval flood. 
(15)  If the subdivision borders a lake or stream, the distances and bearing of a meander line established not less than 20 feet back from the ordinary high water mark of the lake or stream. 
(16)  Location, widths, and names of all existing streets, alleys or other public ways and easements; railroad and utility rights-of-way; parks; cemeteries; water courses; drainage ditches; permanent buildings; bridges; and other pertinent data as determined by the plan commission within the exterior boundaries of the plat, and within 300 feet of the proposed subdivision, and on all property adjacent to the proposed subdivision that is owned or controlled by the subdivider. 
(17)  Location and names of any adjacent subdivisions and owners of record of adjoining parcels of unplatted lands. 
(18)  Type, width, and elevation of any existing streets and rights-of-way, including easements for sewers, water mains, and other public utilities within the exterior boundaries of the plat or immediately adjacent thereto. 
(19)  Location, size and invert elevation of any existing or proposed sanitary or storm sewers, culverts and drain pipes, telephone poles, and the location and size of any existing or proposed water and gas mains within the exterior boundaries of the plat or immediately adjacent thereto. If there are no sewers or water mains located on or immediately adjacent to the plat, the nearest of such sewers or water mains shall be indicated by their direction and distance from the plat with their invert elevations. 
(20)  Locations of all existing property boundary lines, streams and water courses, marshes, rock outcrops, wooded areas and other similar significant features within the tract being subdivided or immediately adjacent thereto. 
(21)  Location, width, and names of all proposed streets and public rights-of-way such as alleys and easements. 
(22)  Approximate dimensions of all lots together with the proposed lot and block numbers. 
(23)  Location and approximate area of any sites to be reserved or dedicated, and the conditions, if any, of such reservation or dedication, for parks, playgrounds, drainageways, or other public use, or which are to be used for group housing, shopping centers, church sites, or other nonpublic uses not requiring designation by lot number. 
(24)  Proposed building lines. 
(25)  Approximate radii of all curves and length of tangents. 
(26)  Existing zoning within and adjacent to the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1997, § 18.34; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-92. - Street plans and profiles. 
(a)  The city engineer may require that the subdivider provide street plans and profiles showing existing ground surface, proposed and established street grades, including extension for a reasonable distance beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision when requested. 
(b)  All elevations shall be based upon U.S.G.S. datum, and plans and profiles shall meet the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.35; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-93. - Testing. 
(a)  The city engineer may require that borings and soundings be made in specified areas to ascertain subsurface soil, rock and water conditions, including depth to bedrock and depth to ground water table. 
(b)  Where the subdivision will not be served by public sanitary sewer service, the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code ch. H65 shall be complied with; and the appropriate data submitted with the preliminary plat. 
(Code 1997, § 18.36; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-94. - Covenants. 
The plan commission may require submission of a draft of protective covenants whereby the subdivider intends to regulate land use in the proposed subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development. 
(Code 1997, § 18.37; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-95. - Affidavit by surveyor. 
The surveyor preparing the preliminary plat shall certify on the face of the plat that it is a correct representation of all existing land divisions and features, and that he has fully complied with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.38; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Secs. 44-9644-118. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FINAL PLAT 
 
Sec. 44-119. - General. 
A final plat prepared by a registered land surveyor, shall be required for all subdivisions. It shall comply in all respects with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.20, which section is incorporated in this chapter by reference and article II of this chapter. All elevations referred to in such section shall be referred to U.S.G.S. datum and bearings referenced to the Wisconsin state plane coordinate system. 
(Code 1997, § 18.39; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-120. - Additional information. 
The plat shall show correctly on its face, in addition to the information required by said Wis. Stats. § 236.20, the following: 
(1)  Exact length and bearing of the centerline of all streets. 
(2)  Railroad rights-of-way within and abutting the plat. 
(3)  Setbacks or building lines required by the plan commission. 
(4)  All lands reserved for future public acquisition or reserved for the common use of property owners within the plat. 
(5)  Special restrictions required by the plan commission relating to access control along public ways or to the provision of planting strips. 
(Code 1997, § 18.40; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-121. - Deed restrictions. 
The plan commission may require the deed restrictions be filed with the final plat. 
(Code 1997, § 18.41; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-122. - Surveying and monuments. 
All final plats shall meet all the surveying and monumenting requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.15. The city engineer shall examine all final plats and make field checks and generally review the plat, to determine whether the final plat meets all of the requirements of this chapter and the appropriate sections of the Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Code 1997, § 18.42; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-123. - Certificates. 
All final plats shall provide all of the certificates required by Wis. Stats. § 236.21; and in addition, the surveyor shall certify that he has fully complied with all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.43; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Secs. 44-12444-144. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CERTIFIED SURVEY MAP 
 
Sec. 44-145. - General. 
A certified survey map prepared by a registered land surveyor shall be required for all minor subdivisions. It shall comply in all respects with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.34, and article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.44; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. #646)  
Sec. 44-146. - Additional information. 
The certified survey map shall show correctly on its face, in addition to the information required by said Wis. Stats. § 236.34, the following: 
(1)  All existing buildings, water courses, drainage ditches and other features pertinent to proper division. 
(2)  Setbacks or building lines required by the plan commission. 
(3)  All lands reserved for future acquisition. 
(4)  Date of map, graphic scale, and names and addresses of the owner, subdivider, and surveyor. 
(5)  Bearings must be referenced to the Wisconsin state plane coordinate system. 
(Code 1997, § 18.45; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-147. - Certificates. 
(a)  The surveyor shall certify on the face of the certified survey map that he has fully complied with all of the provisions of this chapter and with the appropriate sections of the Wisconsin Statutes. 
(b)  After a recommendation by the city engineer and other reviewing agencies, the common council shall certify its approval on the face of the map. 
(c)  Dedication of streets and other public areas shall require the owner's certificate and the mortgagee's certificate in substantially the form as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.21(2)(a). 
(Code 1997, § 18.46; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-148. - Recording. 
The certified survey map shall be recorded by the city clerk with the county register of deeds only after the certificates of the common council and the surveyor are placed on the face of the map. 
(Code 1997, § 18.47; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Secs. 44-14944-179. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 44-180. - Streets to be public. 
A public street shall be provided for convenient access to all property within the subdivision, and no private street or thoroughfare shall be permitted. 
(Code 1997, § 18.48; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-181. - Street and trail arrangements. 
(a)  In any new subdivision, the street layout and location of pedestrian, bicycle and equestrian trails shall conform to the arrangement, width and location indicated on the official map, comprehensive plan or comprehensive plan components of the city. The streets shall be developed and located in proper relation to: 
(1)  Existing and proposed streets. 
(2)  Topography. 
(3)  Natural features such as streams and tree growth. 
(4)  Public convenience and safety. 
(5)  Proposed use of the land to be served by such streets. 
(6)  The most advantageous development of adjoining areas. 
(b)  Arterial streets, as hereafter defined, shall provide: 
(1)  Ready access to centers of employment and governmental activity, community shopping areas, recreation, and points beyond the boundaries of the community. 
(2)  They shall be properly integrated with, and related to, the existing and proposed system of major streets and highways, and shall be, insofar as practicable, continuous and in alignment with existing or planned streets with which they are to connect. 
(c)  Collector streets, as hereafter defined, shall provide: 
(1)  Ready collection of traffic from residential areas and conveyance of this traffic to the major street and highway system. 
(2)  Shall be properly related to: 
a.  The mass transportation system. 
b.  Special traffic generators, such as schools, churches and shopping centers, and other concentrations of population. 
c.  The major streets into which they feed. 
(d)  Minor streets, as hereafter defined, shall be laid out to: 
(1)  Conform to topography. 
(2)  Discourage use by through traffic. 
(3)  Permit the design of efficient storm and sanitary sewage systems. 
(4)  Require the minimum street area necessary to provide safe and convenient access to abutting property. 
(e)  Optional minor streets, as hereafter defined, are intended to: 
(1)  Provide for a narrower pavement than the standard 27-foot minor street pavement width. 
(2)  This cross section shall be permitted only with plan commission approval and may be used only where one or more of the following specific site conditions exist: 
a.  Extensive tree coverage that can be preserved. 
b.  Difficult topography for construction of the standard minor street. 
c.  Residential density of one or more acres per dwelling unit. 
d.  Provision for sidewalk or other pedestrian walkway facilities within the subdivision. 
e.  Preservation of a historical building or structure. 
(f)  Proposed streets. 
(1)  Proposed streets shall extend to the boundary lines of the tract being subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. 
(2)  Where the new subdivision connects with an existing subdivision, which has cul-de-sac streets which will connect to the streets in the proposed subdivision, the developer will enter the existing subdivision, remove the cul-de-sac, regrade, seed the ditches and extend the existing street to connect with the proposed streets. The removal of the cul-de-sac and the extension of the existing street will conform to city street requirements. 
(g)  Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts for off-street loading and service access. 
(2)  The plan commission may waive this requirement where other provision for such loading and access shall be assured. 
(3)  Alleys shall not be approved in residential areas unless necessary because of topography or other exceptional circumstances. 
(4)  Dead-end alleys are prohibited. 
(5)  Alleys shall not connect to a major thoroughfare. 
(h)  Arterial street and highway protection. Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a major street or highway, adequate protection of residential properties, limitation of access, and separation of through and local traffic shall be provided by reversed frontage, with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line, or by the use of frontage streets. 
(i)  Reserve strips shall not be provided on any plat to control access to streets or alleys, except where control of such strips is placed with the city under conditions approved by the plan commission. 
(j)  Street names shall not duplicate or be similar to existing street names, and existing street names shall be protected wherever possible. 
(Code 1997, § 18.49; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-182. - Limited access highway and railroad right-of-way treatment. 
Whenever the proposed subdivision contains, or is adjacent to, a limited access highway or railroad right-of-way, the design shall provide the following treatment: 
(1)  When lots back upon the right-of-way of an existing or proposed limited access highway or railroad, a planting strip at least 30 feet in depth shall be provided adjacent to the highway or railroad, in addition to the normal lot depth. 
(2)  This strip shall be a part of the platted lot but shall have the following restriction lettered on the face of the plat: "This strip reserved for the planting of trees and shrubs, the building of structures hereon prohibited." 
(3)  Commercial and industrial districts shall have provided, on each side of the limited access highway or railroad, streets approximately parallel to, and at a suitable distance from, such highway or railroad but not less than 150 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 18.50; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-183. - Street design standards. 
The minimum right-of-way and pavement width of all proposed streets, alleys, and trails shall be as specified on the comprehensive plan, comprehensive plan component, official map or neighborhood development study, or if no width is specified therein, the minimum widths shall be determined by the public works committee and approved by the city council, as follows: 
Facility 	ROW 
Width 	Pavement 
Width 
Arterial boulevard streets 	120' 	(2)-22' 
Arterial streets 	90' 	48' 
Standard collector streets 	66' 	36' 
Rural collector streets 	66' 	27' 
Minor streets 	60' 	27' 
Optional minor streets 	60' 	24' 
Alleys 	25' 	20' 
Equestrian trails 	12' 	n.a. 
Combined pedestrian and bicycle trails 	20' 	10' 
Pedestrian ways 	10' 	5' 
 
(1)  Arterial boulevard streets shall have two 22-foot pavements separated by a 20-foot median strip, and a pavement consisting of five inches of compacted and watered three-quarter-inch crushed gravel and four inches of 1½-inch traffic bound crushed limestone base course and 4½ inches of bituminous concrete surface. 
(2)  Arterial streets shall have a pavement width of 48 feet and a pavement consisting of five inches of compacted and watered three-quarter-inch crushed gravel and four inches of 1½-inch traffic bound crushed limestone base course and 4½ inches of bituminous concrete surface. 
(3)  Standard collector streets shall have a pavement width of 36 feet and a pavement consisting of five inches of compacted and watered three-quarter-inch crushed gravel and four inches of 1½-inch traffic bound crushed limestone base course and four inches of bituminous concrete surface. In areas where the projected average daily traffic (ADT) is less than 3,500 vehicles per day and the projected vehicle trip rates in the peak hour are less than 600, the city may designate rural collector streets which may have a pavement width of 27 feet instead of 36 feet. 
In areas where the projected average daily traffic (ADT) is less than 3,500 vehicles per day and the projected vehicle trip rates in the peak hour are less than 600, the city may designate rural collector streets which may have a pavement width of 27 feet instead of 36 feet. 
(4)  Minor streets shall have a pavement width of 27 feet and a pavement consisting of five inches of compacted and watered three-quarter-inch crushed gravel and four inches of 1½-inch traffic bound crushed limestone base course and four inches of bituminous concrete surface. 
(5)  Optional minor streets shall have a pavement width of 24 feet and a pavement consisting of five inches of compacted and watered three-quarter-inch crushed gravel and four inches of 1½-inch traffic bound crushed limestone base course and four inches of bituminous concrete surface. 
(6)  Cul-de-sacs shall meet all of the requirements for a minor street and shall terminate in a circular turn-around having a minimum right-of-way diameter of 120 feet. 
a.  A circle with a minimum diameter of 80 feet shall be paved. 
b.  When it is desired to leave a planting area in the center of the cul-de-sac, a minimum right-of-way diameter of 150 feet, and a minimum pavement width of 18 feet with a minimum centerline diameter of 90 feet shall be provided. 
c.  A cul-de-sac must be provided for any street designed to have one end permanently closed. Such street shall not exceed 400 feet in length. Any such street in excess of 400 feet shall require plan commission approval. 
(7)  Alleys provided to serve business, commercial, or industrial uses shall be constructed in accordance with the specifications for collector streets, provided that the surface shall be 20 feet. 
(8)  Equestrian trails. The surface shall be of such construction as may be approved by the city engineer. 
(9)  Combined bicycle and pedestrian paths shall have a minimum eight-foot pavement width, except where state or federal funding requires a higher standard. 
(10)  Pedestrian ways shall have a minimum pavement width of five feet. 
(11)  Minimum radius of 20 feet must be provided at all points where edges of various pavements as described above join and meet other newly constructed or existing pavements, including all intersections and points where cul-de-sac turn-around circles meet the entrance pavement. 
(12)  Bituminous construction standard. The bituminous concrete surface material described as a part of each pavement type shall be constructed in two lifts: 
a.  The first or binder course lift shall consist of 2½ inches of binder course. The city engineer shall provide asphalt specifications. 
b.  The second or surface lift shall consist of 1½ inches of surface course and installed no sooner than eight months following installation of the binder course and no later than October 1 of the year following installation of the binder course, or as specified in the developer's agreement. 
c.  The surface course shall be installed only after the binder course is thoroughly cleaned and swept, and a tack coat for bonding purposes applied. 
d.  Prior to installation of the surface course, the binder course shall be inspected by the city engineer and any distressed areas noted by the engineer shall be repaired in accordance with City of Delafield specifications. 
(13)  Typical street cross sections. Typical street cross sections on the pages A through F attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived shall govern the construction of the subdivision streets and trails under this chapter. 
(Code 1997, § 18.51; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #562; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-184. - Street grades. 
(a)  Unless necessitated by exceptional topography, and always subject to the approval of the plan commission, the maximum centerline grade of any street or public way shall not exceed the following: 
(1)  Arterial and collector streets: six percent. 
(2)  All other streets, alleys and pedestrian ways: eight percent. 
(3)  In no event shall the grade of any street, alley or pedestrian way be less than one-half of one percent. 
(b)  Street, alley and pedestrian way grades shall be established wherever practicable so as to avoid excessive grading, promiscuous removal of ground cover and tree growth and general leveling of the topography. 
(Code 1997, § 18.52; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-185. - Horizontal curves. 
A minimum sight distance with clear visibility, measured along the centerline, shall be provided of at least 300 feet on arterial streets, 200 feet on collector streets, and 120 feet on all other streets. 
(Code 1997, § 18.53; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-186. - Vertical curves. 
All changes in street grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to 30 times the algebraic difference in the rate of grade for arterial and collector streets, and 20 times this minimum for all other streets. 
(Code 1997, § 18.54; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-187. - Tangents. 
A tangent of at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
(Code 1997, § 18.55; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-188. - Half-streets. 
(a)  Where an existing dedicated or platted half-street is adjacent to the tract being subdivided, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider. 
(b)  The platting of half-streets shall be avoided where possible. 
(Code 1997, § 18.56; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-189. - Street intersections. 
(a)  Streets shall intersect each other at as nearly right angles as topography and other limiting factors of good design permit. 
(b)  Number of streets converging at one intersection shall be reduced to a minimum, preferably not more than two. 
(c)  Number of intersections along major streets and highways shall be held to a minimum and, wherever practicable, the distance between such intersections shall not be less than 1,200 feet. 
(d)  Property lines at street intersections when required by the plan commission shall be rounded with a minimum radius of 30 feet or of a greater radius when required by the plan commission. 
(e)  Minor streets need not necessarily continue across arterial or collector streets, but if the centerline of such minor streets approach the major streets from opposite sides within 125 feet of each other, measured along the centerline of the arterial or collector street, the location shall be so adjusted that the alignment across the major or collector street is continuous. 
(Code 1997, § 18.57; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-190. - Blocks. 
(a)  The widths, lengths and shapes of blocks shall be suited to the planned use of the land and the type of development contemplated, but the length of any block in residential areas shall not exceed 1,500 feet, nor have less than sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots of appropriate depth between street lines. 
(b)  Pedestrian ways may be required by the plan commission near the center and entirely across any block over 900 feet in length to provide adequate pedestrian circulation or access to schools, shopping centers, churches, transportation or other community facilities. 
(c)  Lots or parcels reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial use shall have a width and length adequate to provide for off-street service and parking required by the use contemplated and the area zoning restrictions for such use. 
(Code 1997, § 18.58; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-191. - Lots. 
(a)  The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. The lots shall be designed to provide an appropriate building site and a proper architectural setting for the buildings contemplated. Proposed building elevations for each site shall be submitted with street cross-sections, drainage, erosion control and grading plans. 
(b)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines on which the lots face. 
(c)  Lot lines shall follow municipal boundary lines wherever possible, rather than cross them. 
(d)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be prohibited except where necessary to provide separation of residential developments from through traffic or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
(e)  Access. Every lot shall front or abut for a distance of at least 30 feet on a public street. Lots with an access only to existing private drives or streets shall be permitted only with the approval of the plan commission, and only when permitted by the zoning code. The 30-foot limitation set forth above shall not apply to flag lots. Flag lots shall have frontage on a public street not less than the lot width requirement for the zoning district in which the lot is located. 
(f)  Lots at right angles to each other shall be avoided whenever possible, particularly in residential areas. 
(g)  Flag lots shall be avoided whenever possible, particularly in residential areas. Flag lots shall be prohibited unless the staff of the flag lot has street frontage not less than the lot width required in the zoning district in which the lot is located. 
(h)  Area and dimensions of lots shall conform to the requirements of the zoning code. 
(1)  Excessive depth in relation to width shall be avoided, and a proportion of 2½ to one shall normally be considered as a desirable maximum for lot widths of 100 feet or more. 
(2)  Where a lot has a narrow strip of land as part of the lot (not as an approved easement), extending from the public road to the main part of the lot where the principal structure could lawfully be placed (flag lot), such a narrow portion (staff of the flag lot) shall not constitute frontage unless the narrow portion is as wide as the required lot width for the district in which such lot is located, unless otherwise approved by the plan commission. 
(i)  Subdivision into large parcels. Whenever a tract is subdivided into large parcels, such parcels shall be arranged and dimensioned as to allow resubdivision of any such parcels into normal lots in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
