(j)  Depth of lots or parcels reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial use shall be adequate to provide for off-street service and parking required by the use contemplated, and by the area zoning restrictions for such use. 
(k)  Corner lots for residential use shall have increased minimum corner side yard setback as required by applicable provisions of the zoning code. 
(l)  Lands lying between the meander line and the water's edge and any otherwise unplattable lands which lie between a proposed subdivision and the water's edge shall be included as part of lots, outlots, or public dedications in any plat abutting a stream or lake. All lands under option to the subdivider or to which he holds any interest that abut the proposed subdivision and a stream, lake, flowage or wetland shall also be included. 
(m)  Water level. In determining the minimum lot areas under this code, 90 percent of the minimum lot area shall be at least two feet and 80 percent of the minimum lot area shall be at least three feet above the elevation of the 100-year floodplain boundary. 
(Code 1997, § 18.59; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-192. - Building setback lines. 
All building setback lines shall be controlled by the zoning code. 
(Code 1997, § 18.60; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-193. - Easements. 
(a)  Utility easements shall be provided at the rear of all lot lines and on side lot lines or cross lots, where necessary or advisable. Such utility easements shall be at least ten feet wide, and evidence shall be furnished the common council that easements to be incorporated on the plat or in deeds have been reviewed by the individual utility companies or the organization responsible for furnishing the service involved. 
(b)  Drainage easements. 
(1)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, an adequate drainageway or easement shall be provided as may be required by the plan commission. The location, width, alignment and improvement of such drainageway or easement shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(2)  Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection with such drainageway or easement. 
(3)  The watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream may be relocated so that adequate drainage will be assured. 
(4)  Wherever possible, it is desirable that the drainage be maintained by an open channel with landscaped banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume of flow. 
(5)  In all cases such watercourse shall be of a minimum width of the established two-foot high water mark, or in the absence of such specification, not less than 30 feet. 
(Code 1997, § 18.61; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-194. - Waterway openings. 
(a)  Waterway openings of all new bridges and culverts carrying arterial streets over perennial streams shall be adequate to accommodate the 50-year recurrence interval flood flow with the upstream high water elevation not to exceed a level of two feet below the roadway elevation and the hydraulic head loss through the structure not to exceed 0.01 feet. 
(b)  Waterway openings of all new bridges and culverts carrying minor streets over perennial streams shall be adequate to accommodate the ten-year recurrence interval flood flow with the upstream headwater elevation not to exceed a level of two feet below the roadway elevation and the hydraulic head loss through the structure not to exceed 0.01 feet. 
(c)  The combination of the waterway opening and the approach road elevations on the floodlands shall not increase the flood stages more than 0.01 feet upon the occurrence of the 100-year recurrence interval flood. 
(d)  Such bridges and culverts shall be so designed and constructed as to facilitate the passage of ice floes and other debris. 
(e)  Any stream designed as navigable shall meet all applicable federal, state and county requirements and regulations. 
(Code 1997, § 18.62; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-195. - Public sites and open spaces. 
(a)  In the design of the plat, proper consideration shall be given to the reservation of suitable sites of adequate area for future schools, parks, playgrounds, drainageways and other public purposes. 
(b)  If such sites are not designated on the comprehensive plan as referred to in section 44-15, consideration shall be given in the location of such sites to the preservation of scenic and historic sites, stands of fine trees, marshes, lakes and ponds, watercourses, watersheds and ravines. 
(Code 1997, § 18.63; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #620)  
Sec. 44-196. - Acceptance of dedications and improvements. 
(a)  The approval of the final plat by the mayor and common council shall constitute acceptance of the dedication of the right-of-way for any public street, open space or other public area, but the developer shall remain liable for any accidents on any such street, open space or other public area, prior to the time of final acceptance by the city of the street improvement. 
(b)  The acceptance of the improvements constructed shall be deemed to be made after successful completion of the guaranteed period covered by the guaranty bond, and by formal resolution of the mayor and common council. 
(c)  The normal operating cost of the operation of such improvement shall be assumed by the city when put in operation and pending the final acceptance thereof. 
(Code 1997, § 18.64; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Secs. 44-19744-215. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 44-216. - Survey monuments. 
The subdivider or developer shall install survey monuments placed in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 236.15, and as may be required by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.65; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-217. - Procedure. 
(a)  After filing the preliminary plat, or sooner if the subdivider or developer prefers, two copies of construction plans and specifications, prepared by a professional engineer registered in Wisconsin, shall be furnished for the following improvements where such improvements are required by this chapter, or are to be installed voluntarily by the developer: 
(1)  Streets and sidewalks. 
(2)  Sanitary sewage system. 
(3)  Storm drainage and storm sewers. 
(4)  Water supply and distribution. 
(5)  Public utility installations. 
(6)  Street lights, street signs, street trees, and the like. 
(7)  Additional special plans or information as required by the plan commission and public works committee. 
(b)  The city engineer shall review, or cause to be reviewed, the construction plans and specifications for conformity with all applicable requirements, and shall approve, conditionally approve, or reject in writing the proposed improvements before such improvements are commenced. 
(c)  Upon such decision and recommendation by the city engineer, the common council shall within 90 days after such recommendation grant approval, conditionally approve, or reject the proposed improvements, and the subdivider or developer shall be notified in writing of the approval, any conditions imposed, or the reason for rejection. 
(Code 1997, § 18.66; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-218. - Construction and inspection. 
(a)  Construction of each phase shall not commence without 24-hour notice to the city engineer. This approval shall be conditioned upon the receipt of all necessary permits and the compliance with all construction methods, specifications and design, as required by this article. 
(b)  All construction of improvements required of the subdivider or developer must be completed within two years of the date of the approval of the preliminary plat by the plan commission, unless good cause can be shown for granting of an extension of time by both the mayor and the common council. 
(c)  Inspections shall be made at the start and during the course of construction as the city engineer deem necessary in order to ensure compliance with the plans and specifications as approved. 
(d)  The final plat shall not be approved, or sureties or money deposits released, until final inspection and approval by the city engineer of all completed work. 
(Code 1997, § 18.67; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. #562)  
Sec. 44-219. - Grading. 
After the installation of temporary block corner monuments by the subdivider or developer, and the establishment of street grades by the city public works committee, the subdivider shall grade the full width of the right-of-way of all streets and alleys proposed to be dedicated, in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. The subdivider or developer shall grade the roadbeds in the street rights-of-way to subgrade. 
(Code 1997, § 18.68)  
Sec. 44-220. - Surfacing. 
(a)  After the installation of all underground improvements as may be required, the subdivider shall surface all roadways in streets and alleys in accordance with the provisions set forth in article VI of this chapter, and in accordance with any other applicable rule, regulation, design or specification of this or any other ordinance. Any construction in existing surfaced roadways will require slurry backfill. 
(b)  No street pavement construction shall commence until after the backfill has settled where any underground installations have been made in the roadway. The settlement may be accomplished by either mechanical compaction, or by the combination of mechanical compaction and jetting, or by using granular backfill. 
(Code 1997, § 18.69; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720. )  
Sec. 44-221. - Curb and gutter. 
(a)  After the installation of all underground improvements, the subdivider or developer shall construct concrete curbs and gutters if recommended by the public works committee and plan commission in accordance with plans and standard specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  Where curb and gutter installation is not required and is waived by the city council, the subdivider or developer shall finish grade all shoulders and road ditches, install all necessary culverts at intersections and, if required, surface ditch inverts to prevent erosion and sedimentation in accordance with plans and standard specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.70; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-222. - Sidewalks. 
Where required by the plan commission, the subdivider or developer shall construct a sidewalk on one side of all frontage streets and both sides of all other streets within the subdivision and the construction of all sidewalks shall be in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.71; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-223. - Sanitary sewers and sewer design. 
(a)  If public sewer facilities are not available, the plan commission may require that the subdivider or developer make provisions for an adequate private sewage disposal system, which shall be constructed according to all applicable laws, rules and regulations and shall be made available to all lots in the subdivision. 
(b)  If public sewer facilities are available or the city engineer shall certify that they will, within reasonable probability, be available within five years from the date of filing the application for preliminary plat approval, the subdivider or developer shall install sanitary sewers and laterals to the street lot line and shall cap and mark all laterals in the manner specified herein. In all of the events covered by this subsection, the following specifications for sanitary sewers shall be applicable: 
(1)  Sanitary sewers shall be constructed and installed in accordance with the Standard Specifications for Sewer and Water Construction in Wisconsin, latest edition, hereinafter referred to as "Standard Specifications" and in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 110. 
(2)  Manholes shall be as specified in "Standard Specifications," except that brick manholes shall not be allowed. 
(3)  Manhole frames shall be Neenah R1660 or equal. Covers shall have machined bearing surfaces and a nonrocking lid with concealed pick holes and no vent holes. Gasketed covers may be required in certain areas at the direction of the city engineer. 
(4)  Sanitary sewers shall be located in the center of the street right-of-way, unless otherwise approved by the city engineer. 
(5)  Sanitary sewer laterals shall be installed to the lot line or street right-of-way line. The ends of the sanitary laterals at the right-of-way or lot lines shall be properly marked with a six feet long by two inches by six inches plank, a six-foot-long by one-inch diameter steel reinforcing rod or some other method approved by the city engineer. Four-inch or six-inch sanitary sewer laterals may be installed. The materials and construction shall conform to "Standard Specifications" and Wis. Admin. Code ch. H62. 
(6)  If larger diameter sanitary sewers are required to service areas outside the proposed development, the cost of such oversizing shall be prorated in proportion to the ratio which the total area of the proposed development is to the total service area to be served by such larger sewer and the excess cost shall be borne either by the city or assessed against the total tributary service area, excluding the proposed development. (Public sanitary sewers shall be a minimum of eight-inch diameter, per state code.) 
(7)  When small diameter pressure systems are required to provide service, the developer shall provide adequate plans and specifications for the proposed system and equipment to the city engineer for approval. This shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Plans and specifications of piping system showing proposed locations and elevations of the pumping units and discharge points. 
b.  Operation and maintenance manuals, including: 
1.  Manufacturer's name and performance data of the proposed pumping units. 
2.  Information on availability of repair parts and maintenance service for the proposed pumping units. 
(c)  The systems shall be designed for outdoor installation of the pumps. All alarms and controls associated with the pumping units shall be mounted in close proximity to the units and be readily accessible to maintenance personnel. 
(d)  The complete pumping unit, including motor, must be designed to operate in a submerged condition. The units shall be capable of reducing all solids normally found in sewage and then pumping the resulting slurry through the pressure service pipe to the pressure or gravity sewer system. 
(e)  All curb stops on a pressure line shall have curb stop extension rods in place a minimum of 18 inches from the top of the cover. The stationary rod shall be pinned onto the operating end of the curb stop. 
(f)  All new sanitary sewers, shall be cleaned and videotaped, with true copy of tape given to city, prior to final acceptance. 
(Code 1997, § 18.72; Rep. & Recr. #441; Cr. #515)  
Sec. 44-224. - Stormwater drainage facilities. 
(a)  Stormwater sewering or surface drainage systems shall be provided adequately serve the area being platted, considering, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The design of the drainage system shall consider and show the following: 
a.  Storm drainage area of which the subdivision is a part. 
b.  Detailed calculations as to volume of stormwater generated and method of storage and conveyance. 
c.  A stormwater system sufficient in size to eliminate flooding or ponding of water, consisting of culverts, ditches, storm sewers, retention basins, etc. 
(2)  Where storm sewers can practically be installed and where the city engineer concludes that storm sewers will be necessary to control erosion or ponding, such storm sewers shall be designed in accordance with the following minimum specifications: 
a.  General. All stormwater detention facilities shall be designed to restrict post-development flow rates to meet the following multiple storm conditions: A ten-year post-development conditions flow rate to discharge at no more than a two-year pre-developed flow rate. A 100-year post-developed conditions flow rate to discharge at no more than a ten-year pre-developed flow rate. 
All stormwater detention basins will be required to serve as temporary sedimentation facilities during the construction phase of the development. The sediment basin shall be designed per the "State of Wisconsin Construction Site Best Management Practice Handbook" to include a minimum of two feet of sediment storage below the dewatering hole(s) and a riser pipe(s) with trash guard(s). All riser pipes and initial stone layer shall be wrapped with filter fabric and protected with six inches of clean stone rip-rap. At the end of construction when the area has been fully restored, the riser pipe(s) shall be removed and the sedimentation storage area filled and restored to the detention basin final grades. 
1.  Dry detention basins. All dry detention basins shall be designed with maximum 4:1 sideslopes. All basins require emergency overflow spillways that can accommodate the 100-year developed conditions storm. The spillway shall be set at an elevation that provides a minimum of one foot of freeboard above the peak state elevation of the 100-year post-developed conditions storm. 
2.  Wet detention basins. All wet detention basins shall be designed with a maximum 4:1 sideslope leading to the water's edge. The wet basin shall then include a safety shelf at a maximum 10:1 slope, for a minimum of six feet in width. The wet basin may then drop at a maximum 3:1 sideslope until a maximum normal water depth of eight feet. All wet detention basins must include an emergency spillway, as outlined above. 
b.  Storm sewers shall be designed in such way as to insure a minimum velocity of flow of two feet per second. 
c.  Manholes shall be provided at all changes in direction of pipe and pipe size and shall be of the type specified in "Standard Specifications" or the standard specifications of the city. Inlets shall be located not more than 500 feet apart and shall be the type specified in "Standard Specifications" or the standard specifications of the city. 
d.  All new storm sewers shall be cleaned and videotaped, with true copy of tape given to the city, prior to final acceptance. 
(3)  Where ditches are utilized for storm drainage, they shall meet the following minimum standards: 
a.  Culverts at all street or driveway intersections, sized to eliminate flooding or ponding of water. 
b.  Driveway culverts shall be arch pipe no less than 15 inches in diameter equivalent with metal flared end sections. 
(b)  All storm drainage facilities shall be so designed as to present no hazard to life or property and shall be designed with due consideration to aesthetic values. 
(c)  If storm sewers of greater than 36-inch diameter are required to handle the contemplated flows, the cost of such larger sewers shall be prorated in proportion to the ratio which the total area of the proposed plat is to the total drainage area to be served by such larger sewer and the excess cost shall be borne either by the city or assessed against the total tributary drainage area. 
(d)  All work must be in compliance with section 42-13 relating to erosion control. 
(Code 1997, § 18.73; Rep. & Recr. #441; Cr. #515; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-225. - Water supply and water distribution. 
(a)  Water supply. 
(1)  Water supply and water distribution systems shall be designed to furnish water in the quantity required by the State of Wisconsin requirements for domestic water supply, and also in accordance with the National Board of Underwriters for fire demand. 
(2)  Sufficient storage shall be designed and constructed to provide a reserve supply in accordance with the requirements of the State of Wisconsin and National Board of Underwriters. 
(3)  The city shall have the right to furnish water meters of the design specified by the city engineer. 
(4)  If the city operates or supervises the operation of any water supply system, it shall have the right to make an appropriate service charge therefore, and the right to make such charge shall be stated both in the recorded plat and in all deeds to property embraced in such plat. 
(b)  Water distribution. 
(1)  All work shall be done in accordance with the provisions Standard Specifications for Sewer and Water Construction in Wisconsin, latest edition, and State of Wisconsin department of transportation division of highways and transportation services, Standard Specifications for Highway and Structure Construction, latest edition, including all supplemental specifications and other revisions to date, unless otherwise specified herein or on the plans. Both documents are referred to herein as Standard Specifications. 
(2)  No public water main shall be installed of less than eight inches in diameter, but if greater than such diameter water mains are required, the excess cost of such mains over and above the cost of an eight-inch main shall be borne by the subdivider or developer. 
(3)  Water mains shall be Class 52 Ductile Iron conforming to AWWA C151, cement lined in accordance with AWWA C104 with polyethylene wrap. Class 150 PVC pressure pipe per AWWA C900 may be used subject to city approval. 
(4)  Fittings shall be ductile iron conforming to the requirements of AWWA C110. All fittings should have a minimum working pressure rating of 250 psi. 
(5)  Fire hydrants, with auxiliary valves, shall be provided in accordance with the recommendations of the National Board of Underwriters, but in no case shall the spacing of said fire hydrants be greater than 500 feet. Fire hydrants shall be AWWA traffic-type with breakoff couplings Waterous-Pacer WB67 with six-inch inlet and 5¼-inch valve opening, one 4½-inch pumper nozzle and two 2½-inch hose nozzles. All hydrants shall have a red barrel and bonnet with white caps. The paint shall be reflective type paint. A fiberglass marker wand, approved by the city, shall be installed on the breakaway flange of each hydrant. 
(6)  Fire hydrants shall be vandal-proofed. A vandal-proof device shall be installed on all fire hydrants by the City of Delafield water department. The cost of installation of the vandal-proof device, including parts and labor, shall be billed to the developer. The vandal-proof device shall be approved by the City of Delafield fire chief and the City of Delafield water department. The device shall be attached to the fire hydrant housing or opening mechanism per manufacturer's specifications. All materials used shall be strong enough to withstand acts of vandalism and weather extremes and still provide smooth hydrant operation. An inner-barrel construction of high tensile manganese bronze shall be designed to fit over the fire hydrant operating nut. An outer housing constructed of stainless steel shall be installed over the inner barrel so as to swivel freely until a special key wrench is used. Attachment of the outer housing shall be by a special snap ring groove designed to withstand repeated blows by sledge hammers without shearing. A mating collar shall be installed between the outer housing hydrant top for a weather seal and to prevent removal of the swivel housing. The mating collar shall extend up the sides of the swivel housing to a height sufficient to provide added protection for the hydrant operating nut and to resist repeated blows by sledge hammers. A special key wrench shall be constructed of an aluminum magnesium alloy with handles extending from both sides for easy operation. The wrench shall incorporate a unique permanent magnet which will engage an activator located inside the outer housing. The special key wrench will be the only means of opening or closing the hydrant. The opposite side of the key wrench shall contain a conventional pentagon recess that will work on standard hydrants. Performance of the vandal-proof system must not be affected by local environmental temperature ranges or weather conditions. 
(7)  Valves shall be provided in such locations to allow the shutting down of not more than 1,000-foot linear pipe. Gate valves shall conform to AWWA C500. Valves eight inches and smaller shall have a Clow 3-piece valve Box F-2450 complete with F-2494 cover. Valves 12 inches and larger require a five-foot diameter manhole complete with Neenah cover R-1900-D lettered "Water." Any substitution of an approved equal will require city approval. 
(8)  Water service lines to be extended to lot line and to be one-inch diameter minimum continuous, from main to lot line, Type K, ASTM B88. Corporation stops to be Mueller H-1500 for three-quarter-inch to 1¼-inch lines and Ford FB-600 for 1½-inch to two-inch lines. Curb stops to be Mueller H-15154. Curb boxes to be Mueller H-10302. Curb stops shall have a stationary rod in place which is a minimum of 18 inches from the top cover. The stationary rod shall be pinned onto the operating end of the curb stop. Valve boxes shall have a valve box extension stem in place which is a minimum of 18 inches from the top of the cover. The valve box extension stem shall be fastened to the operating end of the valve equals subject to approval by city. 
(9)  All water mains shall be installed with a blue, three-inch-wide warning tape located over the main and 12-inches below finished grade. Said tape shall read "Caution - Water Line Buried Below." 
(10)  All water main and facilities shall be installed with a detector wire consisting of an insulated AWS #12 copper wire taped to the main. In addition: 
a.  Wrap four feet of extra wire around beginning and end of main; 
b.  Wrap each valve, including hydrant valves to below operating nut flange; and 
c.  Wrap each valve box to within two inches of top ending in a loop. 
A satisfactory conductivity test shall be performed prior to acceptance of system. 
(c)  Miscellaneous. Where a water supply system is not available, or is not required under the terms of this chapter, individual sources of water supply shall be permitted, provided that all requirements of the city and the State of Wisconsin are fully complied with, but in all such cases restrictions shall be filed with the final plat and incorporated in each deed to parcels in the subdivision, which shall provide that each private owner of such parcel shall bear his fair proportionate share of the cost of any future public water main as determined by agreement or special assessment proceeding, or other means authorized by law to finance construction of water systems. 
(Code 1997, § 18.74; Rep. & Recr. #441; Cr. #457; Am. #505; Am. #515)  
Sec. 44-226. - Other utilities. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall cause gas, electric, and telephone facilities to be installed in such manner as to make adequate service available to each lot in the subdivision. 
(b)  All electric and telephone cables shall be buried underground in accordance with the specifications of the state electrical code, and this shall include feeder cables and individual service connections. 
(c)  Plans indicating the proposed location of all gas, electric and telephone distribution and transmission lines required to service the plat shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.75; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-227. - Street lamps. 
(a)  If requested by the public works committee and required by council, the subdivider or developer shall install or cause to be installed street lamps along all streets proposed to be dedicated, of a design compatible with neighborhood and the type of development proposed, such design to be approved by the plan commission. 
(b)  Such lamps shall be placed or caused to be placed at each street intersection and at such interior block spacing as may be required by the public works committee. 
(Code 1997, § 18.76; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-228. - Street signs. 
The department of public works shall install a street sign of a design approved by the plan commission at the intersection of all streets proposed to be dedicated, and such signs shall, where possible, conform to the design of signs elsewhere in the city. Costs shall be paid by the developer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.77; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-229. - Guard rails. 
Guard rails shall be placed along the shoulder of any street where street construction has resulted in an embankment higher than six inches measured vertically. 
(Code 1997, § 18.78; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-230. - Street trees, sodding clean-up, and the like. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall pay to the city the sum of $100.00 per lot of the proposed subdivision to be used for tree plantings or planting screens in the city. (See subsection (b) of this section for definition of planting screens.) Payment under this subsection shall be made prior to final plat approval. 
(b)  Planting screens. In some circumstances the plan commission may require a planting screen "buffer" between conflicting or contrasting land uses, and/or to provide visual and sound screening along highways and major roads. Such planting shall be placed within a designated planting easement of adequate width, and shall conform to plans required as part of the preliminary plat submittal, and in accuracy and detail sufficient for review by the plan commission. The following general guidelines shall apply: 
(1)  Planting screens shall consist of compatible naturalistic groupings of hardy native plant material. 
(2)  A diverse mixture of deciduous and evergreen tree and shrub varieties shall be used. 
(3)  Monotonous straight-row plantings of identical or similar material will not be accepted. 
(4)  Sizes shall be adequate for reasonable immediate effect. 
(5)  Short-lived, softwood tree varieties are not acceptable, i.e., silver maple, Lombardy poplar, box elder, Chinese elm. 
(c)  Wherever possible, existing trees shall be preserved in the installation of subdivision improvements. All street right-of-way which is not paved shall be seeded or sodded. Provisions shall be made to assure the growth of all landscaping. 
(d)  All stripped areas shall be seeded, and all destroyed trees, brush, debris and rubbish removed. All cut and filled sections throughout the subdivision are to be developed, and returfed in a manner satisfactory to the city engineer. 
(1)  Developer shall comply with requirements of chapter 52 of this Code relating to erosion control. 
(2)  Bond requirements for other improvements in the subdivision shall apply to this section. 
(Code 1997, § 18.79; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-231. - Erosion controls. 
Erosion controls approved by the city engineer must be in place, inspected, and approved prior to issuance of any building permits or granting a permit for preliminary grading or site preparation. 
(Code 1997, § 18.80; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-232. - Fire protection water supply. 
In areas not served by a municipal water supply and distribution system, subdividers or developers shall provide on-site storage tanks of sufficient size to provide an adequate supply of water for the purpose of controlling fires. The size of the on-site water storage tank shall be determined by the fire chief based on the guidelines of the State of Wisconsin and the National Fire Protection Association. 
Where in the opinion of the plan commission, the fire protection needs of the subdivision can be better met by use of a tanker vehicle, the subdivider or developer may be allowed to pay a fee equivalent to the cost of an installed on-site water storage tank to the city in lieu of providing on-site water storage. Any funds received by the city under the provision of this section shall be used exclusively for the purchase and maintenance of a water tanker vehicle. 
(Code 1997, § 18.81; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-233. - Final construction plans. 
Final construction plans shall be prepared on 22-inch by 36-inch paper or Mylar film, and shall contain at least the following information in the following order: 
(1)  Title page. 
(2)  Plat of subdivision. 
(3)  General layout drawings of the proposed streets. 
(4)  General layout drawings of the proposed water system, if any. 
(5)  General layout drawings of the proposed sanitary sewers, if any. 
(6)  General layout drawings of the proposed storm drainage. 
(7)  Plans and profiles of streets and sewers, with a scale of not less than one inch to 50 feet horizontal, and one inch to five feet vertical. 
(8)  Details of structures and other improvements required to be installed in the subdivision. 
(Code 1997, § 18.82; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-234. - Material standardsGeneral. 
(a)  All construction of improvements covered by this chapter, shall be in accordance with, and materials used shall be in compliance with, the methods and materials required in the appropriate sections of "Standard Specifications" as amended, published by the division of highways, State of Wisconsin. 
(b)  The following construction materials shall conform to the public works industry improvement program minimum indicated: 
(1)  Standard strength clay sewer pipe: ASTM C-13-50T, as revised. 
(2)  Extra strength clay pipe: ASTM C-200-50T, as revised. 
(3)  Concrete sewer pipe: ASTM C-76, ASTM C-14. 
(4)  Corrugated metal pipe: AASHTO Designation M36. 
(5)  Concrete masonry: ASTM C-139, as revised. 
(6)  Building brick: ASTM C-62 grade SW, as revised. 
(7)  Concrete building brick: ASTM C-55 grade A, as revised. 
(8)  Cast iron water pipe: ASTM Class 150. 
(9)  Cast iron sewer pipe: ASTM Class 100. 
(10)  Frames and grates: city standards. 
(11)  PVC: ASTM D-3034 and F-679. 
(12)  Other materials: city standards and other materials as detailed in "Standard Specifications" and/or approved by the city. 
(Code 1997, § 18.83; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-235. - Material standardsAsphalt pavements. 
(a)  Asphalt roadway surface. The developer and contractor shall install a minimum of four inches of hot mix asphalt (HMA) in two lifts, with compaction per the latest version of the Wisconsin department of transportation standard specifications for highway and structure construction. Tack coat will be installed between lifts of asphalt. The city engineer may require a thicker asphalt section for collector or nonresidential applications. Traffic controls and barricades must be installed and maintained per the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). The city will require submittal of asphalt mix designs prior to paving. The city engineer will require the contractor to submit load tickets for asphalt yield computations and submit nuclear density test results for asphalt density verification. 
(b)  Slopes and ditches; planting; grass cover. Side slopes and ditches along roads or in easements shall be covered with topsoil, prepared seeded or sodded, fertilized and maintained for a sufficient period to provide adequate grass cover prior to acceptance by the city council. The city may require erosion control matting or turf reinforcement matting to stabilize slopes as necessary. The developer's engineer shall provide the seed mix for approval. 
(c)  Signs; posts and guardrails. Street signs, roadway striping, culvert posts, and guardrails, as required by the city council, shall be obtained and placed by the city, the cost of which shall be paid by the developer or owner. 
(d)  Acceptance by the city. Roads will not be accepted by the city before May 1 or after November 1. Acceptance of the roads does not relieve the developer of responsibility relative to adequate grass cover on the side slopes or in ditches. 
(Code 1997, § 18.84; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-236. - Completion of improvements. 
All of the improvements required under this chapter shall be constructed in accordance with the applicable provisions of this chapter and with all other standards, rules and regulations which are now or may hereafter be adopted by the city council. All improvements shall be completed prior to the final approval of the plat by the city council, except that in lieu of the completion of construction, a certified check, surety bond or letter of credit approved by the city attorney may be furnished as provided in section 44-16. 
(Code 1997, § 18.85; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-237. - Guarantee of material and workmanship. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall provide a guarantee bond running to the city in the amount of 20 percent of the cost of improvements, either actual or estimated, such bond to be for a period of one year after final completion of construction. 
(b)  The city engineer shall certify to the city council the correctness of the amount of the bond and the date for final completion of all work guaranteed by such bond. 
(Code 1997, § 18.86; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-238. - "As built" plans. 
(a)  After completion of all public improvements and prior to final acceptance of such improvements, the subdivider or developer shall make or cause to be made a map showing the actual location of all valves, manholes, tubs, sewer and water mains and such other facilities as the engineer shall require. 
(b)  This map shall be in black ink and shall bear the signature and seal of a professional engineer registered in Wisconsin. Additionally the same shall be submitted to the city clerk-treasurer digital (i.e. PDF) format. 
(c)  The presentation of this map shall be a condition of final acceptance of the improvements and release of the surety bond assuring their completion. 
(Code 1997, § 18.87; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720 )  
Secs. 44-23944-269. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - FEES 
 
Sec. 44-270. - General. 
The subdivider or developer shall pay the city all fees as hereinafter required and at the times specified. The city shall be under no obligation to process any part or portion of any application for subdivision unless and until the appropriate fees as herein provided shall have been paid. 
(Code 1997, § 18.90; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-271. - Preliminary plat review fee. 
(a)  At the time of first application for approval of any preliminary plat and in order to assist in defraying the cost of review, the subdivider shall pay a fee according to the following schedule, which fee shall be paid to the city treasurer: 
Up to and including 20 acres 	$250.00 
Over 20 acres 	$250.00 plus 
$2.00 per acre 
 
(b)  A reapplication fee amounting to $15.00 shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time of a reapplication for approval of any preliminary plat which has previously been reviewed. 
(Code 1997, § 18.91; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rep. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-272. - Improvement review fee. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall pay a fee equal to one percent of the cost of the required public improvements as estimated by the city engineer at the time of submission of improvement plans and specifications, partially to cover the cost to the city of checking and reviewing such plans and specifications. 
(b)  A reapplication fee equal to the initial application fee shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time of a reapplication for approval of any preliminary plat which has previously been reviewed. 
(Code 1997, § 18.92; Rep. & Recr. #441; Am. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-273. - Inspection fee. 
The subdivider or developer shall pay a fee equal to the actual cost to the city for such inspection as the city engineer deems necessary to assure that the construction of the required improvements is in compliance with the plans, specifications and ordinances of the city and any other governmental authority. 
(Code 1997, § 18.93; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-274. - Final plat review fee. 
(a)  The subdivider shall pay a fee to the city treasurer at the time of first application for approval of such plat, in order to assist in defraying the cost of review. Such fee shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Up to and including 20 acres: $190.00. 
(2)  Over 20 acres: $190.00 plus $2.00 per acre. 
(b)  A reapplication fee equal to the initial application fee assessed in subsection (a) of this section, shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time of a reapplication for approval of any final plat which has previously been reviewed. 
(Code 1997, § 18.94; Rep. & Recr. #441; Rec. & Recr. # 720 )  
Sec. 44-275. - Engineering fees. 
(a)  The subdivider or developer shall pay a fee equal to the actual cost to the city for all engineering work incurred by the city in connection with the plat. Engineering work shall include the preparation of construction plans and standard specifications. Fees for engineering work as herein referred to shall be in addition to those fees for inspection, checking and reviewing, as provided in sections 44-272 and 44-273. 
(b)  See section 44-17 for bonding requirements. 
(Code 1997, § 18.96; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-276. - Administrative and legal fee. 
The subdivider or developer shall pay a fee equal to the cost of any legal, administrative, or fiscal work which may be undertaken by the city in connection with the plat, and legal work shall include, among other things, the drafting of contracts between the city and the subdivider or developer. 
(Code 1997, § 18.97; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Sec. 44-277. - Recording fees. 
The subdivider or developer shall pay any and all recording fees required by this chapter in advance of recording. 
(Code 1997, § 18.98; Rep. & Recr. #441)  
Chapter 46 - TAXATION 
 
Sec. 46-1. - Preparation of tax roll and tax collection. 
(a)  Preparation. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.65(2), the clerk-treasurer and finance officer/budget analyst shall prepare the tax roll and transfer it to the county treasurer on or before the third Monday in December. The clerk-treasurer and finance officer/budget analyst shall furnish a tax roll certificate for taxes levied to the county treasurer, per Wis. Stats. § 70.65(3) on or before the third Monday in December. 
(b)  Treasurers responsible for collection. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 74.07, the county treasurer shall collect the general property taxes, special assessments, special taxes and special charges shown in the tax roll. 
(c)  Dates for payment of taxes, special assessments and special charges. 
(1)  All real estate and personal property taxes, special assessments, special charges and other taxes shall be paid as provided in Wis. Stats. § 74.11. 
a.  All taxes on real property and on improvements on leased land shall be paid in one of the following ways: 
1.  In full on or before January 31. 
2.  In two equal installments, unless subject to subsection (c)(1)d of this section, with the first installment payable on or before January 31 and the second installment payable on or before July 31. 
b.  All special assessments, special charges and special taxes that are placed in the tax roll shall be paid in full on or before January 31. 
c.  All taxes on personal property, except those on improvements on leased land, shall be paid in full on or five working days after January 31. 
d.  If the total real property tax levied on a parcel of property is less than $100.00, or if the total property tax levied on an improvement on leased land is less than $100.00, it shall be paid in full on or before January 31. 
e.  Payments. 
1.  Payments made on or before January 31 shall be made to the county treasurer. 
2.  Personal property payments shall be made to the city clerk-treasurer after January 31. 
3.  All other payments shall be made to the county treasurer. 
(Code 1997, § 3.01; Am. #373; Rep. & Recr. # 696 )  
Sec. 46-2. - Special assessments. 
(a)  Payment in installments. 
(1)  Whenever any special assessments shall be levied to defray the cost of any public improvement, such special assessments may be paid in annual installments of not more than ten in number as determined by the city council. 
(2)  The first installment shall include a proportionate part of the principal of the special assessment determined by the number of installments, together with interest at the rate determined by the city council. Such interest rate shall be computed for a period of one year from the date of the notice hereinafter provided for, and each subsequent installment shall include a like proportion of the principal and one year's interest upon the unpaid portion of such assessment. 
(3)  The first installment shall be entered in the first tax roll prepared after the installments shall have been determined as a special tax on the property upon which the special assessment was levied, and thereafter this tax shall be treated in all respects as any other city tax. One of the subsequent installments shall be entered in a like manner and with like effect in each of the annual tax rolls thereafter until all are levied. 
(4)  If any installment so entered in the tax roll shall not be paid to the city treasurer with the other taxes, it shall be returned to the county as delinquent and accepted and collected by the county in the same manner as delinquent general taxes on real estate. 
(b)  Deferred assessments. 
(1)  The city council has made the following finding: In the interest of the public health, welfare and safety, it is often necessary to construct certain public improvements in areas which are undeveloped or outside the territorial limits of the city. 
(2)  The city council may defer the due date of any special assessment levied against property abutting or benefited by a public improvement, which abutting property is undeveloped or outside the territorial limits of the city. Such special assessment must be paid, however, within ten years of the date of the resolution making the levy, unless the city council permits additional time by allowing payment of the assessment in installments, in which case the assessments shall be paid within the time prescribed by the resolution permitting installment payments. 
(3)  If the city council defers the due date of special assessments under this section, it shall make an annual interest charge, the rate thereof to be set by the city council, which charge shall be added to the total assessment for each full year of deferment. 
(4)  Owners of property for which a special assessment has been deferred under this section shall not have use of the improvement until: 
a.  The amount of the deferred assessment, including interest due thereon, is paid in full to the city; or 
b.  Such an owner desiring to make use of the improvement shall enter into an agreement with the city to pay the assessment plus accrued interest, plus future interest over a stipulated period of time in equal installments of principal plus variable installments of interest as determined by the city council, except that, where approved by the city council, only that portion of the total amount of deferred assessment shall be collected as it applies to the portion of the land being developed. 
(5)  Any special assessment deferred under this section shall be a lien against the property assessed from the date of the resolution making the levy. 
(6)  Whenever the due date of a special assessment shall be deferred under this section, a notice shall be published in the official paper substantially as follows: 
DEFERRED ASSESSMENT NOTICE 
Notice is hereby given that the special assessments for improvement of (describe the improvement) have been determined as to each parcel of real estate affected thereby, and a statement of the same is on file with the City Clerk-Treasurer. It is proposed to defer payment of the same with interest thereon (here insert the percent per annum). 
(c)  Wis. Stats. ch. 66 adopted. The provisions of the Wisconsin Statutes relating to street improvements, laying of sanitary sewers, water mains, stormwater sewers, paving and any other public improvement, and providing for the costs of installing and constructing the same and the manner of levying special assessments against the property benefited thereby, are hereby adopted for the city and shall be in force and effect as ordinances of the city as if fully set forth herein, except that wherever such statute provides for the giving of notice in addition to the posting and publication of notice, as provided in the statutes, personal notice shall be given by mailing such notice to each interested person whose post office address is known or can, with reasonable diligence, be ascertained at least ten days before the hearing or proceeding specified in the notice. 
(d)  Alternate procedure. 
(1)  In addition to other methods provided by law, special assessments for any public work or improvement, or any current service, may be levied in accordance with the provisions of this subsection (d). 
(2)  Whenever the city council shall determine that any public work or improvement, or any current service, shall be financed in whole or in part by special assessments levied under this section, it shall adopt a resolution specifying this intention and the time, either before or after completion of the work or improvement, when the amount of the assessments will be determined and levied, the number of annual installments, if any, in which assessments may be paid, the rate of interest to be charged on the unpaid balance and the terms on which any of the assessments may be deferred while no use of the improvement is made in connection with the property. 
(3)  The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 shall apply to special assessments levied under this section except that, when the city council determines by resolution that the hearing on the assessments be held subsequent to the completion of the work or improvement or the rendering of the service, the report required by Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(4) shall contain a statement of the final cost of the work, service or improvement in lieu of an estimate of the cost. 
(4)  Notice of the time and place of the public hearing on any special assessment proposed to be levied and notice of the final assessment and terms of payment thereof shall be given in the manner prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(10), and subsection (c) of this section. 
(5)  Any special assessment levied under this section shall be a lien against the property assessed from the date of the final resolution of the city council determining the amount of the levy. 
(6)  Any person against whose property a special assessment is levied under this section may appeal therefrom in the manner prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(12), within 40 days of the date of the final determination of the city council. 
(Code 1997, § 3.10; Cr. #126; Cr. #178; Rep. & Recr. #696 )  
Sec. 46-3. - Room tax rates; commission created. 
(a)  Purpose. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.06015, for the privilege of furnishing at retail rooms or lodging to transients by hotel keepers, motel operators and other persons furnishing accommodations that are available to the public, irrespective of whether membership is required for use of the accommodations, a room tax is hereby imposed upon retailers at the rate of eight percent of the gross receipts for the lease or rental of such accommodations, rooms or lodging within the city, effective January 1, 1998. 
(b)  City promotion and tourism commission created. A city promotion and tourism commission ("commission") is hereby created. The commission shall consist of six voting members and one city council representative serving in an ex officio capacity. Each member shall be appointed by the mayor and shall be confirmed by a majority vote of the common council who are present for the vote. In addition, the mayor shall appoint one alternate member of the commission, who shall act with full power only when a member of the board refuses to vote because of interest or when a regular member is absent. Such alternate members shall be designated alternate. Any vacancy occurring on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member involved by appointment and confirmation as provided above. Commission members shall serve one-year terms and may be reappointed. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. The commission shall include a representative from the state hotel and motel industry. The commission shall meet regularly, and, from among its members, it shall elect a chairperson, a vice chairperson and a secretary. 
(c)  Definitions. In this section, "transient," "hotel," and "motel" have the meanings in Wis. Stats. § 77.52(2)(a)1. 
(d)  Exempt from selective sales tax. The room tax shall not be subject to the selective sales tax imposed by Wis. Stats. § 77.52(2)(a)1. 
(e)  Reports. Each retailer engaged in furnishing such accommodations, rooms or lodging as defined in this section shall submit a quarterly report to the treasurer's office showing the gross receipts from furnishing such accommodations, rooms, or lodging and a copy of his/her state sales tax report for such business, along with the effective percentage tax for the gross receipts as reported, but not later than 30 days from the end of each calendar quarter for the receipts of that past calendar quarter. 
(f)  Distribution and use of room tax. Room tax shall be collected by the city in accordance with this section and Wis. Stats. § 66.0615. The city shall retain the maximum amount of room tax allowed by state statute for general purposes and the remainder of the room tax shall be forwarded to the city promotion and tourism commission ("commission"). The commission shall use such funds for the purpose of tourism, promotion and development. As used herein, the term "tourism, promotion and development" means any of the following that are significantly used by transient tourists and reasonably likely to generate paid overnight stays at any establishment required to collect and remit to the city the room tax established by this section: 
(1)  Marketing projects, including advertising media buys, creation and distribution of printed or electronic promotional tourist materials, or efforts to recruit conventions, sporting events, or motor coach groups. 
(2)  Transient tourist informational services. 
(3)  Tangible municipal development, including a convention center. 
The commission shall submit to the city council annually a detailed report of the amount of room tax revenues received by the commission and the purpose or purposes for which the revenues were spent. The report shall include such information as may be required by the city, from time to time, so as to allow the city to submit all reports and information necessary to complete and submit timely filings required by the department of revenue or any other state agency charged with the responsibility of administering and regulating the collection and use of room tax revenues. 
(g)  Unpaid taxes. All unpaid taxes shall bear interest at the rate of 1½ percent per month from the due date of the return. Failure to pay the tax or delinquent payment of such taxes shall be subject to a $50.00 late filing penalty in addition to the interest imposed by this section. 
(h)  Liability. If any person liable for any amount of tax under this section sells his/her business or stock of goods or goods or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall be responsible for unpaid tax due under this section. 
(i)  False or fraudulent return. If a false or fraudulent return is filed with the intent in either case to defeat or evade the tax imposed by this section, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be paid in addition to the tax interest and late filing penalty. 
(Code 1997, § 3.12; Cr. #195; Recr. #424; Am. #572; #609; Rep. & Recr. #696 ; Rep. & Rec. 735 ) 
( Ord. No. 747 , §§ 3, 4, 8-20-2018) 
Note Subsection (a) of this section was amended by Ord. #347; subsection (e) of this section was amended by MCC 1995.  
Sec. 46-4. - Impact fees; imposition and effective date of fees; effective February 25, 2000. 
(a)  Fees generally. The following fees shall be paid prior to issuance of a zoning or building permit for any single family residential structure, any residential structure having in excess of one dwelling, and any principal structure intended or capable of human occupancy for non-residential purposes. The amount of fee and the categories of public facilities for which the fee is created shall be adopted from time to time by the council and kept on file by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Adjustments. 
(1)  Impact fees shall be reviewed annually to determine adjustments deemed necessary by the common council to reflect changes in the net capital value of facilities and changes in the municipal debt and any other relevant change of circumstances. The date for review shall be correlated to the issuance of the annual "statement of values" as part of the State of Wisconsin Local Government Property Insurance Fund Program. All changes in impact fees shall be in effect as adopted by ordinance. 
(2)  In response to specific applications, the common council may provide an exception from or the reduction in the amount of impact fees on land development that provides low-cost housing, provided that the impact fee reduction or exemption does not result in increasing fees to other properties that are subject to the fees. 
(c)  Treatment of impact fee revenues. 
(1)  Impact fees collected pursuant to this section shall be accounted for separately from other funds of the city. Impact fee revenues and interest earned on impact fee revenues may be expended only for the capital facilities for which the impact fees were collected. 
(2)  Impact fees that are collected pursuant to this section but are not used within a reasonable length of time after they are collected to fund the capital facility costs for which they are collected shall be refunded to the then-current owner of the property with respect to which the impact fees were collected. 
The time periods indicated below are deemed by the city to constitute reasonable periods of time within which the fees that are collected may be retained by the city and used for the purposes for which they are collected: 
Capital Facility 	Time Period from Date of Collection Within Which Funds Will be Available for the Specified Use by the City 
Library facilities 	10 years 
Law enforcement facilities 	10 years 
Fire protection facilities 	10 years 
Recreation facilities 	10 years 
Recycling facilities 	10 years 
 
(d)  Appeals. Property owners or other parties who are aggrieved by the imposition of an impact fee or fees pursuant to this section may file an appeal of the amount of the impact fee, the collection, or use of the impact fee. The form of appeal shall be a written narrative stating the nature and reasons for the appeal and filed with the city clerk-treasurer. The appeal shall be noticed on the agenda of the next meeting of the common council and referred to those boards, committees, commissions, departments and advisors deemed necessary by the common council. Following receipt of reports from said committees, the common council shall provide an opportunity for the appellant to address the council. Following this, the council shall determine whether or not to sustain the appeal, in whole or in part, and shall grant relief appropriate to the circumstances. 
(Code 1997, § 3.13; Cr. #466; Am. #645; #672; Rep. & Recr. #696 )  
Chapter 48 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 48-1. - State traffic laws adopted. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, the statutory provisions of Wis. Stats. chs. 340 to 348 and § 941.01, describing and defining regulations with respect to vehicles and traffic, exclusive of any provisions therein relating to penalties to be imposed, are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this section. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated herein are intended to be made part of this chapter in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic on the highways, streets and alleys of the state. 
(Code 1997, § 7.01; Rep. & Recr. # 699 )  
Sec. 48-2. - State standards for motor vehicle equipment adopted. 
(a)  Administrative regulations adopted. The administrative rules and regulations of Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305, exclusive of any provisions therein relating to the penalties to be imposed, are hereby adopted by reference and made part of this Code as if fully set forth herein. 
(b)  Limitation. A law enforcement officer may not stop or inspect a vehicle solely to determine compliance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305. A law enforcement officer may issue a citation for a violation of Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305, observed in the course of a stop or inspection made for other purposes, except that a law enforcement officer may not take a person into physical custody solely for a violation of Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305. 
(c)  Noncompliance prohibited. No person shall operate or allow to be operated on any highway, street or alley within the city a vehicle that is not in conformity with the requirements of subsection (1) of the equipment provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 347, or Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305. 
(d)  Owner's liability. Any owner of a vehicle not equipped as required by this section who knowingly causes or permits such vehicle to be operated on a highway is guilty of the violation the same as if he had operated the vehicle. The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 347.04, relating to nonapplicability of demerit points shall apply to owners convicted of violation of this section. 
(e)  Penalty. Penalty for violation of any provision of this section, including the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans 305, incorporated herein by reference, shall be as provided in section 1-4 together with the costs of prosecution and applicable penalty assessment. 
(Code 1997, § 7.015; Cr. #441-A)  
Sec. 48-3. - No through truck streets. 
All local streets within the city limits shall be "no through truck" streets. Through trucks having an empty weight limit of over six tons shall be permitted only on county and state highways, but trucks having an empty weight limit of six tons or less shall be exempt from restrictions on using city streets. 
(Code 1997, § 7.02)  
Sec. 48-4. - Speed limits. 
(a)  Speed limits established. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 349.11, the speed limits set forth in Wis. Stats. §§ 346.57 and 356.58 in fixed miles per hour are established as follows: 
(1)  Special speed restrictions for certain vehicles. In addition to complying with other speed restrictions imposed by law, no person may drive any vehicle equipped with metal tires or sold rubber tires at a speed in excess of 15 mph. This subsection does not apply to bicycles. 
(2)  Speed restrictions for special locations. 
a.  School zones: 15 miles per hour, when children are present. 
b.  Public alleys: 15 miles per hour. 
(3)  Vehicular travel on all streets, or portions of streets, within the City of Delafield shall be restricted to 25 miles per hour, unless otherwise posted and identified on the official traffic control map, or as identified in subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  Excepting vehicles described in Wis. Stats. § 346.58(1), 25 mph: 
a.  Hillside Dr., west of Austin Circle. 
b.  Hillside Ct., entire length of street. 
c.  Huntington Rd., entire length of street. 
d.  Evelyn Ave., entire length of street. 
e.  Johns St., entire length of street. 
f.  Glen Oak Ct., entire length of street. 
g.  Bahr Rd., entire length of street. 
h.  Main St., from Milwaukee Street westerly to its intersection with Wells Street. 
i.  Genesee St., from I-94 north to Exeter Street. 
j.  Genesee St., south from Church Street to I-94. 
k.  Campbell Trace, entire length of street. 
l.  S. Lapham Peak Rd., entire length of street within city limits. 
m.  Vettelson Rd., from Capitol Drive westerly to the east Chenequa Village limits. 
n.  Kettle Drive, entire length of street. 
o.  Kettle Court East, entire length of street. 
p.  Oakwood Dr., from Spanjer Street extended east to Genesee Street. 
q.  Golf Rd., from STH 83 to Milwaukee Street. 
r.  Milwaukee St., entire length of street. 
s.  Cushing Park Rd., north of Main Street. 
t.  West Shore Dr., the east-west segment only, from CTH C to the curve turning north. 
u.  North Shore Dr., entire length of street. 
(5)  Excepting vehicles described in Wis. Stats. § 346.58(1), 30 mph: 
a.  Golf Rd., entire length of street within city limits, east of STH 83. 
b.  Nagawicka Rd., entire length of street. 
c.  Nagawicka Rd. E., entire length of street. 
d.  Oakwood Rd., entire length of street (located between STH 83 and Keypoint Ln.). 
e.  Oakwood Dr., between Spanjer Street extended and the city limits. 
(6)  Excepting vehicles described in Wis. Stats. § 346.58(1), 35 mph: 
a.  Cushing Park Rd., south of Main Street. 
b.  Genesee St., as to northbound traffic only, between Exeter Street and the north city limits. 
c.  Genesee St., as to southbound traffic only, between the north city limits and Church Street. 
d.  Hillside Dr., for both eastbound and westbound traffic between County E and Austin Circle. 
e.  Indian Spring Dr., the entire length of street. 
f.  Main St., from its intersection with Wells St. to the west city limits. 
g.  Mill Rd., entire length of street. 
h.  Mission Ave., entire length of street within the city limits. 
i.  Mission Rd., entire length of street. 
j.  Nashotah Rd., entire length within the city limits. 
k.  STH 83, from north of Golf Road to the southern city limits. 
(7)  Excepting vehicles described in Wis. Stats. § 346.58(1), 45 mph: 
a.  STH 83, from the bridge over Vettelson Road to north of Golf Road. 
b.  Vettelson Rd., from the Chenequa Village limits on the east to the west city limits. 
c.  CTH C, south of I-94. 
(8)  Excepting vehicles described in Wis. Stats. § 346.58(1), 15 mph: 
a.  Heritage Dr., entire length of street. 
b.  West Shore Dr., the north-south segment only, inclusive of the curves on the north and south ends. 
(b)  School zones. The following named streets on and about the grounds of St. John's Military Academy are hereby designated school zones: 
(1)  Farrand Lane, Church Street, Exeter Street, Smythe Lane, St. John's Road, Spanjer Street and that portion of Genesee Street between Exeter Street and Anderson Drive. 
(2)  Whenever children are present on or about any of such streets, or on or about the sidewalk, play, camp or recreation areas adjacent thereto, no person shall operate a motor vehicle on any of such streets at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour. 
(3)  Church Street is hereby designated as a two-way street, with traffic flow going both east and west. 
(4)  That portion of Farrand Lane between St. John's Road and Church Street is hereby designated as a two-way street, with traffic flow going both north and south. Parallel parking, as much as is practicable, shall be permitted on the east side of Farrand Lane. 
(5)  The department of public works of the city shall erect and maintain sufficient appropriate signs to inform the public of the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Stop signs. Stop signs shall be placed on Nagawicka Street midway between Milwaukee Street and Main Street. 
(d)  Yield signs. At the intersection of Indian Spring Drive and South Lapham Peak Road. 
(e)  Dead end signs. At the intersection of Indian Springs Drive and South Genesee Street. 
(Code 1997, § 7.03; Rep. & Recr. #662; Am. #699 )  
Sec. 48-5. - Parking regulations. 
(a)  Exemptions. Exempted from these provisions shall be authorized emergency vehicles, delivery vehicles while their operators are actually and temporarily engaged in making deliveries to abutting premises and temporarily and accidentally disabled vehicles during the time actually and reasonably required to repair and remove the same. The burden of proving such exempting circumstances shall be upon the owner or operator. 
(b)  Definitions. Whenever "intersection" is used herein, it shall refer to the intersection of the centerlines of the intersecting streets concerned, and distances specified from such intersection shall be measured along the centerline of the appropriate street. Whenever parking is prohibited, limited or regulated herein by reference to any such distances, the area limited shall be determined by lines running through such measured points at right angles to the centerline to the side of the street or highway concerned. 
(c)  Parking on or about city hall. 
(1)  No person shall, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on any day, park any motor vehicle, trailer, wagon, or other conveyance upon, or in the roadside, curb, or shoulder area immediately in front of the tract of land occupied by the city hall for any period of time exceeding three hours consecutively. 
(2)  Persons actually and necessarily engaged in business with, consulting with, or in attendance upon any city officer, board, council, or public meeting, at the city hall shall, during the period of such consultation, attendance or meeting, be exempt from the provisions hereof; but such fact shall be deemed to constitute matter of affirmative defense to any charge of violation hereof, and the burden of providing the same shall be on the defendant. 
(3)  There shall be erected and maintained, at not less than two appropriate places upon such area of traffic limitation, proper signs warning of the general parking limitation at such place. 
(4)  Any vehicle parked or left standing upon a highway, street or alley or other public grounds in violation of any of these provisions is declared to be a hazard to traffic and public safety. Such vehicle shall be removed by the operator, upon request of any police officer, to a position where parking, stopping or standing is not prohibited. Any police officer after issuing a citation for illegal parking, stopping or standing of an unattended vehicle in violation of this Code is authorized to remove such vehicle to a position where parking is not prohibited. The officer may order a motor carrier holding a permit to perform vehicle towing services, a licensed motor vehicle salvage dealer or a licensed motor vehicle dealer who performs vehicle towing services to remove and store such vehicle in any storage garage or rental parking grounds or any facility of the person providing the towing services. In addition, the owner or operator of a vehicle so removed shall pay the cost of towing and storage. 
(d)  Overnight parking. 
(1)  Between November 1 and May 1 following, no person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, trailer, wagon or piece of machinery upon any street, municipal parking lot or any other generally available public parking area of the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Physicians on emergency call shall be exempt from the provisions of this subsection (d). 
(3)  Whenever any snowfall shall accumulate to the extent of four inches or more in any 24-hour period, and within a period of 12 hours after such snowfall terminates, no person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, trailer, wagon, or piece of machinery upon any street, municipal parking lot or any other generally available public parking area of the city for a period of time longer than 30 minutes between the hours of 7:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m., and between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. 
Vehicles parked in violation of this subsection are subject to being removed from the street, municipal parking lot, or public parking area by a towing service as provided in subsection (c)(4) of this section. 
(4)  The registered owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for violation and the fact that the owner was not the driver shall not be a defense. 
(5)  No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, trailer, wagon or piece of machinery upon any municipal parking lot of the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. unless specifically permitted by signage posted by the chief of police, with the assistance of the department of public works. 
(6)  No vehicles in excess of 8,000-pound GVW shall be allowed upon any municipal parking lot. 
(7)  Perpendicular parking on the east side of Canal Street, for the distance north of the point of 75 feet north of Milwaukee Street, is exempt from the provisions of this section except that between November 1 and May 1 following, no person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, trailer, wagon or piece of machinery upon this designated parking area between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(8)  Vehicles parked in violation of this section are subject to being removed by a towing service as provided in subsection (c)(4) of this section. 
(e)  Parking prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall at any time park or leave standing any automobile or other vehicle, wagon, trailer or other conveyance whatever, either wholly or partly, upon or within the limits of any of the "no parking" zones on streets, roads or ways as identified on the official traffic map. 
(2)  No vehicles in excess of 8,000-pound gross vehicle weight shall be allowed upon any municipal parking lot. 
(3)  Exempted from these provisions shall be authorized emergency vehicles, delivery vehicles while their operators are actually and temporarily engaged in making deliveries to abutting premises and temporarily and accidentally disabled vehicles during the time actually and reasonably required to repair and remove the same. The burden of proving such exempting circumstances shall be upon the owner or operator. 
(4)  No person shall, at any time, park any vehicle in a loading zone on the south side of Milwaukee Street within 90 feet east of its intersection with Genesee Street; nor upon the north side of Milwaukee Street within 70 feet of such intersection. 
(5)  Whenever "intersection" is used herein, it shall refer to the intersection of the centerlines of the intersecting streets concerned, and distances specified from such intersection shall be measured along the centerline of the appropriate street. Whenever parking is prohibited, limited or regulated herein by reference to any such distances, the area limited shall be determined by lines running through such measured points at right angles to the centerline to the side of the street or highway concerned. 
(f)  Angled and perpendicular parking required. On all streets where parking is permitted, no person shall park any vehicle except in the manner described in Wis. Stats. § 346.54, as lawful parallel parking except, however, the following streets and portions of streets where angle parking as defined in such section shall be permitted: 
(1)  The south side of Milwaukee Street from a point 90 feet east of its intersection with Genesee Street east to its intersection with Onedia Street. The angle parking for the first two parking spaces immediately west of Onedia Street on the south side of Milwaukee Street shall be restricted to no sport utility vehicle (SUV), truck or van parking. Vehicles parked in violation of this section are subject to being removed by a towing service as provided in subsection (c)(4) of this section. 
(2)  Canal Street: The entire east side of the street, between Milwaukee Street and Mill Street, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(3)  Canal Street: The west side of the street, from Mill Street to a point 120 feet south, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(4)  Mill Street: The south side of the street, from Canal Street to a point 100 feet west, shall be angled parking. 
(5)  Oneida Street: Both sides of the street, from Main Street to a point 90 feet north, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(6)  Oneida Street: The entire east side of the street, between Wells Street and Main Street, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(7)  Wells Street: The north side of the street, from a point 60 feet east of Oneida Street to a point 150 feet further east, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(8)  Main Street: North side of the street, between Genesee Street and Oneida Streets, shall be angled parking. 
(9)  Main Street: South side of the street, from Oneida Street to a point 130 feet east, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(10)  Division Street: North and south sides of the street, between Lake Street and Bleeker Street, shall be angled parking. 
(11)  Pamelia Street: North and south sides of the street, for the entire length of the street, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(12)  Wells Street: The north side of the street, between Dopkins Street and Butler Street, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(13)  Wells Street: North side of the street, from Dopkins Street to a point 200 feet east, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(14)  Dopkins Street: East side of the street, from Wells Street to a point 160 feet north, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(15)  Exeter Street: The south side of the street, from Williams Street to a point 220 feet west, shall be perpendicular parking. 
(16)  St. John's Road: South side of the street, from Farrand Street to a point 200 feet west, shall be angled parking. 
(17)  Farrand Lane: The entire west side of street, between St. John's Road and Church Street; and on the east side from St. John's Road to a point 120 feet south shall be angled parking. 
(g)  No parking, standing or stopping. 
(1)  No parking, standing or stopping between east and west boundaries of Firemen's Park on the north side of Main Street. 
(2)  No parking, standing or stopping between signs on the south side of Main Street from Lapham Peak Road to Nagawicka Street. 
(3)  No parking, standing or stopping on either side of the entire length of Heritage Drive. 
(h)  Parking against traffic prohibited. 
(1)  Upon a street in the city where traffic is permitted to move in both directions simultaneously and where angle parking is not clearly designated by official traffic signs or markers, a vehicle must be parked parallel to the edge of the street, heading in the direction of traffic on the right side of the street. 
(2)  The registered owner of the vehicle violating the terms of this subsection (h) shall be responsible for the violation. The fact that such owner was not the driver of the vehicle shall not be a defense. 
(i)  Bleeker Street parking lot regulated. 
(1)  Nor person not a resident of the City of Delafield or the Village of Nashotah, and who does not display a window sticker issued in accordance with subsection (i)(2) of this section, may park any motor vehicle, trailer, wagon, or other conveyance upon or in the Bleeker Street parking lot. 
(2)  No resident of the City of Delafield or the Village of Nashotah shall park in the Bleeker Street parking lot without first having obtained an annual parking permit from the city clerk. The annual parking permit shall be a window sticker which shall be affixed to the inside lower left-hand corner of the windshield of any motor vehicle parked in such lot. The city clerk may issue up to three window stickers for each residence or household for which an annual parking permit is issued. Before approving any annual parking permit and issuing any window sticker, the applicant requesting issuance of an annual parking permit, and the owner of each motor vehicle for which a window sticker is being requested must provide proof that the applicant and/or owner of the motor vehicle is a resident of the City of Delafield or the Village of Nashotah. Proof of residency may be established by providing a driver's license, tax bill, rental agreement or motor vehicle registration certificate.
