If the applicant or owner of the motor vehicle is unable to provide documentation establishing proof of residency, as provided in this subsection, the applicant and/or owner of the motor vehicle may request the lake welfare committee to determine that he/she is a resident of the City of Delafield or the Village of Nashotah. The fee for each window sticker shall be determined by resolution as adopted by the common council from time to time. 
(3)  Prohibited practices. No person, firm, partnership or corporation or any officer, member, agent, servant, or employee of any firm, partnership or corporation shall park any vehicle of any kind or description in the Bleeker Street parking lot when such vehicle is displaying a forged, counterfeited or duplicated City of Delafield Bleeker Street parking lot permit, any object mimicking the appearance of such a permit, or any such permit which has been issued for a vehicle other than the one upon which it is displayed. 
(4)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this subsection (l) shall forfeit to the city the sum of $70.00 for each such violation, provided such forfeiture is paid within 72 hours, or the sum of $100.00 if payment of forfeiture is not made within 72 hours, plus the cost of prosecution. 
(j)  Parking of heavy vehicles, trucks and heavy equipment in residential districts. No operator, owner or person having control of any of the following described vehicles: motor truck as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(34), which is 24 feet or more in length, truck tractor as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(73), motor bus as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(31), school bus as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(56), semitrailer as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(57), road machinery as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(52), or any vehicle of a type that is registered as a commercial vehicle under the quarterly or consecutive monthly registration systems per Wis. Stats. §§ 341.30(1)(a), (c), (d), (e) to 341.305(2)(a), (b), (c), shall park any such vehicle on any public street, alley or parking lot in a residential district, except when loading, unloading or rendering service to a property on said public street or alley, or any adjacent street or alley. Residential districts include all areas zoned for residential use on the official zoning map of the City of Delafield. 
(k)  Parking trailers prohibited. 
(1)  Parking of trailers, whether attached or detached, from motor vehicles is prohibited on all city streets and public areas, unless in an area designated for trailer parking. This subsection shall not apply to temporary parking for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or in receiving or discharging passengers and while attended so it can be moved in case of emergency or to avoid obstruction of traffic. 
(2)  Exception. Subsection (k)(1) of this section shall not apply to temporary parking of trailers and other equipment/vehicles being utilized by city police department personnel for public safety purposes, department of public works personnel in the performance or maintenance of public facilities or municipal service functions and lake country fire and rescue department personnel for fire, rescue and EMS services. 
(3)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this subsection (k) shall forfeit to the city the sum of $70.00 for each such violation, provided such forfeiture is paid within 72 hours, or the sum of $100.00 if payment of forfeiture is not made within 72 hours, plus the cost of prosecution. 
(l)  Overnight parking in city parks. 
(1)  Restricted. No person shall, from one-half hour after sunset until 7:00 a.m. on any day, park or leave standing any vehicle, trailer, wagon or piece of machinery upon any city park or parking lot designated for use of any city park. 
(2)  Exceptions. 
a.  The city council may, upon written application of any group desiring to organize an athletic, recreational or social function, grant a permit waiving the restrictions of subsection (l)(1) of this section for a specified number of days. 
b.  Repealed. 
(3)  Signs. There shall be erected and maintained at each such area of traffic limitation proper signs warning of the parking limitation at such place. 
(4)  Towaway. 
a.  Any vehicle parked or left standing within the boundaries of any city park or parking lot designated for use of any city park in violation of any of the provisions of this subsection (l) is declared to be a hazard to traffic and public safety. Such vehicle shall be removed by the operator, upon request of any police officer, to a position where parking is not prohibited. 
b.  Any police officer, after issuing a citation for illegal parking of an unattended vehicle in violation of this subsection (l), is authorized to remove such vehicle to a position where parking is not prohibited. The officer may order a motor carrier holding a permit to perform vehicle towing services, a licensed motor vehicle salvage dealer or a licensed motor vehicle dealer who performs vehicle towing services to remove and store such vehicle in any storage garage, rental parking grounds or any facility of the person providing the towing services. In addition, the owner or operator of a vehicle, trailer, wagon or piece of machinery so removed shall pay the cost of towing and storage. 
(m)  Temporary parking prohibition. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the lack of specific parking prohibition, the chief of police has the authority to erect temporary no parking signs on any city street or part thereof whenever it is necessary to prohibit parking on any city street or part thereof in order to maintain adequate available roadway width. 
(2)  The chief of police, with the assistance of the department of public works, shall post such streets or parts thereof with signs bearing the words "No Parking-Temporary." 
(3)  No person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle upon any city street or part thereof in violation of such signs. 
(Code 1997, § 7.04; Cr. #281; Cr. #298; Renum. #461; Am. #490; #502; #549; Rep. & Recr. #699 ; Rep. & Recr. # 739 )  
Sec. 48-6. - Snowmobiles. 
(a)  State snowmobile laws adopted. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the statutory provisions describing and defining regulations with respect to snowmobiles in the following enumerated sections of the Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference and made part of this section as if fully set forth herein. Acts required to be performed or prohibited by such statutes are required or prohibited by this section. 
(1)  350.01 (Definitions). 
(2)  350.02 (Operation of Snowmobiles on or in Vicinity of Highway). 
(3)  350.03 (Right-of-Way). 
(4)  350.04 (Snowmobile Races, Derbies and Routes). 
(5)  350.045 (Public Utility Exemption). 
(6)  350.047 (Local Ordinance to be Filed). 
(7)  350.05 (Operation by Youthful Operators Restricted). 
(8)  350.055 (Safety Certification Program Established). 
(9)  350.07 (Driving Animals). 
(10)  350.08 (Owner Permitting Operation). 
(11)  350.09 (Head Lamps, Tail Lamps and Brakes). 
(12)  350.10 (Miscellaneous Provisions for Snowmobile Operation). 
(13)  350.12 (Registration of Snowmobiles). 
(14)  350.13 (Uniform Trail Signs and Standards). 
(15)  350.15 (Accidents and Accident Reports). 
(16)  350.17 (Enforcement). 
(17)  350.18 (Local Ordinances). 
(18)  350.19 (Liability of Land Owners). 
(b)  Applicability of rules of the road to snowmobiles. The operator of a snowmobile upon a roadway shall, in addition to the provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 350, be subject to Wis. Stats. §§ 346.04, 346.11, 346.14(1), 346.18, 346.19, 346.20, 346.21, 346.26, 346.27, 346.33, 346.35, 346.37, 346.39, 346.40, 346.44, 346.46, 346.47, 346.48, 346.50(1)(b), 346.51, 346.52, 346.53, 346.54, 346.55, 346.87, 346.88, 346.89, 346.90, 346.91, 346.92(1) and 346.94(1), (6), (6m) and (9). 
(c)  Permitting operation by improper persons prohibited. No owner or person having charge or control of a snowmobile shall knowingly authorize or permit any person to operate such snowmobile who is incapable by reason of age, physical or mental disability, or is under the influence of an intoxicating liquor, fermented malt beverage or a controlled substance. 
(d)  Intoxicated snowmobiling. Wis. Stats. §§ 350.101 through 35.101 shall apply to the operation of a snowmobile anywhere within the city. 
(e)  Written consent of owner required. The consent required under Wis. Stats. § 350.10(6), (11), (12) and (13) shall be written consent dated and limited to the year in which the consent is given. If the property is owned or leased by more than one person, the consent of each shall be obtained. 
(f)  Special local regulations. 
(1)  Hours of operation. No person shall operate a snowmobile or all-terrain vehicle within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday night, or between 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on any Saturday and Sunday night. Snowmobile operation on holidays shall be during those hours permitted on weekends when such holiday is a weekday. 
(2)  Lake operation. In addition to compliance with provisions of Wis. Stats. § 350.10(9), adopted by reference under subsection (a) of this section, operation of snowmobiles on ice of Lake Nagawicka shall also be governed by the following regulations: 
a.  Except for the purpose of entering or leaving the lake, snowmobile operation is prohibited within 200 feet of the shores of Lake Nagawicka after 9:00 p.m. 
b.  No snowmobile shall be operated anywhere on Lake Nagawicka between 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. Monday through Friday or between 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. Saturdays and Sundays. 
(3)  Snowmobile trails. The following routes are designated as approved snowmobile trails within the city: 
a.  Mariner Drive, from its beginning at State Trunk Highway 83 to the Waukesha County Park lagoon where it connects to the Wales Trail. 
b.  The south side of Vettelson Road starting on the east side of Nagawicka Road and proceeding easterly to a point at which Vettelson Road crosses the railroad tracks; and in the event that there is not sufficient city-owned right-of-way on the south side of the pavement of Vettelson Road that such trail be established on the north side of Vettelson Road; and that permission shall be granted from year to year. 
c.  That a snowmobile trail presently established running from the Nagawicka Road along Vettelson Road westerly from Nagawicka Road and on the south side of Vettelson Road to the Village of Nashotah boundary shall be approved each year by the council with the understanding that the snowmobile club responsible shall make every effort to straighten the trail, going over private property and get the permission of the property owner to cross his property with their trail. 
d.  Snowmobiles shall be operated on all trails in single file. 
(Code 1997, § 7.05; Am. #699 )  
Sec. 48-7. - Official traffic signs and signals. 
(a)  Chief of police responsible. The director of public works shall procure, erect and maintain appropriate standard traffic signs, signals and markings conforming to the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices giving notice of the provisions of this chapter as required by state law. Signs shall be erected in such locations and in such manner as the chief of police determines shall best effect the purposes of this chapter and give adequate warning to users of the streets and highways. 
(b)  Removal of unofficial signs and signals. The director of public works shall have the authority granted by Wis. Stats. § 349.09 and shall order the removal of a sign, signal, marking or device placed, maintained or displayed in violation of this chapter or Wis. Stats. § 346.41. Any charge imposed on any premises for removal of an illegal sign, signal or device shall be reported to the chief of police for his review and certification. 
(Code 1997, § 7.06; Am. # 699 )  
Sec. 48-8. - Unnecessary noise prohibited. 
No person shall make unnecessary and annoying noise with a motor vehicle by squealing tires, excessive acceleration of engine or by emitting unnecessary and loud muffler noises. 
(Code 1997, § 7.07)  
Sec. 48-9. - School bus warning lights regulated. 
School bus operators shall use flashing red warning lights in a business or residence district when pupils or other authorized passengers are to be loaded or unloaded at a location at which there are no traffic signals, and such persons shall cross the street or highway before being loaded or after being unloaded. 
(Code 1997, § 7.08; Cr. #271)  
Sec. 48-10. - Operating vehicle within 50 feet of snowplow prohibited. 
No driver shall operate a motor vehicle within 50 feet of the rear of a municipal truck while the truck is engaged in snowplowing activity. 
(Code 1997, § 7.09; Cr. #312)  
Sec. 48-11. - Weight limits. 
(a)  Special and seasonal weight limits. Wis. Stats. § 349.16 is hereby adopted by reference and as referenced on the special and seasonal weight limit map on file with the city clerk. 
(b)  Exemption of vehicles carrying certain commodities. Under Wis. Stats. § 349.16(3), vehicles carrying the following commodities are exempt from the special weight limits imposed by this section: 
(1)  Milk from dairy farms. 
(2)  Pupils and students to and from schools. 
(3)  Garbage, rubbish or other refuse. 
(4)  Persons and property for the purpose of protection of person and property. 
(5)  Personal property owned by the city or carrying persons acting as agents of the city within the scope of their duties. 
(6)  Personal property owned by public utilities or carrying persons acting as agents of the public utilities within the scope of their duties in an emergency only. 
(7)  Farm tractors and farm implements carrying persons or commodities directly related to farming activities. 
(8)  The Bridges Library System delivery truck shall also be exempt from the special and seasonal weight limits. 
(c)  Increased weight limits for vehicles carrying certain commodities. Vehicles carrying the following commodities in an emergency shall carry no more than one-half load: 
(1)  Vehicles carrying material loaded on the vehicle directly from a septic tank or holding tank. 
(2)  Vehicles carrying fuel. 
(3)  Vehicles carrying livestock feed. 
(d)  Penalty and enforcement. The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 348.21(3) shall apply to this section. 
(Code 1997, § 7.10; Cr. #338; Am. # 699 ) 
( Ord. No. 752 , §§ 1, 2, 5-20-2019)  
Sec. 48-12. - Operation of motor vehicles on premises held out to the public. 
(a)  This section shall apply to all premises held out to the public for use of their motor vehicles, whether such premises are publicly or privately owned and whether or not a fee is charged for the use thereof. This section shall not apply to any street or highway. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle on such premises: 
(1)  Across parking stalls indicated by painted lines. This section shall not prohibit entering and occupying a parking stall nor exiting the same, if the operator properly remains within the painted lines. 
(2)  In a manner commonly known as "spinning doughnuts," wherein the vehicle is driven rapidly in a tight radius. 
(3)  At a rapid or sudden acceleration. The squealing of tires or leaving of tire marks shall be evidence of rapid or sudden acceleration. 
(4)  The wrong way in a driving lane where such wrong way is indicated by painted arrow or by the entry angle of adjoining parking stalls or left of a marked centerline in a driving lane. 
(5)  Without stopping for a stop sign posted on such premises. The stop required hereunder shall be complete and of sufficient duration to allow adequate observation of the possible approach of other vehicles or pedestrians before proceeding with safety. A rolling stop or a momentary stop shall not comply with the provisions hereof. 
(6)  At a speed in excess of posted limits. 
(7)  At a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard for the actual and potential hazards then existing. The speed of a vehicle shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any object, person, vehicle or other conveyance on such premises and in compliance with legal requirements and using due care. 
(8)  By backing, turning or otherwise maneuvering in an unsafe manner or without regard for the actual or potential hazards then existing. 
(c)  No person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, temporarily or otherwise, upon the following designated areas of the premises: 
(1)  Any portion of such premises where and at the time when stopping or standing is prohibited by appropriate signs indicating the prohibition of any stopping or standing. 
(2)  Any portion of such premises marked as a fire lane. 
(3)  Except for a motor vehicle used by a physically disabled person as defined under Wis. Stats. § 346.503(1), any portion of such premises reserved by official traffic signs indicating the restriction for vehicles displaying special registration plates which designates the vehicle as a vehicle used by a physically disabled person. 
(Code 1997, § 7.11; Cr. #350)  
Sec. 48-13. - Motor vehicles; operation on public and private land. 
(a)  Application of section. This section is intended to regulate the operation of motor vehicles in areas where the state traffic laws and this chapter do not apply. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Motor driven vehicle means any conveyance which is propelled by a mechanical power source whether or not capable of being licensed to be driven upon the public highways, except snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles which are regulated by other ordinances, and vehicles operated as maintenance vehicles. 
Owner means all persons or entities which possess any ownership or leasehold interest in a particular private parcel of land upon which motor driven vehicles as herein defined are presently being operated or are proposed to be operated. 
Written consent means any dated, written document which is limited to the calendar year in which it is given and which is signed by all persons or entities which possess any ownership or leasehold interest in a particular private parcel of land upon which motor driven vehicles as herein defined are presently being operated or are proposed to be operated. 
(c)  Excessive speed. No motor driven vehicle shall be operated on public or private land at a speed in excess of 25 miles per hour or in excess of a speed which creates a hazard to the person of the operator or to the peace, tranquility, person and property of others, whichever is less. 
(d)  Age of operation. No minor person under the age of 12 years shall operate any motor driven vehicle except on the premises upon which he resides unless he is under the direct supervision of an adult person over the age of 18 years who shall in all respects be responsible for the activities of said minor person. 
(e)  Operator to wear helmet. No person shall operate any motor driven vehicle on public or private land unless the operator's compartment is fully enclosed by a metal roof or roll cage or unless the operator is wearing a helmet which is designed to furnish adequate protection against head injury. A helmet shall be viewed as furnishing adequate protection within the terms of this section only for operators of motor driven vehicles with two wheels or those motor driven vehicles with more than two wheels which have a gross weight of 500 pounds or less. 
(f)  TrespassPrivate. 
(1)  No person shall operate any motor driven vehicle upon private property upon which he does not reside or which he does not own, unless he has first received the specific written consent of all owners of said property. Any person apprehended operating any motor driven vehicle upon private property upon which he does not reside or which is not owned by him shall be presumed to be in violation of this section and such presumption shall be rebutted only by the prompt subsequent display of a written owner's consent which conforms to this provision. 
(2)  In the event a citation is issued and the recipient displays written consent by the private property owner before or in court, which complies with this section, then the case shall be dismissed without costs by the city. 
(3)  Any private property owner who wishes to give prior written consent to an operator of a motor driven vehicle to use his property may do so by filing a copy of same with the police department. In the event that such prior written consent is filed with the police department, then in that event only, any operation of motor driven vehicles upon property owned by the person who has filed such consent shall be treated within the terms of this chapter as being with the said owner's consent. 
(g)  Operation near buildings. No person shall operate any motor driven vehicle within 500 feet of any building or structure which is on public land or which is on private property upon which he does not reside or upon which he does not possess the written consent of the owner to operate a motor driven vehicle. In any event, no person shall operate a motor driven vehicle in such close proximity to a building or structure such as would pose a hazard to their person and to the peace, tranquility, person or property of others. 
(h)  Operation on public lands. No person shall operate any motor driven vehicle upon any public lands, including, but not limited to, highways, highway rights-of-way, streets, street rights-of-way, roadways, road rights-of-way, sidewalks, sidewalk rights-of-way, parklands, waysides, bridle paths, bicycle trails, drainage ditches or basins, unless the said area is specifically designated as an area that has been set aside for the operation of motor driven vehicles, or in the event that the area is a highway, highway right-of-way, street, street right-of-way, sidewalk, sidewalk right-of-way, roadway or road right-of-way then, in that event only, no person operating a motor driven vehicle shall cross the same unless he does so by the most direct route practicable, in a safe manner and so as to not disturb the peace, tranquility and property of others. Public land also includes any land owned by a government or a government agency where the state traffic laws in this chapter do not apply. 
(Code 1997, § 7.115; Cr. # 699 )  
Sec. 48-14. - Low-speed vehicles permitted. 
(a)  Definition. A "low-speed vehicle" (LSV) means a self-propelled motor vehicle that conforms to the definition and requirements as adopted in the federal motor vehicle safety standards for "low-speed vehicles" under 49 CFR 571.3(b) and 571.500. "Low-speed vehicle" does not include golf carts. 
(b)  Requirements. LSVs shall be four-wheeled and have a speed range of at least 20 mph and not more than 25 mph on a paved surface and have a gross vehicle weight at rest of less than 2,500 pounds. LSVs shall have: 
(1)  Head lamps. 
(2)  Front and rear turn signals. 
(3)  Stop lamps. 
(4)  Reflex reflectors: One red on each side as far to the rear as practicable, and one red on the rear (three total). 
(5)  An exterior mirror mounted on the driver's side, and either an exterior mirror on the passenger side or an interior rearview mirror. 
(6)  A parking brake. 
(7)  A windshield that conforms to the requirements of the federal motor vehicle safety standard on glazing materials (49 CFR 571.205). 
(8)  A vehicle identification number (VIN) that complies with federal law (49 CFR 565). 
(9)  A Type 1 or Type 2 seatbelt assembly conforming to 49 CFR 571.209 and federal motor vehicle safety standard No. 209 for each designated seating position. 
(10)  Meets the general test conditions under 49 CFR 571.50056. 
(c)  Permitted users of low-speed vehicles. To use a LSV on city streets, the operator must have a valid Wisconsin driver's license. 
(d)  Operation. Operation of a LSV within the City of Delafield is permitted on roadways and alleys located within the territorial boundaries of the City of Delafield, subject to the following prohibitions: 
(1)  Operation of a LSV is prohibited on any roadway with a speed limit greater than 35 mph. 
(2)  Operation of a LSV is prohibited on any municipal sidewalk or recreational trail. 
(3)  Operation of a LSV is prohibited within any municipal park, golf course, or recreational area except on a roadway or parking area routinely open to motor vehicle traffic. 
(4)  Headlamps must be on at all times during operation of a LSV on city streets. 
(e)  Operational requirements of low-speed vehicles. LSVs shall comply with all state and local traffic laws, including, but not limited to, this chapter, and owners and operators of LSVs shall be subject to citations and forfeitures for any violations. 
(f)  Registration. LSVs operated within the City of Delafield shall be registered with the Wisconsin department of transportation and shall display that registration in accordance with Wis. Stats. ch. 341. 
(g)  Enforcement. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to a forfeiture as provided in section 48-16. 
(h)  Severability. In any portion of this section or its application to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the validity of this section as a whole, or any other provision herein and its application to other persons or circumstances shall not be affected. 
(Code 1997, § 7.12; Cr. #639)  
Sec. 48-15. - Bicycle regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bicycle means every device propelled by the feet acting upon pedals and having wheels any two of which are not less than 14 inches in diameter. 
Bicycle lane means that portion of a roadway set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles or other modes of travel where permitted under Wis. Stats. § 349.23(2)(a), and so designated by appropriate signs and markings. 
Bicycle way means any path or sidewalk or portion thereof designated for the use of bicycles. 
Bike route means any bicycle lane, bicycle way or highway which has been duly designated and which is identified by appropriate signs and markings. 
(b)  Rules of the road. 
(1)  Riding bicycle on bicycle lane. 
a.  Unless two-way traffic is authorized, every person operating a bicycle upon a bicycle lane shall ride in the same direction in which vehicular traffic on the lane of the roadway nearest the bicycle lane is traveling. 
b.  Two-way traffic may be authorized on any portion of a roadway which it has set aside as a bicycle lane. Appropriate traffic signs shall be installed on all bicycle lanes open to two-way traffic. 
c.  1.  A person operating a bicycle may enter or leave a bicycle lane only at intersections or at driveways adjoining the bicycle lane. 
2.  A person may leave a bicycle lane at any point by dismounting from the bicycle and walking it out of the lane. A person may enter a bicycle lane at any point by walking his bicycle into the lane and then mounting it. 
d.  Every person operating a bicycle upon a bicycle lane shall exercise due care and give an audible signal when passing a bicycle rider proceeding in the same direction. 
e.  Every operator of a bicycle entering a bicycle lane shall yield the right-of-way to all bicycles in the bicycle lane. Upon leaving a bicycle lane, the operator of a bicycle shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles and pedestrians. 
(2)  Riding bicycle on bicycle way. 
a.  Every person operating a bicycle upon a bicycle way shall: 
1.  Exercise due care and give an audible signal when passing a bicycle rider or a pedestrian proceeding in the same direction. 
2.  Obey each traffic signal or sign facing a roadway which runs parallel and adjacent to a bicycle way. 
b.  Every person operating a bicycle upon a bicycle way open to two-way traffic shall ride on the right side of the bicycle way. 
c.  Every operator of a bicycle entering a bicycle way shall yield the right-of-way to all bicycles and pedestrians in the bicycle way. 
(3)  Riding bicycle on sidewalk. When bicycles are permitted on the sidewalk under Wis. Stats. § 346.94(1), every person operating a bicycle upon a sidewalk shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall exercise due care and give an audible signal when passing a bicycle rider or pedestrian proceeding in the same direction. 
(4)  Riding bicycle on roadway. 
a.  Unless preparing to make a left turn, every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway carrying two-way traffic shall ride as near as practicable to the right edge of the unobstructed traveled roadway, including operators who are riding two abreast. On one-way roadways, the operator of the bicycle shall ride as near as practicable to the right edge or left edge of the unobstructed traveled roadway, including operators who are riding two abreast. Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall exercise due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction, allowing a minimum of three feet between the bicycle and the vehicle. 
b.  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall ride single-file on all roadways which have center lines or lane lines indicated by painting or other markings. On roadways not divided by painted or other marked centerlines or lane lines, bicycle operators may ride two abreast. 
c.  Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway but moped riders shall use such path only if signs specifically indicate that use of the path is required for both bicycles and mopeds. 
d.  No person may operate a bicycle or moped upon a roadway where a sign is erected indicating that bicycle or moped riding is prohibited. 
e.  Every rider of a bicycle shall, upon entering on a highway, yield the right-of-way to motor vehicles. 
(5)  Special rules applicable to bicycles. Whenever a bicycle is operated upon a highway, bicycle lane or bicycle way the following rules apply: 
a.  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
b.  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
c.  No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the operator from keeping at least one hand upon the handle bars. 
d.  No person riding a bicycle shall attach himself or his bicycle to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
e.  No person may ride a moped upon a bicycle way. 
(6)  Lamps and other equipment on bicycles. 
a.  No person may operate a bicycle upon a highway, bicycle lane or bicycle way during hours of darkness unless such bicycle is equipped with or the operator is wearing a lamp emitting a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front of such bicycle. Such bicycle shall also be equipped with a red reflector that has a diameter of at least two inches of surface area on the rear so mounted and maintained as to be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 500 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to but not in lieu of the red reflector. 
b.  No person may operate a bicycle upon a highway, bicycle lane or bicycle way unless it is equipped with a brake in good working condition, adequate to control the movement of and to stop the bicycle whenever necessary. 
c.  No bicycle may be equipped with nor may any person riding upon a bicycle use any siren or compression whistle. 
(7)  Use of controlled access highways, expressways and freeways. 
a.  No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from a controlled access highway, expressway or freeway, except through an opening provided for that purpose. 
b.  No pedestrian or person riding a bicycle or other non-motorized vehicle or person operating a power driven cycle or motor bicycle shall go upon any expressway or freeway when official signs have been erected prohibiting such person from using the expressway or freeway. 
(Code 1997, § 7.13; Cr. #706 )  
Sec. 48-16. - Penalty. 
The penalty for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a forfeiture and penalty assessment, if required by Wis. Stats. § 757.07, a jail assessment, if required by Wis. Stats. § 53.46(1), plus any applicable fees prescribed in Wis. Stats. ch. 814. 
(1)  State forfeiture statutes. Any forfeiture for violation of the statutes adopted by reference in section 48-1 shall conform to the forfeiture permitted to be imposed for violation of such statutes in the uniform deposit and misdemeanor bail schedule of the Wisconsin Judicial Conference, including variations or increases for subsequent offenses, which schedule is adopted by reference. 
(2)  Local regulations. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the penalty for violation of sections 48-3 through 48-6 and 48-8 shall be as provided in section 1-4. 
(3)  Parking violations. 
	Forfeiture 
	Minimum 	Maximum 
346.51(1) 	Improper parking on/off roadway 	$30.00 	$300.00 
346.52(1) 	Stopping/standing in prohibited areas 	$20.00 	$40.00 
	Second conviction within one year 	$50.00 	$100.00 
346.52(2) 	Stopping/standing on highway by grade school 	$20.00 	$40.00 
	Second conviction within one year 	$50.00 	$100.00

	Second conviction within one year 	$50.00 	$100.00

	Second conviction within one year 	$50.00 	$100.00

346.55(2) 	Parking vehicle for sale on highway 	$30.00 	$300.00

(Code 1997, § 7.20; Am. MSC '91; Am. MSC '92; Rep. & Recr. #144; # 699 )  
Sec. 48-17. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Enforcement procedure. This chapter shall be enforced according to Wis. Stats. §§ 23.33, 66.0114, 345.11 to 345.61, and 350.17 and ch. 800, as amended, revised and renumbered from time to time. 
(b)  Deposit. 
(1)  Any person arrested for a violation of this chapter may make a deposit of money as directed by the arresting officer at the police station or at the office of the clerk of court or by mailing the deposit to such places. The arresting officer or the person receiving the deposit shall notify the arrested person, orally or in writing, that: 
a.  If the person makes a deposit for a violation of a traffic regulation, he need not appear in court at the time fixed in the citation and will be deemed to have tendered a plea of no contest and submitted to a forfeiture and penalty assessment, if required by Wis. Stats. § 757.07, a jail assessment, if required by Wis. Stats. § 53.46(1), plus any applicable fees prescribed in Wis. Stats. ch. 814, not to exceed the amount of the deposit that the court may accept as provided in Wis. Stats. § 345.37. 
b.  If the person fails to make a deposit for a violation of a traffic regulation or appear in court at the time fixed in the citation, the court may enter a default judgment finding the person guilty of the offense or issue a warrant for his arrest. 
(2)  The amount of the deposit shall be determined in accordance with the deposit schedule established by the Wisconsin Judicial Conference and shall include the penalty assessment established under Wis. Stats. § 757.07, a jail assessment, if required by Wis. Stats. § 53.46(1), and court costs. If a deposit schedule has not been established, the arresting officer shall require the alleged offender to deposit the forfeiture established by the municipal judge, which shall include the penalty assessment established under Wis. Stats. § 757.07. Deposits for nonmoving violations shall not include the penalty assessment. 
(3)  The officer or clerk receiving payment in person shall issue the arrested person a receipt therefor as required by Wis. Stats. § 345.26(3)(b). 
(c)  Petition to reopen judgment. Whenever a person has been convicted in this state on the basis of a forfeiture of deposit or a plea of guilty or no contest and the person was not informed as required under Wis. Stats. § 345.27(1) and (2), the person may, within 60 days after being notified of the revocation or suspension of the operating privilege, petition the court to reopen the judgment and grant him an opportunity to defend on merits. If the court finds that the petitioner was not informed as required under Wis. Stats. § 345.27(1) and (2), the court shall order the judgment reopened. The court order reopening the judgment automatically reinstates the revoked or suspended operating privilege. 
(d)  Notice of demerit points and receipts. Every officer accepting a forfeited penalty or money deposit under this chapter shall receipt therefor in triplicate as provided in Wis. Stats. § 345.26(3)(b). Every officer accepting a stipulation under the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 343.28, 345.26(1)(a) and 345.27(2), and shall require the alleged violator to sign a statement of notice in substantially the form contained on the uniform traffic citation and complaint promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11, as amended, revised, renumbered from time to time. 
(e)  Forfeitures; officer to post bond, qualify. Any officer accepting deposits or forfeited penalties, except parking violation forfeitures, under this chapter shall deliver them to city hall within 20 days after receipt. After the court orders a forfeiture, it shall deliver the money to the city treasurer. Any officer authorized to accept deposits under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or this chapter shall qualify by taking the oath and filing an official bond in the sum of $500.00 as described by Wis. Stats. § 19.01. 
(Code 1997, § 7.21; Am. MSC '90; Am. #699 )  
Chapter 50 - UTILITIES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Agreement to comply with water utility operating rules. 
All persons now receiving a water supply from the utility, or who may hereafter make application therefor, shall be considered as having agreed to be bound by all rules and regulations as filed with the state Public Service Commission. 
(Code 1997, § 13.01; Rep. and Recr. # 741 )
