8 	Turbine Class II 	2400 	120.0 
10 	Turbine Class II 	3800 	190.0 
12 	Turbine Class II 	5000 	250.0 
 
(c)  Meters other than listed may be approved by the utility on a case-by-case basis. WCA charges will be based upon the AWWA safe maximum operating capacity for the meter adjusted for equivalent DUEs based upon one DUE equaling a 20 GPM safe maximum operating capacity. 
(d)  WCA assessments may be increased annually as determined by the city council to pay for the costs of additional waterworks facilities that are constructed or placed in service. 
(e)  Water capacity assessments may, in hardship cases, be payable in installments of equal principal plus interest as determined by the city council. 
(f)  There is capacity in the initial system to service an area considerably beyond the properties fronting the proposed mains. The city council directs that additional oversizing costs in future extensions may also be paid from WCAs. 
(Code 1997, § 13.27)  
Sec. 50-43. - Maintenance of services. 
(a)  All building water services from the point of connection of curb stop to the house or to the premises served must be maintained free of defective conditions, by and at the expense of the owner or occupant of the property served. 
(b)  The service pipe from the main, to and through the curb stop, will be maintained and kept in repair and when worn out, replaced at the expense of the utility. The property owner shall maintain the service pipe from the curb stop to the point of use. All adjustments to stop boxes due to landscaping or other changes in grade level, except those performed by public contract, will be the responsibility of the property owner. 
(c)  If the property owner does not repair an existing leak between the curb stop and the building within 24 hours, the water will be shut off and remain off until the repair is made. 
(Code 1997, § 13.28)  
Sec. 50-44. - Severance of private wells. 
(a)  Severance from municipal system. Upon connection to the water utility's municipal water system, the owner of any private well shall sever completely from the municipal system the operation of his private water supply. Once the private water supply has been severed from the municipal water system, there shall be no reconnection of said private supply to the municipal system. 
(b)  Method of severance. Severance of a private well consists of disconnection and removal of the well lateral at the well casing, and thereafter any use of the private well shall be by separate water piping. 
(c)  Private wells to be tested and those testing unsafe abandoned and sealed. 
(1)  Private wells where a municipal connection exists. Private wells, after complete separation from the municipal system, shall be allowed to be maintained by the owner, if said owner complies with the following procedure and receives a permit therefor. 
(2)  Safe well test. The city council, or its agents, will, annually, at its discretion, test all private wells on those premises served by municipal water. Owner will permit the water utility or its agents to collect a sample from said private well following correct sampling procedures. Said water sample collected by the water utility will then be provided to a certified testing laboratory for analysis. The property owner will be charged the actual cost of such analysis, plus $25.00 administrative charge, including, but not limited to, cost of collection, postage and handling. If the water sample tests bacteriologically safe, owner will receive from the water utility a permit for private well usage for ensuing year. If the owner of a private well disputes the test performed by the water utility, said owner will have the right to provide to the water utility the results of its own water test performed by a certified water testing laboratory under the terms of this section or the well will be permanently abandoned as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  Abandonment of private wells when determined by the water utility, as needed. 
(1)  In order to prevent contamination of groundwater and to protect public health, safety and welfare by assuring that unused, unsafe or noncomplying well or wells which may serve as conduits for contamination or wells which may be illegally cross connected to the municipal water system, the water utility will review such wells to determine that the wells are properly abandoned. 
(2)  All wells located on premises served by the municipal water system shall be abandoned in accordance with the terms of this section and Wis. Admin. Code chs. NR 811.10 and 812.26, by no later than one year from the date of connection to the municipal water system, unless a well operation permit has been obtained by the well owner from the water utility. 
(3)  The water utility may grant a permit to a private well owner to operate a well as outlined in this section providing the conditions of said section are met. An owner may be required to renew a well operation permit by submitting information verifying that the conditions of this section are met. The water utility, or its agent, may conduct inspections or have water quality tests conducted at the applicant's expense to obtain or verify information necessary for consideration of a permit application or renewal. Permit applications and renewals shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk. The following conditions must be met for issuance or renewal of a well operation permit: 
a.  The well and pump installation meet or are upgraded to meet the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 812. 
b.  The well construction and pump installation have a history of producing bacteriologically safe water as evidenced by at least two samplings taken a minimum of two weeks apart. No exception to this condition may be made for unsafe wells, unless the DNR approves, in writing, the continued use of the well. 
c.  There are no cross connections between the well and pump installation and the municipal water system. 
d.  The proposed use of the well and pump installation can be justified as being necessary in addition to water provided by the municipal water system. 
e.  All wells abandoned under the jurisdiction of this section or rule shall be abandoned according to the procedures and methods of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 812.26. All debris, pump, piping, unsealed liners and any other obstructions which may interfere with sealing operations shall be removed prior to abandonment. 
f.  The owner of the well, or the owner's agent, shall notify the city clerk at least 48 hours prior to commencement of any well abandonment activities. The abandonment of the well shall be observed by the city administrator or his designee. 
g.  An abandonment report form, supplied by the DNR, shall be submitted by the well owner to the city clerk and the DNR within ten days of the completion of the well abandonment. 
(4)  Any well owner violating any provision of this section shall upon conviction be punished by forfeiture of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 and the cost of prosecution. Each day of violation is a separate offense. If any person fails to comply with this section for more than ten days after receiving written notice of the violation, the municipality may impose a penalty and cause the well abandonment to be performed and the expense to be assessed as a special tax against the property. 
(Code 1997, § 13.29)  
Sec. 50-45. - Continuation of private wells permitted. 
(a)  Use of private wells upon connection to municipal water service. 
(1)  Intent. Since it is recognized that the entire private water supply in the water utility has the potential for pollution, the building's distribution system upon connection to the municipal water system shall be completely severed from the private well. If such private well does not test "safe" according to standards of the state DNR and Waukesha County health department, such well shall be permanently sealed and abandoned in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 112.21. 
(2)  Test results to be filed. The owners of those wells testing "safe" and being utilized for outside chores not involving human consumption of water shall on or before June 1, commencing the first year following the year of severance, file with the water utility test results performed by the Waukesha County health department, or recognized private testing laboratory, showing that the water from such well is bacteriologically safe. Testing such well shall be performed by a person working for the testing laboratory from a sample obtained from the well and that person shall certify the test results. 
(3)  Test required. Such well tests shall be required every five years before the renewal well permit is issued. 
(4)  Severance from private well supply. 
a.  Once the private water supply has been severed from the municipal system, there shall be no reconnection of said private supply to the municipal system. After severance of the private well, no cross connection between the public and private system will be allowed. Those owners that desire to keep the private well in service shall install a backflow preventer approved by the water utility. The backflow preventer shall be installed in the outlet piping from the water meter and no outlets shall be permitted between the water meter and the backflow preventer. All municipal water entering the building must pass through the reduced pressure backflow preventer before being distributed for other use. 
b.  Backflow preventers shall be installed and maintained in compliance with Wis. Admin. Code § ILHR 82.41. 
(5)  Permanent abandonment procedure. 
a.  Owners intending to permanently abandon a well will notify the water utility of the date of the intended abandonment. The water utility will be permitted to fully inspect the entire process of abandonment. Owner will comply with Wis. Admin. Code § NR 112.21(1) and (3). In the event the owner of a private well that has tested unsafe or has failed to obtain a well permit refuses or neglects to permanently abandon said well on or before September 1 of each year, the water utility, or its agents or contractors may, without notice, enter upon owner's property and permanently seal said well in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code § NR 112.21(1) and (3) and the cost thereof shall be presented to the city treasurer who shall place said amount on the tax roll as a special charge pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.60(16). 
b.  Any person who shall attempt to abandon said well without having first notified the water utility shall be subject to the requirements of furnishing the water utility proof of proper compliance with Wis. Adm. Code § NR 112.21(1) and (3). In the event owner is unable to furnish satisfactory proof to the water utility that said well was properly abandoned under said Administrative Code provision, the water utility shall have the right to enter upon the property and perform all necessary tasks to verify that the abandonment of said well was done under the Administrative Code procedure and specifications. Any and all costs incurred by the water utility in permanently sealing said well shall be presented to the city treasurer who shall place said amount on the tax roll as a special charge pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.60(16). 
(6)  Wells testing unsafe or wells not having a permit. All private wells in the water utility that test unsafe or have not received a permit as provided for herein shall be immediately removed from use and shall on or before September 1 of each year be permanently sealed and abandoned as provided below. 
(7)  Temporary sealing not permitted. Because of the clear and present danger from the water supply serving private wells in the water district, private wells, whether within or without the municipal water service area, will not be permitted to be temporarily sealed. 
(8)  Permit procedure for new wells. New wells will be permitted to be constructed only under the following conditions: 
a.  Said new well must be located in an area where municipal water service is not available and cannot readily be made available by the water utility. 
b.  Owner or applicant applies to Waukesha County health department and the city and receives a permit for the construction of the new well. 
c.  The new well is constructed in complete conformity with state and local regulations and codes. The owner of the new well, before it will be permitted to be put into use, will furnish to the water utility test results verified by a certified testing laboratory that said well water is bacteriologically safe. 
d.  All new wells constructed within the water utility limits will be permitted on the condition that the owner agrees that once municipal water is available to the property, said private well owner will immediately connect to municipal water and sever the private well. 
e.  Whenever municipal water service is available or can readily be made available by the water utility, no new wells for potable or nonpotable water will be permitted to be constructed and the owner of the property will be required to connect to the municipal service. 
(Code 1997, § 13.30)  
Sec. 50-46. - Connection of malfunctioning wells. 
In the event that the water utility undertakes a project and the project adversely affects the local well water supply of local residents, or if the water utility anticipates that a project may adversely affect the local well water supply, then the water utility at its option may undertake the following steps: 
(1)  The water utility shall request that the residents or property owners allow the water utility to test and inspect individual wells. Such testing and inspection may include but is not limited to: 
a.  Testing for potability of water supply. 
b.  Removal of pump for water level inspection. 
c.  General inspection of well pump facilities. 
(2)  If during the inspection of the well, either the well or appurtenant facilities are damaged through no fault of the property owner, the water utility may have the damages repaired at no cost to the owner, or, if public water is available the owner may connect to the public water supply and the water utility will credit the owner for the cost of the damages against any outstanding assessments or water connection fees. The water utility reserves the right to prorate the cost of repairs if it is determined that the age or existing condition of the owner's facilities were at or near the point of failure at the time of damage. Determination will be made by the water utility or its authorized representatives. 
(3)  If the owner cooperates with the water utility and allows inspection of the owner's well, and if the well is determined to be operating within normal standards as defined in Wis. Admin. Code § 112, and it is determined that the water utility's operations have adversely affected the owner's well, then the following shall apply: 
a.  The water utility reserves the right to determine if the well will return to its normal functioning capacity. This includes waiting for 14 days after termination of water utility activities to determine if the adverse effect on the private well was minor in nature. The water utility shall provide interim relief. 
b.  If the well is determined to be permanently damaged then the property owner shall connect to the public water supply. The water utility shall waive the water capacity assessment fee and shall pay all costs related to the connection of the residence to the public water supply. The resident will still be responsible for the payment of all frontage and right-of-way lateral costs and pay those costs in accordance with the final resolution for the respective water main project. The water utility shall be allowed to approve or deny the plumbing contractor that will be making the residential connection. The water utility will only pay for those costs associated with the connection of the public water supply to the point of the meter horn and the abandonment of the owner's well, or at the water utility's option, improve or upgrade the existing private well. 
(4)  Documentation necessary in lieu of testing. 
a.  If the owner fails to cooperate with the water utility and does not allow for testing and inspection of the owner's well, the owner shall provide documentation that the water utility's activities caused the owner's well to malfunction. Such documentation shall include, but is not limited to, well logs and tests that indicate that the well was properly functioning immediately prior to the commencement of water utility activities. 
b.  If it is determined that the water utility's activities adversely affected the owner's well then the water utility shall connect the owner to the public water supply as in subsections (1)a through c of this section. 
c.  If it cannot be determined that the water utility activities adversely affected the owner's well or documentation cannot be provided by the owner of a properly functioning well as per Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 112, then no reimbursement will be made to the owner. 
(Code 1997, § 13.31)  
Sec. 50-47. - Connections. 
(a)  Required connections. To assure preservation of public health, comfort and safety, the owner of any house, building, or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other habitation, situated within the city and adjacent to a water main, or in a block through which a water main extends, is hereby required at the owner's expense to install a lateral and to connect such facilities to the structural plumbing in accordance with the provisions of this article within 12 months after the public water main first becomes operational, upon receipt of notice from the city administrator or his designee; or if an immediate health hazard exists, within ten days, upon receipt of notice from the city health officer or the city building inspector, unless said required connection is waived by resolution of the common council. 
(b)  If a person fails to comply with said notice to connect within the given period of time, the city may, at its option, cause such connection to be made and bill the property owner for such costs. If such costs are not paid within 30 days, such costs shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property, unless the owner within 30 days after completion of the work files a sworn affidavit with the city clerk stating that he cannot pay such amount in one sum and asking that it be levied in not to exceed five equal annual installments, and the amount shall be so collected with interest at a rate which is sufficient to recover the city's cost of borrowed funds or interest lost plus one percentage point per annum from the completion of the work, the unpaid balance to be a special tax lien. 
(Code 1997, § 13.32)  
Sec. 50-48. - Billing and payment. 
(a)  Billing. Billing for water service shall be on a quarterly basis with quarters ending March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31. The property owner is held responsible for all water bills on the real estate he/she owns. All water bills and notices relative to water service shall be addressed to the owner and mailed to the address of the premises referred to on such bill or notice or to such other address as requested in writing by the owner. 
(b)  Failure to receive bill no excuse. Reasonable care shall be exercised in proper delivery of water bills. Failure to receive a water bill shall not relieve any owner of responsibility of payment of a water bill within the prescribed period, nor exempt any person from any penalty imposed for delinquency in the payment thereof. 
(c)  Penalty for polluting water or injuring waterworks. No person shall willfully pollute or otherwise injure any water supplied by the system in any tunnel, aqueduct, reservoir, pipe, etc.; to willfully injure or cause damage to the system, building, machinery or fixture pertaining thereto; to willfully and without authority of the water utility impede or divert the flow of water in any tunnel, aqueduct, pipe, etc., belonging to such system; to willfully and without written authority of the city council to otherwise cause to leak any tunnel, aqueduct, reservoir, pipe, etc., used in the system to hold, convey or distribute water. 
(d)  Damage recovery. 
(1)  The water utility shall have the right to recover from any person any expense incurred by such water utility for repair or replacement of any water pipe, curb cock, valve, hydrant or valve box damaged in any manner by any person by reason of operation of any electrical system, performance of any work under their control or by negligence. 
(2)  Owners or operators of motor vehicles shall be liable for the cost of repair of any hydrant damaged by such vehicle. The water utility or the city shall not be responsible for the damage caused to the motor vehicle or individuals by reason of such accident. 
(Code 1997, § 13.33)  
Sec. 50-49. - City of Delafield Wellhead Protection Ordinance. 
City of Delafield Wellhead Protection Ordinance, section 50-7 of the Municipal Code, and all amendments thereto are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1997, § 13.34)  
Sec. 50-50. - Penalties. 
Any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $100.00, nor more than $500.00 plus the costs of prosecution for each violation, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall have such costs added to their real property as a lien against the property. Each day a violation exists or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1997, § 13.35)  
Secs. 50-5150-73. - Reserved.
